PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are opposed to any moves to cut funding to universities. We believe that funding cuts to universities can only have a negative impact on society and will impede the development of our Nation.

Furthermore, that we are opposed to any increased to the annual amount payable by students via the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). We believe that increases to HECS will discourage individuals from enrolling in universities. We believe that university entry should be based upon relative merit, not relative wealth. We believe that education has a direct social and economic benefit and appropriate levels of funding should be made available from public revenue.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will not cut funding to universities or increase HECS fees.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should legislate to establish national Gun Controls binding upon all States.
That a National Register of guns and those possessing guns be established, and that a penalty of one year imprisonment be established for any person found to be in possession of an unregistered gun.

That the private ownership, or possession of automatic and semi‐automatic guns of all calibre's be made illegal and strong penalties introduced for all those found to be in breach of these provisions.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are opposed to any moves to cut funding to universities. We believe that funding cuts to universities can only be to the detriment of an educated and democratic society. We believe that a broadly accessible and liberating higher education system is fundamental to efforts at creating a more just and equitable society.
In particular we are opposed to any attempts to:

PARA.TAB: introduce up front fees for any students, including any attempt to allow universities to charge up front fees to students enrolled in excess of Commonwealth funded quotas;
increase the level of debt incurred by students through the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS);
lower the level at which HECS debts must be repaid through the taxation system;
replace the grant based component of the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY scheme with a loans scheme;
expand the loans component of AUSTUDY/ ABSTUDY;
cut funding on a per student basis, in particular operating grants; and
cut the number of Commonwealth funded places already in the system or promised during the previous Parliament.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will not cut funding to universities or increase the financial burden on current or future students by raising fees or reducing access to financial assistance. We call on the Parliament to at least maintain current funding to higher education with a view to increase funding per student and the number of student places available in the remainder of the thirty‐eighth parliament.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: that the overwhelming majority of Australians support uniform, national gun laws and the associated compensation measures as agreed between the Prime Minister, State Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the ACT and NT.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask that the Senate:

PARA.TAB: continue to demonstrate its firm support for these measures;
take all possible action to expedite their implementation; and
resist all calls for the control measures to be watered down or abandoned.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

The purpose of the bill is to amend the Civil Aviation Act 1988 to allow the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to appoint an additional member and a Deputy Chair to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority Board, both of whom are to have aviation experience.

Introduction and passage in the Winter sittings 1996 is required as the Government's aviation policy highlights the need for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to develop into a cohesive and close knit organisation, with a strong and cooperative relationship with industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1996.
I also table a statement of reasons justifying the need for this bill to be considered during these sittings and seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Purpose of Bill

There are currently limitations on the transfer of the Development Allowance benefit where ownership of a project is transferred to another entity after application for the allowance but before registration; and across different entity structures after registration but before pre‐qualification for the Allowance. The amendments will allow all types of project restructures of a bona fide nature and for genuine commercial reasons, and are conducive to completing the carrying out of the project. To be effective, they will be retrospective and will apply from 1 January 1993, which is the date applications for the Allowance closed. The Bill also contains minor technical amendments to Infrastructure Borrowings provisions.
Reasons for seeking introduction and passage of the Bill in the 1996 Winter sittings

PARA.TAB: Priority status was obtained for these measures for the 1995 Spring Sittings. However, while the 1995 Bill passed all stages in the House of Representatives, it was not passed by the Senate due to the pressure of business. The main reason for the request to maintain priority status is that existing statutory deadlines for registration and pre‐qualification for the Allowance mean that passage in the 1996 Winter Sittings is considered essential.

A project must be registered for the Allowance before it can apply for a pre‐qualification certificate which is a pre‐requisite for eligibility for the 10% tax deduction when the relevant plant is either used for the purpose of producing assessable income or installed ready for use for that purpose.
An application for a pre‐qualification certificate is to be given to the Development Allowance Authority (DAA) before 1 August 1996.

Therefore, it is essential and time critical that the amendments on project restructures are both introduced and passed in the Winter sittings. Otherwise they may not be passed until the Spring Sittings in 1996, in which event it will be impossible for the DAA to register projects. As a result, the applicants cannot prepare and lodge valid applications for pre‐qualification.

Legal advice from Attorney‐General's have indicated that the DAA has no power to accept an application for pre‐qualification prior to registration. There is also no discretion to the DAA to accept an application for pre‐qualification after 31 July 1996 deadline. Eligible applicants under the amended provisions may miss out on the Allowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the explanatory medmorandum to this bill, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now be read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

Mr President, the Government's Law and Justice Policy foreshadowed a "statute stocktake" to repair existing Commonwealth legislation, with a view to having the repair process in sight of completion by 2001.
The processes for the statute stocktake, and a program for the next 5 years, are still to be worked out.
However, this Statute Law Revision Bill begins the work of repairing the Commonwealth statute book.
The bill deals with four aspects of repairing the statute book.
First, it repeals a number of acts whose operation is exhausted.
Secondly, it corrects minor clerical and drafting errors in various current acts.

The kinds of errors being corrected are spelling mistakes, mistakes in punctuation, mistakes in the numbering or lettering of parts of acts (for example, incorrect numbering of subsections or incorrect lettering of paragraphs) and misdescribed amendments.
A misdescribed amendment is one that either incorrectly describes the text to be amended or specifies the wrong location for the insertion of new text.
Although the intended effect of the amendments is usually clear, it can be confusing or misleading to leave these errors uncorrected.
In particular, misdescribed amendments can delay the publication of official reprints, and can affect the accuracy of commercial consolidations of acts.

For instance, an amendment that purports to require a new provision to be inserted after a non-existent provision would probably be given some meaning by a court if the general intention of the amendment was clear.
However, it would be inappropriate to publish an official reprint when the act cannot be consolidated because the proper location of the new provision is not clear.
Correcting errors of these kinds does not change the law.
However, it ensures that consolidated acts can be published, and without confusing mistakes.
In some cases, this may have a significant impact on the accessibility of legislation.

I confirm to the Senate that the Ministerial Council for Corporations has been consulted and, to the extent necessary, has approved the amendments to the Corporations Law which are included in this bill in accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on Future Corporate Regulation in Australia.
Thirdly, the bill brings up to date a large number of references in acts to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973.
In 1988 the name of the act was changed from Remuneration Tribunals (plural) Act to Remuneration Tribunal (singular) Act.
Although the old form of the title in legislation does not create any legal problems, it is desirable that all references to the act reflect the current form of its title.
Finally, the bill continues the process, which has been going on for some years, of altering gender specific language in acts.
The main element in this process is the insertion of feminine pronouns to accompany masculine pronouns wherever they occur.
This bill, while not changing the law, makes many useful improvements to the statute book.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Spring sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 114, relating to Burma, be taken as formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 114.

There is, I believe, a recognition of the urgency and importance of this chamber making a statement in relation to the situation in Burma. There is one important but small reason for that and one larger and significant reason. One reason is that today is the birthday of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. It is a time when all eyes around the world are looking towards the situation in Burma and feeling the pain of that situation on the birthday of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. That is the smaller reason for it being urgent today. The larger reason is that the situation in that country is increasingly concerning and we need to make a public statement.

I circulated a motion for formality. I believe the reason we have not been able to arrive at a formal motion is not any unwillingness to cooperate on the part of any of the parties in this chamber but because of the complexity and sensitivity of the issues in Burma. From discussions with both Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and Senator Schacht, acting on behalf of the Labor Party in relation to this motion, it seems that I have some competing amendments.

BREAK.PARA: I believe it is urgent that we get this debate under way so that we can reach a consensus in this chamber to achieve the greatest possible good in making a public statement that will illustrate the concern we have about the situation in Burma and to say that Australia is taking seriously these concerns and is making a stand on those matters. I urge my colleagues to support the motion for suspension of standing orders to allow us to debate a motion that will constructively assist in giving a voice to the people who are concerned about democracy in Burma now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to the suspension of standing orders. The correct time for debate of this motion is during general business, which is on Thursday. No case has been made out for why it cannot be dealt with at the proper time. It is becoming a habit of certain senators to disrupt the business of the program on days other than general business, just to pursue what they might regard as of political benefit to them at the time. If we did that every day, no government business at all would be transacted in this place. I see no reason at all why this matter cannot be dealt with tomorrow, which is the correct time for dealing with notices of motion that are put up in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore in those circumstances, while I recognise the importance of the issue—there is no dispute about the importance of the issue—no difference will be made between today and tomorrow on the merits of the issue and I am opposed to the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I support the suspension of standing orders. I believe that we could do this very quickly. When you look at the proposal that Senator Hill has kindly given me for an alternative motion and when you look at the motion of Senator Chamarette, you see that much is similar. The Labor Party would support Senator Chamarette's motion, except that we will move an amendment to paragraph (d) which we believe is more appropriately worded in the circumstances.

BREAK.PARA: We think this motion should be carried today in the Senate because today is the birthday of Aung San Suu Kyi—the Nobel Peace Prize winner of four years ago and probably the most well-known leader of political human rights in the world now, a figure of world stature. I am also told that various international radio programs on the short‐wave band will be broadcasting today. These programs are listened to in Burma by people interested in human rights to know that the world is thinking of them. If this motion were carried today, that would be broadcast. I think it would be a great message to those people listening in Burma that today, on Aung San Suu Kyi's birthday, the Australian Senate carried the motion.

I do not want to delay the government's business or use the Senate's time, but I believe we could do this very quickly, in a matter of a few minutes, and get maximum political impact on the human rights issue in Burma. Therefore, the opposition supports the suspension of standing orders.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion no. 114 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) expresses greetings to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi for her birthday on 19 June;
(b) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) with deep concern, the recent moves by the military regime in Burma against the democracy movement in that country,
(ii) reports that the State Law and Order Restoration Council is using `scorched earth' tactics, in the form of looting and burning villages in Kayah State, and
(iii) with approval, the strong statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) in response to renewed repression in Burma;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) welcomes moves by the State Legislature of Massachusetts in the United States of America to ban state contracts with companies doing business in Burma; and
(d) calls on the Government to actively discourage Australian companies from doing business in Burma.

I reiterate that what we are discussing today is not only an expression of greeting to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi for her birthday today, 19 June, but also the deep concern that people throughout the world have felt about the recent moves by the military regime in Burma against the democracy movement in that country.

Only recently, we have heard with grave concern about the increasing number of arrests of those people who were democratically elected in Burma in the elections of 1990 to prevent them meeting together. The movement of people throughout that country has been curtailed by the military regime.

We have heard very disturbing evidence of scorched earth tactics being used in the form of looting and burning in villages in Kayah State. Heaven knows that the information is not as clear and comprehensive as we would wish in relation to other areas and the problems that are being experienced by minority groups in Burma.

We express our approval of the strong stance that this government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) have taken in response to the renewed oppression in Burma. We want to make sure that that stance is supported at every level by this parliament. That is why this motion does two things. It expresses our concern and it urges this government to take its responsibility very seriously and to go even further than the previous government was prepared to go. In the United States moves have been made by the state legislature of Massachusetts to ban state contracts with companies doing business in Burma. As far as I know, that has not yet received total assent but there is pressure in that regard.

We believe that it is time that Australia considered a stronger stance than the one we have taken so far because the situation in Burma is deteriorating rapidly. We can no longer say that constructive engagement is achieving anything. We are standing by and letting a disastrous situation get worse and we are remaining silent. We become culpable when we do that.

The motion I have moved calls on the government to actively discourage Australian companies from doing business in Burma. We read news reports daily of increasing attempts to exploit the situation in Burma, to exploit the willingness of the SLORC to entice trade as a way of building up their support. This is not acceptable. As global citizens we have to voice our protest against it. That is the reason for the motion that is being put to the chamber today. I have heard from the government and from Senator Schacht their concerns about the wording of this motion, so I welcome to the debate the suggestions that are supplied and indicate that we will be prepared to support anything that strengthens the stand of Australia and makes our voice much stronger on these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government seeks to amend this motion. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "Senate", substitute:
(a) congratulates Burma's pro‐democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, on her birthday and commends her courage and determination to bring democracy to Burma;
(b) condemns:

PARA.TAB: (i) the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) for continuing to refuse to accept the verdict of the Burmese people freely expressed at a democratic election, and
(ii) in particular, the latest heavy‐handed attempts by the SLORC to curtail political opposition by introducing draconian penalties for those expressing political dissent; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) urges the Australian Government:

PARA.TAB: (i) to maintain the embargo on the export of defence and defence‐related goods to Burma, and

(ii) in concert with democratic governments world‐wide to press the SLORC to release immediately all political prisoners, to desist from all practices of forced labour and to respect basic human rights and freedoms and democratic expression.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the birthday of Burma's pro-Democracy leader. It is a good occasion, therefore, to recognise her courage and her determination to bring political freedom to her people. Anyone who has been prepared to accept the loss of his or her own freedom for as long as she did in an effort to focus the international community's attention on the plight of the Burmese people and to focus the attention of the SLORC on the determination of the Burmese people to obtain their political freedom deserves the admiration of all of us. Certainly she is an example to the whole international community of one who is prepared to suffer severe personal sacrifice to achieve a political end for her people which is just and fair. We admire her for that. We recognise her internationally for the democratic leadership that she offers the Burmese people.

It is also an occasion to internationally condemn the policies of the SLORC. Those of us who have sat down with the SLORC generals from time to time and tried to influence them to a different way, both positively and negatively, by pointing out the consequences that Burma as a country suffers by not being accepted willingly within the international community, the consequences it has suffered as a result of lack of access to international financial institutions and the like, and the comparisons with other developing nations that are prepared to embrace democracy and become part of a civilised international community that respects human rights and freedoms, those of us who have tried, in a positive sense, to persuade the generals that a reform of their undemocratic regime would earn the respect of their own people and the respect of the international community, understand just how complex the issue is.
The generals will argue, as all generals in these circumstances do, that their first responsibility is to maintain internal stability, that that is an essential for the wellbeing of their people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had the same conversation as I have had.

—You have heard this argument before? In this instance, through the history of Burma, it has always been the army that has been called upon to save the people from internal trauma and suffering that would result from the instability of political uncertainty. It is very difficult to convince generals who have been brought up within an isolated world such as we find in Burma that there is no reason for them actually to be frightened of change, that it can actually bring them great credit if they are prepared to embrace it.

SPEECH.PARA: I only say that to try, in a simplistic way, to demonstrate that this is a difficult debate not only for us but internally within Burma. I have sat down in Burma and talked to dissidents who have just been released after months, in some instances years, in prison, and in appalling circumstances in prison. We have heard of the psychological pressure that is placed on them in isolation cells for months on end. Yet some of these dissidents say to me that the isolation of Burma, which is the trend of Senator Chamarette's motion, is the worst thing for Burma's future, that the best chance of change for Burma is if it is opened up to the world—opened up to pressure from the international community and also opened up in such a way that the Burmese people have an opportunity to appreciate the benefits that come from a different form of government, a democratic form of government, where political freedoms are treated as important.

Some, including Aung San Suu Kyi herself, argue to the contrary. They believe that by opening doors to the international community and the international community responding in terms of trade, aid and political contact, it actually takes pressure off the generals to reform. So the debate within Burma is a complex one. The debate for those of us in the international community who are trying to work out the best way to influence change in Burma is an equally complex one.

No‐one has found the right formula. The ASEAN countries believe that a constructive engagement is more likely to bring about political change.Australia has held the view that that is probably not so. With the exception of the United States, Australia has probably had the strongest anti‐trade and investment policies of any country in the world. But that has not achieved the objective that we are seeking, either. In fact, this motion is being debated in an environment in which the SLORC has just introduced new draconian laws to outlaw political meetings and political contact. So the correct set of policies for the international community is difficult to find.

What is clear is that the only chance of the international community influencing positive change is if the countries of the democratic world work together, work through the issues and try to find a common position. There is no chance that a country such as ours, operating in isolation, will have any effect whatsoever on the policies of the SLORC or make any advance in seeking to achieve the political advantage for the Burmese people that is our objective.

We think, by and large, that the policies that were put down by the previous Labor government in this country were right—the benchmark set of policies whereby if positive changes do occur, they are acknowledged and supported and if they do not, we continue to apply all the diplomatic pressure that is open to us. We do not encourage Australian trade or investment in the country until we see an improved political outlook. But we do, both with the carrot and the stick, try to encourage some positive change. We can see no better set of policies than that at the moment.

Our concern with the Greens' motion is that there is no evidence that it is actually more likely to achieve the outcome that we are all seeking. In fact, what concerns me is that it is so easy for us in addressing an issue as complex as Burma to pass resolutions that might make us feel good, to feel that we have done our bit by passing a resolution calling on the Australian government to actively discourage Australian companies from doing business in Burma, to use the words of the Greens (WA). But if that does not achieve any positive outcome for the Burmese people, then what is the real benefit of moving in that direction?

For those reasons I have put down in the form of an amendment an alternative set of words. I think it encompasses everything that the Senate would want to say. It congratulates Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on her courage and determination. It condemns the SLORC for refusing to accept the verdict of the Burmese people at their election. It particularly mentions and condemns the latest heavy handed attempts by the SLORC to curtail political opposition. It urges the Australian government to maintain the embargo on the export of defence and defence related goods, and the Australian government will do so. But that is an instance where the whole international community is in agreement on a sanction—breached in some instances, I regret to say. Nevertheless, it is mouthed by the whole international community.

My amendment also urges the Australian government to work with other governments internationally to explore ways in which we can press the SLORC to release currently held political prisoners, to desist from practices of forced labour, which is the only way in which you can characterise some of the labour practices that they pursue, and to press the SLORC to respect basic human rights and freedoms and democratic expression. I believe the amendment is a better set of words to reflect the views of senators in this place and to encourage the Australian government to continue down the policy path that they are presently maintaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition generally supports the remarks of both the previous speakers and the motion. We have no objection to the proposal moved by Senator Hill as an amendment to Senator Chamarette's motion. In a positive sense, all of the phrases in both motions could be supported by the opposition. On behalf of the opposition, I would like to move an amendment to paragraph (d) of Senator Chamarette's motion to replace paragraph (c), where it now reads `calls on the Government to actively discourage Australian companies from doing business in Burma', to now read `calls upon—
—Senator Schacht, at the moment you cannot move that amendment until we have disposed of Senator Hill's amendment.

—I foreshadow that I will move a new paragraph (d) to read `calls upon the Government to put SLORC on notice that potential trade sanctions must be on the agenda if civil and political rights are not restored'. We believe that is consistent with the opposition when we were in government on how we treated this—as I concede from Senator Hill—complex issue of the balance of trade sanctions and other sanctions on Burma and on the SLORC.

SPEECH.PARA: The real reason these motions have been moved—although it is taking up some time of the Senate this morning—is because there is no doubt that in the world at the moment Burma is probably almost at the top of the list of countries that democratic countries look at as a consistent abuser of human rights. Yesterday in another context Senator Hill mentioned that I had some interest in the issue of Burma in the past. I have always had an interest in Burma. I had a chance to visit in 1989 and 1992 on a private basis. I am now very proud of the fact that in 1989 I was able to meet Aung San Suu Kyi just before she was put away for six years under house arrest in Rangoon.

Today is Aung San Suu Kyi's birthday. For me it is very appropriate that I can associate myself personally with these remarks on her birthday. As former Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which looked into human rights, I have had an opportunity to meet many people around the world who have made major issues of human rights. Aung San Suu Kyi is without doubt one of the most outstanding figures on the world stage, promoting not just human rights in her own country but the general principles of human rights everywhere. The meeting I had with her was one of the most intellectually challenging I have ever had in relation to the issues she raised and the way she put them. There is no doubt, as is her right in my view, that if she were to be the democratically elected Prime Minister of Burma, she would be an outstanding leader in world terms. I hope some time in the not too distant future that we may be able to welcome her to this country as the democratically elected Prime Minister of a democratically run Burma.

PARA.BREAK: We should point out that in 1990 the party she leads—the National League for Democra cy—in an election that SLORC allowed, which just shows us how out of touch they were, won over 80 per cent of the seats in the parliament. From time to time Labor and Liberal members in this country have prided ourselves on having a landslide win here and there. None of us has ever been able to match the landslide victory that the NLD achieved in the only free election that has been allowed in Burma since the 1950s. Of course, the SLORC immediately ignored the result. They were so shocked by it. They could not understand why the Burmese people would so overwhelmingly vote for Aung San Suu Kyi. The reason they do is that they recognise that she is the one person in their country at the moment with the commitment to democracy to be able to run the country in a democratic way.

SPEECH.PARA: It should also be put on the record on her birthday that she is the daughter of the founder of modern Burma, General Aung San, who achieved independence for Burma in the late 1940s from the British. Although she is her father's daughter, everybody in Burma recognises that in her own right she has made her way and established her credentials as the major leader, not just because she is her father's daughter.

All of us have been inspired by the fact that through six years of house arrest, completely cut off from the rest of the world, even her own family for most of that time, she never caved in to the SLORC and she never accepted any financial assistance to provide food. She paid for provisions herself, even though that was very difficult at times. She never gave in when the rest of us in the world would have given up in the end because of that pressure that was being applied.

Now we see those remarkable scenes each week of up to 10,000 Burmese citizens gathering outside her residence to show their support for her. There is no doubt that if you had a general free assembly in Burma millions would turn up, as they did in August 1988 when she made her first address to the public of Burma on the steps of the Shwe Dagon Pagoda. It was estimated by our ambassador at the time, who attended and observed that rally, that as many as three million people may have attended a rally at which she spoke. Even if that figure was exaggerated by 100 per cent, it is still over one million people. That is a size that we in Australia have never contemplated, but again shows the support for her.

The other thing that should not be underestimated about Aung San Suu Kyi is her ability to unify the country through her policies. Senator Hill has quite rightly pointed out that when you have talks with the SLORC, as he and I have both had, they say the main justification for the military regime is that they are the only organisation capable of keeping the unity of Burma. That is utterly false. Through most of the last 35 years of Burmese history, there have been insurrections and insurgencies by various minority ethnic groups who have resented the heavy‐handed military regime first of Ne Win and now of SLORC—unfortunately, its natural successor.

Aung San Suu Kyi has proposed a democratic structure that would enable the minorities of Burma to have a fair say in the running of their own affairs, to preserve their own culture and to preserve their own language and education within a united Burma—something the SLORC is not capable of understanding. The only way they treat these issues is to send the army in on military campaigns against the minority groups within Burma. It is clear that the National League for Democracy is the one political party capable of bringing together, at a national level, the various views of the minority groups.

We have seen in recent days why this resolution is so important. The loosening up of the regime—and we all welcomed the fact that they released Aung San Suu Kyi from house arrest—was a step forward which we all welcomed. This was the point Senator Hill made. Unfortunately in Burma it is like one step forward and two steps back, and wherever you are in the steps you do not quite know what resolution you should carry. One moment you might be a bit more optimistic so you give the SLORC a little encouragement in a resolution or a public statement on behalf of the Australian government. The next week they snatch it back, so then you have to have a tougher position.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to try to interpret it in Burmese terms.

—Yes. The SLORC is really an enigma to itself, let alone to the rest of us. SLORC is an insular group of army officers. Most of them have never served overseas. Most of them have only ever had a career fighting the insurgents around the borders of Burma. When I was there and had a meeting with a group of its colonels in 1992—this was three years after the fall of the Berlin wall—they were still proudly pronouncing that Burma was neutral and non-aligned between the superpowers. So when I said, `Just a moment. Russia has had a free and democratic election; communism has been abandoned. The Berlin Wall has come down. Who are you neutral between?', the irony of my question went right over the top of their heads. They still argued that Burma's neutrality was of major importance.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the problem with the SLORC. I met a former leader of the SLORC, General Saw Maung, who rose from the rank of corporal to be the head of the army and then the head of the SLORC. That was an hour after I had met Aung San Suu Kyi in 1989. The abilities of each of them were like chalk and cheese. Aung San Suu Kyi was a leader of great vision, courage and intellectual standing and the other was an extraordinarily narrow-minded general who had only spent his time serving in the Burmese army fighting insurgence.

To my astonishment, one of the justifications the general made for the military coup in September 1988 that established the SLORC was that at that time the American 7th Fleet was sailing across the Bay of Bengal and if they did not take action to restore army control of Burma the Americans would have invaded Burma. I started to laugh at such an absurd notion when I realised that he was not just putting it to me as a propaganda point; he firmly believed that American intervention into Burmese affairs via the 7th Fleet was a real possibility. That gives you some idea of the mind-set of this military regime and why dealing with someone like Aung San Suu Kyi is such a threat to them.

In Rangoon there is a lake in the middle of the city. At one end of the lake is Aung San Suu Kyi's residence. For six years the army surrounded it to stop people getting in to say hello to her and offer their support. The army was there to keep the people from showing their support. At the other end of the lake is the residence which the former military dictator Ne Win lives in. It is also surrounded by the military, but, as local people will tell you, that is to keep the people from trying to get in and get rid of Ne Win. The army offers him protection from the people who resent his maladministration for nearly 30 years.

As some other people have commented, one way or the other these two figures have become the nub of the political outcome—that is, which one will, in the end, come to the fore and become leader. It is clear to me that, overwhelmingly, the Burmese people want Aung San Suu Kyi.

I believe that on the issue of trade sanctions, which Senator Chamarette mentioned in her motion, which we have mentioned in our amendment and which Senator Hill has mentioned in paragraph 4 of his, it is not unreasonable to give fair warning that, if the present repression and imprisonment of political prisoners continues in Burma, at an appropriate time, irrespective of what ASEAN countries or other countries may do, Australia reserves the right to take trade sanctions in a positive way against Burma.

I agree with Senator Hill. It is very hard to say exactly when you should apply sanctions, how much encouragement you should give the SLORC to change, how much of a carrot you would give and how much stick you would use along the way. How much carrot you give and how much stick you use is a balanced judgment. I have no doubt that you cannot get the SLORC to change by offering them pure carrot, because they will take that as a vindication that they do not have to change. That is the ASEAN position, by and large. I do not think that will be successful. I also believe that if you have an absolute reliance on the stick, without offering the SLORC a way out to save some face for the change, you will not get the change. So in the Australian parliament I think we always have to try to argue that we have the balance about right. There are shades of grey in it. I think from time to time we have to be ready to change our judgment according to circumstances as they evolve.

I would like to conclude on one very personal point about Burma. When I was chairman of the first human rights committee of this parliament, I dedicated the first report that we produced to a young man I met in Burma in 1989. He was Maung Maung Kywe, who, as a 16-year-old high school student at the local high school in Rangoon during the demonstrations of 1988, organised every day for the high school students to march in the streets to demonstrate for democracy. I have to say that that took a lot of courage, because a number of them were shot and killed, arrested and tortured, some of them were murdered in prison and some of them just disappeared. Despite those threats, those young high school students still marched in the streets every day knowing what the threats to them were.

I met him when he was on the run in Burma as a dissenter. Every day he would go down to the marketplace and surreptitiously hand out leaflets calling for democracy, knowing that if he was caught he would probably get, at the very least, very rough treatment. When I asked him why he was doing this, he said, `I want to have democracy for Burma.' When I asked him what that meant, he said, `It means I get the right to elect the government I want, and in three or four years time I get the right to unelect it if I disagree with it.' I thought, `I studied politics for three years at Adelaide University and that is a good enough description of democracy for me,' which I got from a 16-year-old kid.

I returned in 1992 and asked quietly the woman who at one stage gave him shelter if I could meet him. She informed me that he had been killed fighting for democracy in Burma. I must say that that was one of the most awful moments I had in my political life, because only a few minutes later I had to go and have dinner with the colonels of the SLORC, those responsible without doubt for his death. I thought it only reasonable that he get some memory somewhere else in the world, in an Australian parliamentary document, about his contribution to democracy.

For us this is a resolution of words. As Bill Hayden said, in diplomacy words are bullets. They are the ones that make the change. We should recognise that in Burma literally tens of thousands of people have quite courageously paid with their lives to try to get democracy for that country. No matter how little the time we take from time to time in this place to support those very brave people, including the memory of Maung Maung Kywe, I think we should do it.

I believe that the motions we have before us are very adequate for the occasion. This is an occasion for Aung San Suu Kyi personally in which we recognise that she is one of the great figures for human rights and democracy in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in with everyone who has spoken so far in this debate. The main theme of what has been said so far in this debate—I do not think it will go on for much longer—is that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is one of the world's great heroes. I think that everybody in this chamber would say the same; in fact, probably most people in Australia would say the same. We do wish her as happy a birthday as she can possibly have under the circumstances of her current habitation in Burma.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a member of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence, and Trade almost since it was started. I think that I missed the first meeting before I was actually put on to that committee. We have looked at Burma over the years, from 1990 until now. We handed down a quite short but fairly thorough report, a quite recent one, in the last parliament on the situation in Burma and human rights in Burma.

The report demonstrated that human rights in Burma is at an abysmally low level. It has to be one of the worst places, as Senator Schacht said, in the world today for human rights. Forced labour is everywhere. The army just picks civilians out from villages anywhere—anyone they feel like. It does not matter how old you are, how young you are, whether you are pregnant, or whether you have small children. Nothing matters. If you are an individual who can carry what the army needs to be carried, then you are picked up out of the village and you just go with the army.

You just drop everything—your children, your ageing grandfather; you may be the aging grandfather—and you go with the army until either they decide they do not need you, which does not happen all that often, or you drop dead, which does happen far too often. Forced labour is a real and very destructive problem.

Talking of destruction, there is also the destruction of entire villages, the burning of villages. If anybody is suspected of being against the SLORC, then the entire village might go. There is torture all the time, everywhere. There is repression and pervasive fear.

About four years ago I asked the then foreign minister Senator Gareth Evans where the heroin on Australian streets came from. I think that the answer was that about 80 per cent of it comes from Burma. There are plenty of heroin poppy‐growing areas in South-East Asia, outside Burma. If 80 per cent of it comes from within Burma then there is a reason for that. The reason is not just that that is the best area to grow the heroin poppy. The reason must be that it is easier to get the heroin out of Burma, and there must be a reason for that too. Burma is an absolute disaster area. But it well and truly should not be. The reason that it is is obviously the SLORC.

I remember the first time that I heard the term `SLORC'. I think it was in 1990. To Senator Schacht, who at the time was the chair of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, I said: `What a dreadful acronym. Fancy calling something the SLORC. It sounds like a horrible, enormous squishy monster that comes and gets you.' Senator Schacht said, `Yes, it is an enormous, squishy monster that comes and gets you. It is a very accurate acronym for this body.' And it is.

BREAK.PARA: It is one of the most dreadful regimes in the world today. If we cannot agree in this parliament that we should take extremely strong action against such a repressive regime, then we have a problem. If there is any regime in our region that we should be taking incredibly strong action against, this is it. It is very obvious.

I have two motions and an amendment in front of me at the moment, and I would say that I agree with everything in all of them. I think that we do have to take action with countries around the world. That is essential. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) is absolutely right when he says that. I also agree with Senator Schacht when he says that we have to tell the SLORC that we are now considering whether trade sanctions ought to be on the agenda.

They have to know that we are not going to just sit here forever and put up with what they are doing. What they are doing is wrong. It is not right. They have to have very, very strong signals from this parliament that what they are doing is wrong. We have to be able to tell them that.

One of the things Senator Hill said at the end of his remarks was that we will feel good if we pass some of the things in this motion but they will not achieve anything. That is an interesting comment coming from somebody who is a minister and who has been in opposition. I do not actually expect to be a minister in the near future. I expect to be in opposition for a fair while.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would all be in shock if you were.

—Senator Schacht would be shocked if I were a minister. If I were the foreign minister, things would change. However, speaking as somebody who is in opposition and probably expects to be there for quite a while, words are all we have in opposition to try to change things. We will take whatever actions we can to try to change things but these are the actions that we have available to us. Therefore, this is what we will do to try to change things.

BREAK.PARA: Yes, it does make a difference. If enough people say they think this is the wrong thing to do, if enough people put pressure on those who do have the power to change things, it will change. That is how all change happens in this world. I hope that is what I am contributing to every day, and I hope every member of this chamber is also contributing to that every day. We say enough about the things that are wrong in this world and, my goodness me, if anything is wrong in this world, the situation in Burma has to be very high on that list. If we say as loudly and as long as we can enough things about what is wrong in this world, eventually those things will change and the world will become a better place.

You have to believe that. You have to take every action that you can personally take to achieve that end. That is what I am doing, and what I firmly believe this chamber is doing. I would vote for Senator Hill's motion. I would vote for Senator Chamarette's motion. I will also be voting for Senator Schacht's foreshadowed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should put on the record, as Senator Chamarette foreshadowed, that the government is opposed to that motion. There is much within it that we would support but I am concerned about a number of aspects of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I do not know as a matter of fact whether these villages in Kayah State are being torched as alleged. TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 19th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Reserve Bank officers' superannuation fund , together with the submissions and the Hansard transcript of evidence.

BREAK.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The object of this report was to examine the allegations of improper bond trading by the investment committee of the Reserve Bank of Australia Officers' Superannuation Fund, referred to as OSF. The committee recognised the important position of the Reserve Bank of Australia in the economic life of Australia. Accordingly, it regards as crucial the upholding of the Reserve Bank's integrity in all its aspects. On the evidence before it, the committee is satisfied that the integrity has been both upheld and been seen to be upheld.

In the committee's view, perceptions are integral to public confidence, and public confidence in our financial institutions is fundamental to our financial system as a whole. Thus, the committee felt that it was imperative to deal with the concerns that were raised. The committee believes that this inquiry has done that comprehensively, and those concerns have been demonstrated to be without merit.

In a very thorough coverage, the committee heard evidence from Mr Bernie Fraser, the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Alan Cameron, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, and Mr Pat Barrett, the Commonwealth Auditor‐General. We found that the original allegations could not be sustained.

Given the seriousness of the allegations of insider trading, the committee felt it was imperative to deal with the concerns that had been raised. The committee has demonstrated that the allegations have been completely without merit, and they have been now laid to rest. I thank the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 June, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in mid‐sentence when my speech was interrupted last night. The remaining part of the sentence refers to the AIIA, the Australian Information Industries Association, which, in surveys of its membership, found that the multiplier for this scheme was a multiplication of one to 30. The best example of the multiplier that the EMDG scheme provides is set out in evidence to the Senate committee by Mr Oliver of Austrade, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The multiplier found by Professor Bewley, who headed that evaluation, showed that across the scheme, if you considered all claimants, it is 10 to one additional exports. So last year just a touch under $200 million was paid out under the scheme. That in turn generated $2 billion worth of incremental exports. That is the assumption. If you look at claimants that are what we call `experienced' in the scheme—and they would be claimants from year three onwards and have some export experience—the multiplier is up to 25 to one, depending upon the industry and the number of years that the company has been in the scheme.
The multiplier is an effective one. This scheme makes money for Australia. That is the first of my two points that I want to make at this stage.

The second point is that the EMDG scheme is taxed. The government gets back—according to the findings of the report calculated by Professor Bewley—42 per cent of all its outlays. Therefore, in the year 1994-95, where the outlay was $211 million, the Australian government only outlaid $122.38 million. Given the projection that the outlay in the year 1998-99 will be $292 million, it will really be $169.36 million—$88.62 million and $122.64 million on those two figures respectively will be returned to general revenue for other uses by the government.

I just want to emphasis those two points. The multiplier shows that this is an effective scheme. Forty‐two per cent of the outlays, according to the most recent calculation, are returned to the government in revenue. So when we focus on the total cost of the scheme, reduce that by 42 per cent because that is the real cost to the government of the scheme.

More importantly, though, the export market development scheme has to be compared not to its performance domestically in the Australian economy or costs to the government for running the scheme, or indeed even the multiplier, but rather to what other countries in the world provide to their companies, because we are now in the globalised economy. Australian industry competes on the world market. If Australians are not supported by their government and companies from other countries are, we are therefore at a commercial disadvantage in foreign markets.

No evidence has been provided to us as to what the other schemes in nations competing with Australia are, but what is known anecdotally by me is that there are a number of huge industry supports to companies in Japan, Italy, France, Germany, the USA and Britain—schemes that actually help those exporters win markets. If you were to diminish this scheme or remove it, it would be like asking Australians to compete in the Olympic Games over the 100 metres event in Blundstone boots saying to them that the extra handicap that they carry is an incentive to do better. It is a mockery; it is a joke, and the government is aware of that.

I think those facts speak for themselves. This scheme is vital for the health of the export sector. Why industry is concerned—concerned in some detail about this bill but concerned, more importantly, about the intentions of the government—is that the rumours everywhere are that the scheme will be abolished. The government cannot sit back and say, `You can't assume that it will be,' because these are inspired rumours; they are leaks from within the bureaucracy; they are leaks from within government meetings. What has been transmitted to corporate Australia is a view that the future of this scheme is uncertain. Therefore, can you expect Australian companies to invest money in the exercise where this scheme actually repays them on their efforts while there is uncertainty hanging over it and they may not get their money back?

The very existence of the rumours about the future of this scheme is denying the impact the scheme provides for Australia in foreign trade. Indeed, given the level of the current account deficit, you would wonder why anyone with a smart brain or even half a smart brain would give source to those rumours.

But there are sustained leaks, and it is not just about the EMDG scheme. It is about the DIFF scheme; it is about the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development; it is about NIES; and it is about a whole range of industry support schemes—all of which undercut the confidence of industry about the security of those schemes in the future and lead to a more conservative approach by it. Of course, I will not go now into the mythical black hole that these cuts are supposed to feed, but it is passing strange and odd in the extreme that a government would stunt growth in order to balance its budget when it can balance its budget by accelerating growth and getting higher returns from its tax base as a consequence.

I think it is important that every company in Australia realises that the Commonwealth government, the coalition, backed down in the face of state pressure on sales tax on motor vehicles. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) backed down at an NFF meeting on diesel fuel rebate and rural research and development by giving them a wink and a nod that those two schemes for that sector will remain. It does show that there is some give by the government if significant pressure is applied. I simply encourage Australian companies and their industry associations to apply that pressure to protect this scheme. The letters of protest have been many, but I think the efforts can be redoubled and made sure.

When I say that if the scheme is diminished or abolished we will oppose it, I say that with a considerable degree of weight. One of the leaks that came to me was that on 4 June the ERC met and decided that they would impose a 24.3 per cent cut in running costs for Austrade. Austrade administer this scheme. If their running costs were cut by a quarter, the ability to administer this scheme at maximum efficiency, despite the redoubtable skills of the administration capability of Austrade, would be called into question. Companies would be waiting a lot longer for payment and that, of course, exposes them to high interest on the borrowings that they may have undertaken to finance their activities in the first place.

Even if the scheme is kept intact but Austrade is savaged, we will oppose all of that. We will oppose it because of itself it ought to be opposed. Importantly as well, the government in its election promises—and I want to make this point with as maximum emphasis as I can—said that it would enhance this scheme. It did so by the Hon. Tim Fischer MP, the then shadow minister for trade, who spoke at the National Press Club on 15 February 1996. It was repeated on pages 1 and 8 of the coalition's industry and commerce policy document, released by the Hon. John Moore MP. Of course, some industry associations, in evidence to the inquiry, said that they had spoken to Mr Fischer about that, and he gave them assurances that the scheme would not be tampered with. If it is, the government is repudiating its election promise. That will give us perfect right to defend the scheme and hold the government to what it told the electorate at election time.

I make this comment to the government: the government should not assume that, because this is a bill we introduced when we were in office, we will support it now. It should never assume that, because we did not make the election undertakings that you made. Many of the industry associations before the inquiry said that when they heard those election undertakings they did not assume that this government, the current government, would pursue these changes. What was told to those industry associations, if you go back to the Hansard of the hearing, suggests that they have perfect grounds for saying that. I make the point that not all said it, but some said it. There is a degree of ambiguity about it, so the government should stand by its industry undertakings.

The other thing that is clear from the hearing is that this government had not consulted any of the industry. The evidence is that when we were in government we did consult about this proposal, but this government did not. Therefore, there is that reasonable question of whether they ever intended to proceed with the scheme.

There are a number of matters which I am going to have to pursue in the committee stage of this bill concerning the actual detail of the proposals put before the chamber. I just quickly say, in the few minutes available to me now, that what is clear in reducing the maximum per annum grant from $250,000 to $200,000 is that the government has not consulted industry on that. There is some information known about the number of companies affected in the band $200,000 to $250,000.

When you look at the industry break‐up of the evidence given to the inquiry by Austrade, the industry sector most seriously affected is the manufacturing sector. That is the one in which we have had the maximum growth in exports over the last several years under the previous Labor government, and it would appear that this would be the group that would be most severely affected by reducing the ceiling. However, I make the point that that has not been looked at by this government, nor has the impact been looked at on the small business area, where they can conglomerate together such as they do in the furniture industry and present themselves as an association and get that ceiling.

The other area of importance is administrative complexity. This government promised the electorate in stentorian terms that it would reduce red tape on business by 50 per cent. This bill actually increases it. The evidence from everyone is unanimous on that point. This is the voice of business saying, `You are now increasing red tape on us,' and this government is proceeding to do that. While I understand that Austrade is having consultations to try to make that easier, it is still a load that business will bear and is in itself a deterrent to business in actually applying for the scheme.

My time is up. There are a lot of other things I would like to say, but I conclude on this point: we will give passage to this bill, but it will be with the major reservations I have referred to. If the scheme is abolished, we will oppose it tooth and nail all the way down the line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler, Sen Sid

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. The purpose of the bill is to reduce from $250,000 to $200,000 the maximum grant payable to applicants other than an approved trading house, to introduce a series of measures to improve accountability and risk measurement and to introduce registration and grants entry testing of first time claimants. In fact, that testing—the so‐called market readiness test—tries to establish whether or not a particular business is strong enough to maintain its export push. Savings are estimated to be in the order of $32 million between 1996 and 1999 and have already been incorporated in the forward estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill must be seen in the context of this government's overall trade and industry policy, which even its own minister has described as `dreadful' in certain aspects that have been put forward since this government took office. During the campaign the Liberal and National parties assured voters that they attached `a high priority to the effective allocation of funding that assists the growth of Australian exports through providing support to businesses' and they vowed to introduce changes which would introduce a greater level of coherence and accountability into these programs. This bill introduces greater complexity but it is very doubtful whether it introduces a greater level of coherence.

The coalition has said that the role of Austrade and the range of export assistance packages offered to businesses is a cornerstone in the processes of developing an export culture. Yet since then we have seen or heard little but repeated threats and speculation about the axing or severe curtailing of trade and industry assistance programs now lambasted as business welfare, irrespective of the national benefit these schemes have rendered.

The government has seemingly turned its back on its pre‐election commitment to develop a strong proactive and interventionist industry and trade policy. No longer does the government appear intent on building upon and enhancing existing support programs which clearly underpin economic growth, encourage exports, reduce the current account deficit, create jobs and contribute to greater public savings by increasing the tax revenue. Instead, we hear of cuts to the export market development grants scheme, the development import finance facility scheme, the research and development tax concession and the tariff concession scheme. It is unfortunate that the government is trying to please financial markets by cutting $8 billion from the deficit but is doing so without any discernible rational policy framework.
Bert Evans, Chief Executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association, has said that addressing Australia's national saving problem:

. . . by way of cutting our nation's productive and export capacity will render only a short term book‐keeper's benefit . . . Cutting these schemes is not saving. On the contrary, we are contemplating cutting public investment in programs which currently make important contributions to national saving through their positive impact on exports, and ultimately, on the current account deficit.

One can only say, `Hear, hear!' Such concerns have been echoed by the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, who attacked the Commonwealth government over these projected cuts, claiming they would discourage business investment and possibly stall national economic growth. I am delighted to be able to put on record that I wholeheartedly agree with Premier Jeff Kennett.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion.
—And in a very limited ambit of the statements that he is making, Senator Cooney. Mr Kennett said:

SPEECH.PARA: You only have to talk to the federal ministers up there to know that they're going to these expenditure revenue meetings and they're being told what to do. Treasury mandarins are now back in control and must be laughing themselves stupid.

As I said, for once I am able to wholeheartedly agree with Mr Jeff Kennett. The ACTU and the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union have joined industry critics and have warned that Australia risks losing $4.5 billion a year of net exports by the year 2000 and up to 80,000 jobs if the government proceeds with plans to scrap trade and industry programs. The fact is that governments have an important role to play in the economy and in support of small business—a role the present government is doing its utmost to shirk. It is not surprising therefore that the government's policy inconsistencies are reflected in its approach to the export market development scheme. Even as it is threatening to cut the scheme out, the government is seeking amendments to improve it and to make it more cost‐effective.

BREAK.PARA: One is, indeed, tempted to vote against the whole bill, to say, `What's the use,' and, in effect, to challenge the government to come back when it has irrevocably decided to continue it, as it certainly should. However, it is hard to imagine that even this government would wish to damage Australia's efforts to reduce our current account deficit. The Democrats will, therefore, address the substance of the government's bill and the measures it is proposing.

Before I do that, let me put one more suggestion to the government which it may wish to incorporate in its further considerations of this scheme. It is one that the Australian Democrats have often raised, that is the threshold entry figure, which is currently at $30,000. Very clearly, when that was introduced it cut out a lot of people in small business, including those who are not able to get together into consortia to benefit from the scheme.

There are some areas in industry which continue to be in that position. We have had representations from recording artists in the industry producing CDs who are struggling to hold their own against Sony and other major competitors with ample capital to support their efforts. Recording artists, however, are usually individuals with very little capital strength and substance who are facing costs in producing their recordings which further sap their capacity. I believe the government should give consideration in its further examination of the scheme to allowing a lower threshold in particular circumstances such as the one I have described.

The EMDG scheme was established in 1974 and is the government's major export incentive program designed to encourage small and medium business enterprises to seek out and develop export markets and to promote an export culture in the business community. Administered by Austrade, the scheme currently provides cash grants of up to $250,000 per annum for approved enterprises and is based primarily on expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets.

Apart from two insignificant changes, the bill is the same as the one introduced by the former government in November last year but which lapsed with the dissolution of parliament. The present parliament has signalled that it may further amend or, as I have said before, even abolish the scheme in the context of the forthcoming budget deliberations and that any such decision will not be influenced at all by the introduction of this bill.

The Democrats hope that it will be influenced by the passage of this bill because, like the opposition, the Democrats are saying we will grant this bill passage with some reservations and some concerns which we will ask the minister to address. But we are doing so with the expectation that the government will come to its senses and continue this scheme after it has been adjusted to make it yet more cost-effective.

The bill was sent to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. A common concern among witnesses concerned the grants entry test or market readiness, which it was felt would introduce an additional level of administrative delays and costs and undermine the non‐discretionary nature of the scheme by allowing Austrade officials to determine whether an exporter is ready to export.

The market readiness test is introduced by schedule 9 of the bill, administered and formulated by Austrade and which first time applicants will be required to pass. For claimants who fail, the test is to serve as a diagnostic instrument to facilitate counselling and referral to appropriate services. It is the view of the Democrats that this counselling, referral, support, advice and so on should be available at all times, not just when a company is diagnosed as being likely to fail. We should not let companies get to that point and through Austrade we should provide the means of support for our export industries to continue that push overseas.

The screening mechanism is designed to filter out those with little chance of success thereby reducing the number of firms dropping out of the scheme at a later stage before they progress to graduation after eight years. The drop‐out rate is of concern because it indicates a failure to develop export markets and possibly an ineffective use of public funds. To that extent, we certainly share the government's concerns in this area.

However, we are being asked to approve a test which will be administered by public servants who are not necessarily experienced in business. It is a fairly subjective test at the moment on the basis of the information that we have before us. We were very tempted to delete the market readiness provisions by an amendment. However, we have been provided with a list of the criteria that the government intends to develop in consultation with industry. While at the moment the list is little more than that, it simply enumerates the various factors that will be looked at.

We have already suggested to the minister—and I repeat the statement here in the chamber—that we would expect the government to produce a list of criteria which is clear, detailed and appealable so that a business which is rejected on the basis of that test can appeal to the AAT if the judgment that is made by the person concerned in the department is found to be wanting. We have been assured that these criteria will be provided to the Senate as a disallowable instrument. I certainly suggest to the minister that the Democrats will reject that instrument if it does not measure up to the test we are suggesting; namely, that it is objective and detailed.

We believe that once again the applicants, particularly those in the category which is considered to be doubtful, should be supported by advice and training on information rather than be closed out of the scheme. I would like to receive some more information and assurances from the minister on that point when he responds later in this debate.

There is one other provision that has caused us some concern; that is, a reduction in the grant level from $250,000 to $200,000, which was stated by many to be retrospective in its application to people who are already in the system. However, this measure was announced by the previous government in the May 1995 budget. Therefore, we feel that it can hardly be called retrospective in that the applicants concerned had ample notice of it. We will therefore reluctantly pass this bill but look forward to a lower threshold in specific cases, particularly recording artists which I mentioned before.
More importantly, we believe that the government should take notice of the research that has been done on the cost effectiveness of this scheme. A report by Price Waterhouse states:
Typically, mature exporter firms in most industries will generate 15‐25 times the grants paid to them in additional exports.

That, in any terms, surely is an adequate and indeed an excellent return for the investment of public funds. Since our whole efforts in our industries should be directed towards improving our balance of payments and to becoming competitive in international markets, it would be suicidal indeed for the government to remove that particular scheme. I flag the Democrats' opposition to such a move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. Prior to making those remarks, I would like, on behalf of Senator Cook, to formally move the amendment that he flagged on behalf of the opposition. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add ", but the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that the EMDG scheme is:

PARA.TAB: (i) a successful scheme which enhances Australia's export performance,
(ii) a source of job creation and benefits Australia's balance of payments, and
(iii) a successful export incentive for small and medium sized enterprises;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) expresses grave concern at the Government's mooted abolition of the scheme which would be:

PARA.TAB: (i) a cynical and blatant breach of an express election commitment to retain and expand the scheme, and
(ii) counter to any reasonable assessment of the evidence given to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee in the course of the committee's consideration of the bill; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) condemns the Government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the EMDG scheme by making full Export Mar ket Development Grants of 50% available to the tourism industry".

This bill before the Senate today is a very important one—not so much because of the terms of the bill but because of the debate that surrounds the future of the export market development grants scheme in this country. The scheme provides cash grants to assist Australian exporters in seeking out and developing export markets. Exporters are reimbursed 50 per cent of overseas marketing expenses above $30,000. The scheme's primary purpose is to support small to medium sized companies in their export endeavours.

The bill we are considering today is identical to one introduced by the previous Labor government and the amendments contained therein seek to limit grants payable from $250,000 to $100,000 maximum, to introduce a grants entry test to limit grants to higher risk applicants and to provide greater guidance to small exporters, and to introduce accountability and legal measures.

This bill has been considered by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. The inquiry conducted by that committee was very useful in allowing industry to voice its concerns, not only about the bill we are considering today but also about the future of the scheme and the government's reluctance to endorse the future of the scheme.

The particular concerns with the bill have been well covered by Senator Spindler from Victoria in his speech, particularly the concern about the new grants entry tests. Senator Spindler indicated that some assurances have been given regarding the use of regulations in this regard. I am sure the Senate will closely monitor those to ensure that the scheme continues to operate successfully and fairly. Despite the loss of Senator Spindler from the Senate after 1 July, I can assure him that we will be keeping a very close eye on the matter.

The reason I decided to participate in this debate today was the concern of industry groups in my own state of Western Australia and elsewhere about the future of the scheme. They are concerned that the government is intending in the budget to either abolish the EMDG scheme or severely reduce its application. This concern is very real and has been heightened by the failure of various ministers to give any assurances to industry about the future of the scheme.
