I understand that there is always a bit of pre-budget argy-bargy and a normal policy of ministers to `neither confirm nor deny', but this scheme is very important to the future of high-tech and manufacturing industries in Australia. It is vital to the development of our export culture. I really do think that on this occasion the government ought to give an unequivocal commitment to the future of the scheme.

This scheme has been a success. There are various industry assistance programs where people can have a legitimate argument about their efficacy and success. This particular scheme is not one of these. Introduced by the Whitlam government in 1974, it has been almost an unqualified success. In the last financial year, 3,500 companies utilised the EMDG scheme. Ninety per cent were small businesses with turnovers of less than $5 million. Twenty per cent had turnovers of less than $1 million. They were predominantly high technology and information technology companies—the smart companies that are needed to take Australia's economy forward. We heard at the Senate committee inquiry of the many success stories, where the assistance provided by this scheme had allowed companies to expand into markets that they would not otherwise have been able to access.

The EMDG scheme has been reviewed on a number of occasions. On each occasion the reviews have found that the scheme has been working well. Despite some modifications, it has continued to provide very beneficial assistance to industries in broadening their export markets. The last review in 1994 again showed that the scheme was meeting its objectives.

PARA.BREAK: I wish to stress quite clearly that the EMDG is not a handout to companies. Firms must spend at least $30,000 before becoming eligible for the scheme and often do not receive any moneys for two years. High levels of commitment from the company are re quired. It is a partnership rather than a handout.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been found that the scheme is very cost effective. Austrade estimates that for every $1 spent on EMDG $25 is generated in exports. The 1994 Price Waterhouse review for Austrade that Senator Spindler referred to found that the net cost of the scheme was only 58 per cent of the amount spent on grants. That is around $115 million.

The study found that 42 per cent of the cost of the scheme was recouped by the government because of the tax payable on the grants themselves and the additional exports generated. With the EMDG, Austrade estimates that the annual IT&T and multimedia sector exports to North America will rise from $60 million in 1996 to $140 million in the year 2000. Without it, the exciting proposition of breaking into the lucrative North American market will be stifled. So the scheme is providing real success and very tangible benefits for the Australian economy and for our trade performance. The coalition, prior to the election, seemed to recognise this. The coalition trade policy, `Meeting the Challenges', at page 30 stated:
We will maintain the export market development grants scheme.

That view was confirmed by Tim Fischer at the National Press Club on 15 February 1996 when he said: `EMDG stays,' in a style that only Tim Fischer can bring to such things. The reasons why there is concern about the future of the scheme are numerous. I suppose at the back of people's minds is the fact that the Liberal Party went to the 1987 federal election with a policy of seeking to abolish the scheme. There is a widely held view that Treasury has some concerns with the scheme and would rather see it largely amended or scrapped. I think the recent abolition of the DIFF scheme has heightened industry concerns about the whole future of industry assistance measures. The government's constant mantra about the $8 billion black hole and the search for easy targets for cuts means that generally people are concerned about a range of government assistance schemes.

PARA.BREAK: There is enormous industry concern that the scheme may be abolished. This was highlight ed in the evidence given to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee when we inquired into this bill. I quote Mr Peter Campbell of the Australian Publishers Association, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Last year we studied with great interest the policy statements of both parties and took great comfort from the fact that both the coalition and the Labor government promised to continue the scheme into the year 1999. As well as that, our industry group had a meeting with the then shadow minister Mr Fischer, who gave us his personal insurance that the scheme would continue to that date. We received a letter from him last week which concluded by saying `The process, as you say, has still not been resolved and will be an ongoing process. Consequently, I am not able to comment on the future of the scheme.'
Mr Russell Chandler, from the Australian Institute of Export, expressed concern also. He said:

We can only assume that this extreme action is being contemplated by the Expenditure Review Committee on the basis of ignorance of the scheme, its needs, benefits and history, poor departmental advice, a perceived lack of support in relation to the other areas of potential cost cutting, or on the basis of pre-existing attitudes to government supported schemes in general.

These are just indications of the widespread industry concern at the implications of the elimination of the EMDG scheme. There were a number of submissions to the committee which gave very telling evidence as to the success of the scheme. I was particularly struck by the submission from the Lonely Planet book publishing company that talked about their particular history of involvement with the scheme and their experience of taking Australian publishing and Australian ingenuity to new markets. A range of companies like that gave very real, very concrete examples of how the scheme had assisted their firms.

People need to be aware of the implications of the elimination of this scheme. In the last 10 years Australia's trade and export performance has been significant in the development of the economy of this country. Exports have more than doubled: $39 million to $92 billion. Most of that growth has been in non-traditional areas. Services exports trebled to $21 billion and manufactured exports grew fivefold to $17.5 billion. The export boom in manufactures and services has added almost $30 billion a year to Australia's output and perhaps created as many as 500,000 jobs. If it continues to grow at anything like the rates of the past 10 years, the next tranche of benefits will be two to three times that size.

If the scheme is eliminated, either companies will move offshore to take advantage of the concessional tax arrangements for high-tech firms in other countries, which will result in jobs being lost as companies relocate offshore, or companies will simply exploit local markets and ignore the opportunities presented by overseas markets. Companies do need assistance to take that step to develop those export markets. The scheme is not a handout; there is an important role and a justifiable role for governments to play in assisting those companies to build their markets and, therefore, to build jobs and income for Australia.

Government policy of the past decade has placed a priority on encouraging companies to look at export opportunities. At a time when this culture is starting to impact on Australian business, the prospects of this government turning its back on industry are very alarming indeed. Mr Trevor Tappendan, of Ernst & Young, National Entrepreneurial Services Division, has said recently:
The EMDG has been a saviour to Australian small businesses getting into new export markets. It has created an environment for them to increase our exports.

I cannot believe the government would be so stupid as to damage something that has brought such good results. Senator Spindler also referred to the recent report put out by the ACTU and the AMWU entitled `A Preliminary Assessment of the Coalition's Proposed Cuts to Trade and Industry Development Assistance', which looked at the impact of abolishing industry development programs. It highlighted the potential loss of jobs, loss of growth of new exports and the range of flow-on effects that come from that. In summary that report estimated that, if all the mooted cuts were implemented, there would be a potential loss of $4,500 million to the GDP in lost import replacement and export expansion and a potential loss of up to 80,000 jobs from Australian industry.

These are very important considerations in relation to the scheme and in relation to government policy generally. They are about supporting industry and export market development. From a WA perspective, I know there is a large range of Western Australian companies that have benefited from the scheme as they have sought to expand into markets, particularly in South-East Asia.

A large number of high technology companies have been involved. It is interesting also that a large number of companies and activities associated with the WA universities have been beneficiaries of the scheme as we try to move into smart industries and develop Australian industry in new directions. EMDG has been a very important scheme for a range of companies in Western Australia. I have been impressed by the submissions I have received from those companies and from others who see the scheme as being highly desirable and effective in allowing them to grow and develop exports for Australia.

There is real concern on this side of the chamber regarding the axing of the EMDG, especially following the government's announced plans to abolish other industry development programs such as the development import finance facility. We have used this debate today to express those concerns. The amendment I have moved on behalf of Senator Cook goes to the heart of those concerns. It reiterates the success of the scheme in enhancing our export performance, in creating jobs and providing a successful export incentive for small and medium‐sized businesses. The amendment also expresses its concern at the mooted abolition of the scheme. Finally, the amendment seeks to condemn the government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the EMDG scheme by making full export market development grants of 50 per cent available to the tourism industry.

PARA.BREAK: The amendment moved by the opposition today is not addressing strictly the clauses of the bill, but is designed to give voice to the industry concerns and our very real concerns about the future of the scheme and the poten tial for the government in the budget process to do real damage to Australian export markets. I think it will be useful if I refer briefly to a quote by one of the economic writers, Tim Colebatch, in the Age. Talking about these sorts of schemes and the government's attitude, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What is alarming in the coalition's policies and Budget agenda is the evident lack of any strategy for ensuring they will continue—
`they', of course, being the trade and industry programs we have been referring to. He went on:
Trade and industry programs are being tossed up as targets for the axe with no sign that ministers . . . are weighing their importance to achieving the growth the Coalition and Australia need.

It is for this reason that we have taken the opportunity, in debating this bill today, to make the very strong point that the export market development grants scheme is fundamental to expanding our export markets, particularly in high technology areas, and assisting a range of industries in Australia.

We are very strongly supportive of the scheme and we urge the government to continue and expand the scheme following its budget deliberations. If there is any attempt to downgrade or abolish the scheme, the opposition will be taking a very serious view of that and doing all in its powers to assist industry in maintaining the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —An essential dimension of this debate, as appears from what has been said by the speakers before me, concerns an apprehension, an anxiety or fear, about the future of this scheme. This is not a good thing. Australian industry and commerce, some of which have been referred to in the previous speech by Senator Evans, are entitled to be reassured about the future of the scheme. It seems to me that that has been the matter that has concerned everybody who has turned their mind to this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the best way of going about the debate is to refer to the report from the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee. That is a committee of this chamber, and it is another indication of just how successful the committee system is for the proper processing of legislation.

The chair of that committee is Senator Judith Troeth, who, I think you would agree, is a most competent and experienced chair. She was previously chair of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which I now have the honour of heading. I know how good she is from the work that she has done there. The other members of the government party who are on that committee are Senator David MacGibbon and Senator Baden Teague, people with vast experience. They came into this chamber even before you and I came into it, you with considerable grace, Madam Acting President Knowles. The two people from the opposition party who are on that committee are Senator Cook and Senator Evans, from both of whom we have heard.

The point I want to make is that that was an all-party committee with the coalition parties being in the majority. It is interesting to see what they have to say. They turn to the question of the background to this scheme and that has already been described. It would be worthwhile, I think, for the purposes of those listening, to hear what the committee had to say about it. It said:

The Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme is established by the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and is managed by Austrade. It provides taxable cash grants to assist Australian exporters in seeking out and developing export markets. Exporters are reimbursed 50 per cent of overseas marketing expenses in excess of $15 000 having attained a minimum expenditure threshold of $30 000 for that year. The Scheme's primary purpose is to support small to medium sized companies in their export endeavours. Companies who record export sales above $25 million a year are ineligible to apply for a grant.

That theme has been developed by previous speakers. The general thrust of it is that this is a scheme to help small to medium‐sized Australian companies enter overseas markets. On the face of it, it is quite an outstanding scheme. It is a scheme which has been operating since the 1970s.

The fact that this bill has been introduced and contemplates the continuation of the scheme—though a continuation in a different way in the sense that there is less money available than there was before—would indicate that the scheme is to continue. You would have thought that people would have had faith in the government continuing the scheme on the basis that the government has introduced legislation very similar to what was introduced by the previous government.

When the report that I have referred to from the committee that was chaired by Senator Troeth is read it becomes quite clear that the people who gave evidence to the committee are quite fearful of the future of the scheme. It is proper that I read paragraph 12 of the report, which states:

In evidence to the Committee two areas of concern were raised: first, matters relating to aspects of the Bill including the impact of the reduction of the grant, the grants entry test, a possible increase in the complexity of the administration of the Scheme and the possible retrospective application of the amendments; and secondly, the question of the continuity of the Scheme.

Later in the report—at paragraphs 42, 43, 44, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49 and 50—the issue of the continuity of the scheme is developed. It is too long for me to read it during this speech, but the whole thrust of it is that industry is clearly concerned about the future of the scheme. As we heard from the people who have debated this issue today, and Senator Cook who debated it last night, this is causing great uncertainty in commerce and industry. It is not right that commerce and industry should be kept in that state of apprehension.

In the give and take across this chamber when the opposition seeks to find out what is going to happen in terms of expenditure for the purpose of gaining a political point, it is reasonable for the government to fence that approach and say, `Well, wait and see.' But that proposition, which may be correct in terms of the political exchange across the chamber, is not a proposition that has any validity where commerce and industry are concerned. The people who provide the lifeblood of this country, the people who manufacture, the people who produce services, the people who sell those services and the people who provide the wealth of this country are entitled to get a clear message from government. That clear message should come at the earliest opportunity. It should not be held up simply to gain a political advantage.

There may be some other reason why the government refuses to give assurances to the people who produce the wealth of this country. I see Senator Herron across the chamber, a person to whom we must give great respect. If he is responding to this issue, he might tell those people in Australia who want to know about the future of their business exactly why no clear message can be given now.

Perhaps I should indicate to Senator Herron, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, the people who did give evidence at this hearing. They include the Australian Business Chamber, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association Ltd, the Australian Publishers Association, the Australian Institute of Export (NSW) Ltd, the Australian Information Industries Association, Blades Mi‐Sporting Products Pty Ltd, Export and Commercial Research Services Pty Ltd, the Furnishing Association of Australia Ltd, Lonely Planet Publications Pty Ltd, the MTIA, Sunlovers Cruises, the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Growers Association and the Tourism Council Australia.

That list covers a very broad range of industry and commerce in this country, including information industries, sporting products, Lonely Planet Publications, tourism, the metal industries, the business chamber and so on. All these people and all these groups have expressed, as I understand this report, an apprehension about the future. That apprehension is apparently not to be taken from them until, at the very earliest, 20 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is Lonely Planet Publications about?
—Lonely Planet Publications was mentioned by Senator Evans and Senator Cook, who attended this hearing.
—It is a world ranking guide to travellers. It sells everywhere in the world.
—I don't do as much travel as you, Peter.

—I think why we do not use it, Senator O'Chee, and probably why Senator Cook might not either, is that we have our travel arrangements made for us. We have a very easy way around the world. Whether we are going to go down the ski slopes of the mountains of the world or whether we are going overseas to educate ourselves, we have a very easy passage. But my children, when they go travelling with backpacks on their backs, use this book. It is an Australian publication—and Senator Cook would agree with this—which has been acclaimed around the world. It is a very famous book.

SPEECH.PARA: It is published out of Melbourne, if I remember correctly. It is another success story for the state of Victoria. Senator O'Chee, you have successes in Queensland, I understand, but this is one of the famous ones from Victoria. What Lonely Planet wants to know is what your government is going to do about this quite remarkable scheme—and I use that word advisedly—outlined in the Export Market Developments Grant Amendment Bill.
It is in that context that the amendment moved by Senator Chris Evans on behalf of Senator Cook is made. I will just go through the amendment. It says:
At the end of motion add ", but the Senate:
(a) is of the opinion that the EMDG scheme is:

PARA.TAB: (i) a successful scheme which enhances Australia's export performance,

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody could disagree with that. I would not have thought that, since at this stage the government is going to continue the scheme, there would be any problem with everybody agreeing with that. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: (ii) a source of job creation and benefits Australia's balance of payments—

SPEECH.PARA: From the speeches that have already been given, it is quite clear that that is correct. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: (iii) a successful export incentive for small and medium sized enterprises;

SPEECH.PARA: Those three propositions are all propositions that I would think nobody would have any difficulty with and should pass. The amendment then goes on to say:
(b) expresses grave concern at the Government's mooted abolition of the scheme which would be:

PARA.TAB: (i) a cynical and blatant breach of an express election commitment to retain and expand the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I can imagine that the government may have some difficulty with the language of that part of the amendment, but if there have been these assurances given by ministers in the now government in the past, then the expression of a disappointment that that election promise is to be broken is a reasonable proposition. The amendment goes on:

PARA.TAB: (ii) counter to any reasonable assessment of the evidence given to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee in the course of the committee's consideration of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: That seems to be a proposition that is undeniable, but the evidence given to the committee, from the way I have read it in any event, would certainly support the proposition put forward by Senator Evans for Senator Cook. The third part of the amendment says:
(c) condemns the Government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the EMDG scheme by making full Export Market Development Grants of 50% available to the tourism industry.

Again, the language is such that the government may have considerable problems about supporting it. The general proposition contained in the amendment is that this is a good scheme that was guaranteed, while the present government was in opposition, to continue, and that it does produce, for the outlays that are made, a great return. If I remember rightly, and Senator Cook might be able to help me, the committee reported that the multiplier for the return for the outlay was something like 15 to 25 times. Senator Cook has acknowledged that that is correct. It would seem, simply by that proposition, to be a foolish thing to take away a scheme that has a multiplier such as that.

This is a scheme that clearly should continue, and the legislation should continue. It is interesting that the government has chosen to continue this scheme by introducing this legislation. The one thing missing is a guarantee that the scheme will continue into the future. For the sake of the commercial health of these exporters that rely upon the scheme, a clear message should be given that the scheme will continue. That is the very best thing that could happen. But if it is not to continue, they should be given as much notice as possible.

The best thing the government can do is guarantee that the scheme will continue. The second best thing the government can do is that, if they are going to stop the scheme, they should tell these commercial and industrial people now that it is going to discontinue. The worst thing that could happen is for them to be left uncertain, which is what the government is presently doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1996. As honourable senators may remember, I have been fairly critical of the export market development grants scheme in the past, but I note that this bill is basically about implementing the Auditor‐General's recommendation to make the scheme more accountable. As such, it is not a new bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the two other aspects is the reduction of the maximum grant from $250,000 to $200,000, beginning in the 1995-96 financial year. We do not have any problem in principle with this. Since the measure was actually announced at the last budget in May 1995 by the then government, and introduced in November of that year, we feel the industry should have had enough time to understand that reductions were under way.

There is an issue of potential retrospectivity that was raised. The issue concerns what to do about businesses that knew the grants were to be cut but then, when the bill was not passed before the election, planned for higher grant levels on the assumption that the bill either would not be passed or would apply from the next year only. I can understand that people may have got themselves into trouble in relation to that, but I think they were certainly taking a bit of risk and skating near the edge if they made business‐critical decisions on that basis—in the face of the budget announcement and the introduction of the bill.

PARA.BREAK: It is an issue of concern, but I will say that I am not really inclined to support the notion that businesses taking risks on legislation failing to pass should have legislation chan ged for their protection and benefit. I will note that any business which was facing the same legislative scenario and which behaved as if the legislation would pass would be disadvantaged relative to the risk‐takers.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue is the grants entry test. This is also of concern to me. The committee report, in relation to what the test is seen as, says:
undermining the open access principle of the scheme by imposing on first time claimants threshold criteria. It was also seen as being contrary to the non‐discretionary nature of the scheme . . .

I do think that this is a way of reducing expenditure, in spite of Austrade's denial. This was confirmed in my mind by the fact that, when we were given a briefing, this was introduced as a way of ensuring that money is not wasted. We do not support waste, but I believe that measures to reduce expenditure—which this is—should be clearly explained as such.

Evidence has focused on the fact that a percentage of the businesses which get export market development grants subsequently fail. The obvious aim of this measure is to reduce such situations by pre‐assessment. With the grants going down and being more discretionary, perhaps the minister will clarify whether this means there will be more grants available to more businesses, especially the service industries which have had more difficulty, particularly finance difficulties, getting assistance because of the nature of their business. Perhaps we could get some clarification from the minister on that.

PARA.BREAK: The idea of pre‐assessment is a vexatious one. Once you enter it, it does eliminate the open access principle, although the access might still be generally available. Discretion involves an assessment rather than a simple criterion, such as has been applied in this program to date. The problem is that, even with the best will in the world, once you get people deciding whether a business is a good one you get into either picking winners or excluding losers and you are in trouble, you are off into the subjective decisions of some panel. Pretty quickly, you are liable to reach a state where some disgruntled applicants take you to court or a tribunal and get you in volved in litigation. You are also a target of claims of favouritism and improper action, no matter how scrupulous you try to be.

SPEECH.PARA: How do service industries then prove their viability? That is a difficulty that goes on and on. If you are providing a consultative service for export overseas, then the difficulty is that you bring the team together. What do you look at when you are looking at the viability of that kind of proposal?

Should it be assessed project by project? That is an important issue. Often a company will build into their total plan the fact that they rely on such government assistance to get a first proposal under way, on the basis that it gives them experience, something to put in their CV. Project by project, it might not actually be bringing in a profit. If you base it on a project by project basis, how do you then check with the company whether or not that is part of their overall plan and whether it will be of benefit to their general business if they proceed in that particular manner?

There is also a tendency, no matter how discretionary schemes start, for a more and more discretionary approach to be adopted. Often those who are charged with making judgements are themselves assessed in terms of outcomes, so they become more and more conservative. What I am highlighting here is that once you make something discretionary, no matter what your intention, you get on a slippery slope.

I am satisfied that the intention is reasonable, but I question the eventual outcome. I would say that it is problematic, but I would prefer to see some hard criteria which can be used as existing criteria are. We would prefer to see you take a little more time and develop such defined criteria so that you can maintain the open access aspects of the scheme while meeting your concerns. Perhaps this could be dealt with by some guidelines in relation to the discretionary criteria, and that would make it fairer all round. Perhaps the minister would like to help us out with whether or not there are guidelines to be written in so that people clearly know the basis on which this assessment will take place.

BREAK.PARA: We would have trouble supporting singing the praises of the export market development grants scheme. As I said, in the past we have had some concerns. So I am unable to support the wording of the opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill and to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Chris Evans on behalf of Senator Cook. As Senator Cook indicated in his remarks, we support the bill itself, but with this second reading amendment which clearly states our support for the EMDG scheme. As outlined in the amendment, we believe that it is necessary to state now in the Senate why this EMDG scheme should be continued, despite the dreadful speculation now coming from government sources that this scheme may be abolished by the ideologically driven right‐wing agenda of the new government to cut expenditure in a blind way, without any thought to the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: As minister for small business in the previous government, and before that chairman of the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee of the Australian Parliament, I have seen the advantages to Australia of both the export market development grants scheme and the DIFF scheme, which has already been announced as being abolished by the government. Both of these schemes are very important to the economic future of Australia.

I find it incomprehensible that there could be members of the new government sitting around the ERC table saying that we can get a short-term saving of a couple of hundred million dollars by abolishing the export market development grants scheme. They do not understand that evidence now before the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee covering this area says that the multiplier effect of EMDG is at least 10 to one and may be up to 25 to one. This means that, for every dollar that we put into that $200 million, we can get back hundreds of millions of dollars more. Mr Oliver from Austrade, before the Senate legislation committee of 5 June, said:

The multiplier found by Professor Bewley, who headed that evaluation, showed that across the scheme, if you considered all claimants, it is 10 to one additional exports. So last year just a touch under $200 million was paid out under the scheme. That in turn generated $2 billion worth of incremental exports. That is the assumption. If you look at claimants that are what we call `experienced' in the scheme—and they would be claimants from year three onwards and have some export experience—the multiplier is up to 25 to one, depending upon the industry and the number of years that the company has been in the scheme.

This is the scheme the government is considering abolishing to save $200 million, which will cost us $2 billion in fewer exports. That means the current account deficit goes out by $2 billion to save $200 million on a short‐term basis.

We do have economic vandals loose in the ERC and in this new government. That is the best way you could describe them because vandals apparently do know what they are doing occasionally—that is, they deliberately go out to wreck something. It may be that we just have a bunch of dills in this new government who do not understand what they are about and do not understand the consequences.

When we were in government we were lectured by the then opposition that we did not understand the importance of reducing the current account deficit. To now have this new government speculating that it wants to get rid of the export market development grants scheme to save $200 million, even though it will add at least a $2 billion deficit on the current account deficit, is extraordinary.

PARA.BREAK: It is probably not surprising that this is starting to occur in this government as its honeymoon is rapidly coming to an end. When you have ministers of the calibre of Mr Downer, Mr Fischer and Mr Moore responsible for administering these schemes in the foreign affairs area, the trade area and the industry area and for explaining them to their cabinet colleagues, who may not be as fully aware of the ins and outs of this particular scheme, you would think they would understand their importance. Information would be available to them from their departments, from Austrade itself, which I have just quoted, from the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, from the foreign affairs depart ment and its trade people as well as, overwhelmingly, from business. Yet that seems to have all disappeared, and the decision to abolish DIFF is a start.

SPEECH.PARA: In today's Australian there is an article by Mr Sheridan which really makes the case of the stupidity of this new government in abolishing the development import financing facility, commonly known as the DIFF scheme. He says that decision:
. . . represents a triumphant combination of mad left and mad right dogma.

That is what he says about getting rid of the DIFF scheme. Yes, there are a few people in the aid area who would like the DIFF money spent on direct foreign aid. If they are successful in getting rid of the DIFF scheme, does anyone believe that that money would be transferred under this government across to direct foreign aid? Of course not. It will be taken as a saving and spent somewhere else; it will not be transferred across to direct aid in the aid budget, administered by AusAID, and made available to many of the excellent NGOs who have overseas aid programs.

I have been approached by some of those organisations and I pointed out that fact to them. It is all very well to argue philosophically that DIFF money should be in the direct aid budget and should not be counted as direct aid but they are giving succour to this government's ideologically driven agenda to reduce aid full stop. The saving in DIFF will not be flowing across to an increase in direct aid; it will go somewhere else.

The article by Mr Sheridan goes on to point out that in the DIFF area, as I have just pointed out, in the export market development grants area, according to an assessment by AusAID, `. . . each dollar of DIFF generates $5 of export income. Thus, to save $100 million, we are going to destroy $500 million in export income.' As Mr Sheridan says: `This is truly stupid.' I think we have a stupid foreign affairs minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order—
—Order! I would ask you to withdraw that, Senator Schacht.

—I withdraw. I think we have a foolish foreign affairs minister, and his performance recently in America proves it. It is only just starting to come out in articles, such as Mr Sheridan's article today. There was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 June and an article in the Financial Review on 14 June. Mr Downer, in speaking to a major foreign affairs forum in America about 10 days ago, attended by other representatives of the Australian parliament both from the government and the opposition, started off his speech by telling Catholic jokes. The journalist who wrote this article in the Financial Review , Mr Stutchbury, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why on earth would he publicly "confess" to Georgetown president, the Rev. Leo O'Donovon, that his Canberra press secretary was once a Jesuit priest but was now "happily married though"? And why would he make a point of revealing that his own seat contained a smaller proportion of Catholics than any other of Australia's 148 federal electorates?

This is the representative of Australia at large in America, one of our closest allies, making stupid comments. It is at the level of Mr Downer's performance of the `things that batter', the thing that cost him the leadership of the Liberal Party. He is at it again but this time he is disgracing Australia overseas. This is the man whom we expect to understand why it is important to maintain the DIFF scheme and the export market development scheme. Yet all he can do when he is overseas representing this country is make himself out to be an embarrassing fool by telling anti-Catholic jokes at a Jesuit college.

I think we all understand that Mr Downer's humour has never grown up since high school, and that is what cost him the leadership of the Liberal Party. Therefore, I think it should be put on notice that, if this sort of performance continues, Mr Howard will have to ask him to step down as foreign minister. We cannot put up with this sort of embarrassing performance overseas.

The same article mentions Mr Fischer turning up at a meeting with the equivalent US secretary and putting his Akubra hat on the desk, which went down like an indication that we are country bumpkins. It certainly did not impress the Americans. You might say that this is our culture, but I do not think it is. When you are overseas you adapt your presentation to the norms of the particular country you are visiting in order to make the best possible impression. Mr Fischer was asked about his trade policies, and this is his reply:

Clearly they now are comfortable with, and expect that, I as Minister for Trade will be pursuing the bilateral with great energy and activity as well as the regional, APEC and the like, as well as the multilateral, WTO and the like.

This is our trade minister. Can anyone tell me what that means? What would happen if officials from his department had to explain to another official in a foreign affairs department what that meant? If that appeared in a memo or a cable and people had to go out and talk it up because it was what our trade minister said, there would be mass confusion. Nobody can understand that gobbledegook. These characters—Downer and Fischer—are being let loose to do great damage to Australia's—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht, you will refer to the honourable members in the other house by their titles as well as their surnames.

—Mr Downer and Mr Fischer are being let loose to do great damage to Australia's reputation. The articles appearing in the press point that out. A program as important as the export market development grants scheme is under threat because, clearly, they do not understand its importance.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it staggering that a coalition which claims to understand business better than the Labor Party, the Greens, the Australian Democrats or anyone else, which claims to have a closer organic relationship with the business community, is blithely making these changes despite the fact that every Australian exporting business is asking them, `Do you understand what you are doing?' But they just proceed in the way they are going because they are ideologically driven and, more importantly, they do not have the ability to assess the outcome that is best for Australia.

Mr Sheridan, in his article, also puts his view about Treasury's assessment of the DIFF scheme. I think he makes some very good points about Treasury. If Mr Costello always accepts Treasury's views we will end up doing nothing because Treasury will not spend a cent. In relation to the DIFF scheme, Treasury itself said:
. . . it is highly unlikely that the DIFF‐related resources would otherwise be idle.
And further:
. . . the DIFF program could cause some misallocation of resources.

As a former minister, I argued against that Treasury view, as did my colleague Senator Cook as a former industry minister, and as did many others. When Treasury was selling us that line, its own dry economic line, we worked out that it was not necessarily in the interests of Australia. This is not about getting the budget deficit down and fiscal rectitude, things which we support. This is the difference between the madness of wiping out export industries and promoting them.

If we take the Treasury line to its ultimate conclusion, in 1787 when the First Fleet was about to set out to establish European settlement, Treasury would have said that it was not a cost benefit plus for Australia or Great Britain. It would have said that it was a misallocation of resources. That is the Treasury line all the time.

On this side of politics, we make no bones about the fact that government should intervene in the marketplace from time to time to reallocate resources in order to get a better outcome for society. That is not what Treasury believes. The monoculture of economists in Treasury have a different view.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the DIFF schemes our competitors have?

—Yes. When you remind Treasury that all our competitors in Asia have a DIFF scheme, it seems to ignore that. There is no response. Treasury still says that it is a misallocation of resources. The more absurd assertion coming from Treasury is that we should be the first ones to make an example by getting rid of DIFF; then, hopefully, our competitors will get rid of their equivalent schemes. That is the naivety of Treasury's argument against DIFF schemes and export market development grants schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to you, the new government, that if you continue to allow the Treasury view to continue, you will be a one‐term government. Your performance already indicates that you will be a one‐term government because it shows that you do not understand the appropriate measures to take to develop growth in our export areas.

Today we have speculation about the end of the export market development grants scheme coming on top of the DIFF scheme. If the maddies in the Liberal Party fall for that, if that is in the budget, there will be a great couple of weeks here when we read back what government senators when in opposition said about these schemes and how we as the then government were not doing enough. You will have to sit there and cop it and explain why you have done a double back somersault and why all these schemes which you said were good when you were in opposition are now going under.

The line about the $8 billion deficit will not wash, and you know it. All you will accomplish by knocking over these schemes is a reduction of the economy, a reduction of our export potential. Mr Moore might have been an excellent stockbroker but I do not think that he has much of an idea about industry. Mr Downer might have been an excellent member of the Adelaide establishment and an excellent lawyer working for the chamber of commerce, and Mr Fischer might have been an excellent farmer, but they have failed to go the next step, to be ministers who understand how industry works in this country.

We very much look forward to the debate on the budget. Senator Calvert, I hope that between now and 20 August you can convince your government not to knock off this scheme on top of the DIFF scheme. If you do, it will be a very bruising day for all of you in government when you find out what you have done to the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in this debate Senator Chris Evans moved an amendment to the second reading and I wish to take a few minutes to address that amended motion. The motion is in three parts and expresses, if carried, that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) is of the opinion that the EMDG scheme is:
(i) a successful scheme which enhances Australia's export performance,
(ii) a source of job creation and benefits Australia's balance of payments, and
(iii) a successful export incentive for small and medium sized enterprises;. . .
That is the first part of this amended motion. I have already spoken to that and made a number of points, but perhaps I should reiterate them quickly.

The first point concerns the excellence of the EMDG scheme. As given in evidence to the Senate committee, this scheme creates a one to 10 advantage and for experienced exporters a one to 25 advantage. The evidence given came from Austrade and is based on calculations done during a review of the scheme overseen by Treasury and Finance which was then reported. The calculations were done by Professor Ron Bewley who is the professor of econometrics at the University of New South Wales. We heard in evidence that, whilst the scheme currently ranks at approximately $200 million on the outlays side of the budget, it generates $2 billion in exports, according to the calculations done by this independent authority.

Any diminution of the scheme will reduce the ability of Australian companies to compete in foreign markets and therefore earn less income for Australia. If the scheme is abolished, we will be cutting off our noses to spite our faces, because we will make a saving of about $122 million—and I will explain that calculation in a minute—for an outlay of $200 million. But we will be losing $2 billion worth of income to the nation because of the exports generated by this scheme. That is a classic case of cutting off your nose to spite your face and that is why the opposition wants this stake put in the ground now. We want Australia to understand that, if this government moves to abolish this scheme as it is rumoured everywhere that it intends to, that will be a classic case of destroying Australia's international competitiveness and blunting the ability of Australian companies—in particular small to medium sized companies—to win export markets overseas.

On average the multiplier is 10 to one. For experienced exporters it is 25 to one, according to the independent findings. That means that experienced exporters can make even more money out of this scheme for the nation. The Australian Information Industries Association—the body covering the manufacture of software, computer parts and computers—says that the multiplier is 30 to one for experienced representatives of their show. What more critical element of industry could there be than the enabling technology of information technology?

When we say in this amendment that it is a successful scheme, we base that assertion on the clear and independent findings of a recent review of the scheme and what it means to the nation. If the scheme is then blunted, undermined or set aside as the rumours suggest, Australians will lose jobs, the current account deficit will blow out even further and small and medium sized companies in this country, which have taken the government's word at face value and gone into exports, will be undermined and undercut.

A report has come to me that on 4 June this year the estimates for Austrade came before the ERC. Of course the government has declined to verify this, but it is a programatic fact that it occurred on that date. Austrade was told by the ERC to find 24.3 per cent in savings, that is, a 24.3 per cent cut in its running costs. Austrade administers this scheme and it takes a lot of manpower in Austrade to do it effectively. It is what Austrade should do and Austrade exists to support Australian companies in overseas markets. If Austrade's running costs are cut by a quarter, by linear calculation one would assume that it will be a quarter less effective in administering the scheme. Austrade is an ingenious and administratively adept organisation, so it will not be as much as that, but there will be a significant impact on the ability of Austrade—the agency appointed to do this—to support Australian companies in the field in their export efforts. There will be job losses in Austrade as well.

BREAK.PARA: In the second part of this amendment to the motion we express grave concern about the mooted abolition of the scheme. The important thing to remember is that this is a consistent rumour. The bureaucracy leaks, industry knows about it and industry is up in arms. There is no other explanation for the number of industry organisations that came before the Senate committee of inquiry and gave evidence of their concerns about the abolition of this scheme. All of them put a stake in the ground and said that this scheme should stay. All of them said in unanimous harmony that, if the government abolished this scheme, it would be a retrograde step. There is no clearer understanding of where industry stands on this than the actual words of industry itself and that has to be borne in mind.

The other significant fact is: what did industry believe was the government's mandate when it came to office? In order to assess what the mandate of this government is, one has to go to their election undertakings. On three occasions we know that this government, in the run-up to the election, made it abundantly clear to industry that this scheme would stay and, in fact, it would become better and bigger. That is not being complied with by this bill, and some industry organisations said that they believed this bill would not come forward because of the undertakings given in the pre-election period by this government.

If the scheme is to be removed, it flies in the face of a specific undertaking given by the Minister for Trade (Mr Fischer) at the National Press Club in February. It flies in the face of a specific undertaking in an election campaign document released by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore, when setting out the government's proposals on this scheme. It flies directly in the face of private and personal assurances, which were reported to the Senate committee by industry associations, given in meetings between them and the Minister for Trade in his chambers prior to the election.

For those reasons, this opposition will fight as hard as it can to ensure that the government is held to its election undertakings, that the expectations of industry are delivered on and that the government does not repudiate its public position. Of course, if the bean counters have their way and it is repudiated, the government must wear the responsibility for that.

The third part of this motion that is before the chamber relates to a condemnation of the government for its failure to meet its election commitment to extend the EMDG scheme by making full market development grants of 50 per cent available to the tourism industry. I have in my notes—and I do not have sufficient time to go through all of them—copious copies of Hansard and a debate in this chamber on 20 June last year. This was a debate on the EMDG scheme. This was a debate which was led for the then opposition by Senator Warwick Parer, now a minister in this government, and he led in his capacity at that time as the shadow minister for tourism. He sought to amend the bill to increase the payments to the tourist industry.

I might say that he made an excellent case. It is good reading. He made an excellent case about the importance of the tourist industry to Australia: why it is an area of major growth, why it is an area of major income, and why it is so important and significant to the current account deficit. The growth in tourism in Australia over the last several years—the years of the Labor government—is a story in itself, but it is a dramatic story; it is a story about an inexorably upward moving graph and about increasing the income earned to this nation and to tourist operators because of more and more tourists flocking to our shores.

Senator Parer then sought to increase in the bill at that time, 20 June, advantages to the tourist industry, which the government at that time rejected. But in the election undertakings these undertakings were underpinned again. My question really is: can the tourist industry trust this government? This is the first opportunity this government has to deliver on those promises to the tourist industry, and they are not in this bill. They have not delivered on them, and they have not shown the slightest inclination to do so. Therefore, when can the tourist industry expect that this government will own up to its electoral undertakings and deliver on those promises?

There is a precedent for this. This bill that we have before the chamber now is substantially, but not entirely, the same as a bill that was produced by the former government and was introduced for debate in November of last year. While it is not entirely the same, it is substantially the same, and one does not take exception to the differences.

There is a precedent for this government to introduce a bill of the former government but attach to it an advantage to a special interest group because it believes it is appropriate. That was the customs excise bill relating to the diesel fuel rebate scheme, where the announcements of the previous government in the 1995-96 budget gave rise to a bill to modify the scheme to cut out unfair claims upon the scheme so the scheme met its original direction. That bill came up here, but it came up here with an extra clause attached to provide a particular advantage to farmers.

I do not criticise the farming community for that. Obviously the government had promised them that at the fist opportunity they would insert into the diesel fuel rebate scheme a provision that provided additional advantage beyond the advantages that were there, and the government may have been wanting then to deliver on an undertaking that it made. But why does it draw a distinction? Why is it all right for farmers when it is not all right, in the case of the tourist industry, to do what the government promised the industry it would do at the first opportunity when it introduced this bill? Why does the government regard this industry, which has been the star performer in Australian industry over the last decade, as a second-class citizen to the farming community when it comes to delivering on promises? As a consequence, we have a provision in this motion which, if carried, will condemn the government for its failure to do that.

Before I conclude, there is another quite significant fact that ought to be said in support of this motion as well. One of the key election promises of the government was to reduce the level of compliance costs by small business, to reduce the amount of red tape that small business had to deal with when seeking government assistance or conforming to government requirements at the law. The government has climbed on high and with a flourish of bugles announced that it has set up a committee that will examine this. We wait with baited breath to see what the findings of this committee will be if and when it actually returns a finding.

We know already that there has been some backtracking by the government, because the minister responsible for small business has tried now to soft pedal on the amount of red tape that will, in fact, be cut. The small business summit last week turned out to be an absolute fizzer as no real changes were made but, nonetheless, the matter is under study. We will continue to follow that debate and see what the study produces. This bill introduces the complexity.

I had the opportunity—which I acknowledge was extended to me by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade, Senator Brownhill, because of my concerns about the administrative complexity that this bill will add to small business—to be shown by Austrade a pro forma document which Austrade is consulting industry about so as to finalise their position on the regulations for the execution of the provisions in this bill, should it be proclaimed. That document produces a form that requires businesses to fill out 10 pages of quite detailed material on their performance, the nature of their accounts, the market they expect, the competitors they expect to meet in that market and a number of other things—10 pages of considerable detail in order to comply with the requirements of the scheme.

I think Austrade is an excellent organisation and I wish it well in reducing those 10 pages to one or two pages. I hope they succeed. My cynical nature suggests that they have the task ahead of them but I wish them well in their endeavours. The point is that the 10‐page, detailed proposal that small business needs to fill out in order to comply with the requirements to access this scheme is a huge paper burden. The election promise of the government to reduce compliance costs by 50 per cent has taken a smashing blow because, while the government is saying to small business on the one hand that it wants to reduce those compliance costs, on the other hand it is increasing the amount of red tape by virtue of this provision. It is not just increasing it a bit; it is increasing it dramatically.

The committee looking at the red tape issue for the government start not from scratch but from behind scratch in the amount of work that they have to do. As I say, I wish Austrade well and I wish the committee reviewing the red tape well. I hope they succeed. My cynical nature tends to think that they will not and that the government's election promise was an empty rhetorical promise, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. It will be seen through on the first couple of occasions that small business run up against this sort of legislation. I know it outrages many people in small business who are feeling used and duped by this type of rhetoric from the government.

I conclude by saying that this is a bill of some importance to the opposition and, I know from their contributions, to the minor parties. On current performance, this scheme generates $2 billion worth of exports for Australia. That is an independently and arms‐length refereed figure, not one plucked out of the air by me. This bill provides an opportunity for industry in Australia to put a stake clearly in the ground saying that this scheme—a $2 billion advantage to this nation—should continue and that the government, which promised to continue the scheme, should be held to that promise.

The bean counters in Treasury and Finance have been after this scheme for a long time—I saw the submissions coming forward during the former government. They do not like this scheme. If they succeed in overwhelming the industry minister, the trade minister and the others who have a vested advantage in defending this scheme, then we in the opposition will fight them. It will be a tooth and nail, down to the wire fight. The government will not be let off the hook. That is a firm promise from me. I have great pleasure in supporting the motion moved by Senator Chris Evans and I trust that the Senate will see the wisdom of it and carry it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Aff airs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cook for his gracious contributions and the previous speakers for their remarks. Senator Cooney paid tribute to Senator Troeth. As is his usual wont, he made a very erudite contribution and I thank him. I share his regard for Senator Troeth's contribution as well. It was in contradistinction to Senator Schacht's contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, your predecessor in the chair had to reprimand Senator Schacht and tell him that he should put the normal appellation before the surnames of people in the other house. It is for a very significant reason that that is done, as you know. Senator Schacht should not throw stones, because he is in a glasshouse. A small slip of the tongue in the pronunciation of his own surname might lead to an appellation that could be misconstrued. It is in his own interests that he should do that.

In his contribution, Senator Schacht attacked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer. I take the opportunity of reading into the Hansard the words that Mr Downer actually used when he addressed the Georgetown Library when making a gift donation for the newly established Australia and New Zealand Studies Centre. You will recall that Senator Schacht attacked Mr Downer for anti‐Catholic remarks. It is very fortunate that, being a practising Catholic myself, I was here and I knew that that was a complete distortion of what actually occurred. I would like to read the contribution that Mr Downer made at that time. He was at a Jesuit institution and said:

Thanks very much, Jeff, and Father O'Donovan, Your Excellency, the Australian Ambassador and Ladies and Gentlemen. Thank you very much for your introduction, Jeff. I am certainly delighted to be here in this world‐famous and truly great Jesuit institution. I have to confess two things. One of them is that my press secretary who is back in Australia at the moment was himself a Jesuit priest but is not anymore. I don't know what one can say about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure about this?
—I am sure. I have the context and if you want me to incorporate it I am happy to do so.
—You may want to do that, but there may have been other comments as well.
—Do I have your permission to incorporate it?
—Is it a transcript?
—It is.
—A correct transcript?
—It is. Then it has `(Laughter)', Senator Kernot, and it goes on:

BREAK.PARA: He is happily married though.

And another thing is, and this is another rather unfortunate coincidence, that if you take the 148 electoral districts of Australia, mine has the smallest proportion of people of the Roman Catholic denomination. That is, of course, a characteristic of South Australia which is very much dominated by people from the Church of England and what used to be the Methodist Church and is now the Uniting Church.

But I am not here to talk about religion. I am here to talk about the Australia and New Zealand Studies Centre which, I think, is a truly excellent initiative and we as Australians are delighted to see this centre of study established and to provide the support we do provide for it.
This is the context that Senator Schacht misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seeking leave to incorporate the document?
—If that is the wish of the opposition, I am happy to incorporate it.
—Including the laughter?
—It has `(Laughter)', yes. It was a joke. You wouldn't understand that it was a joke. I seek leave to incorporate the speech in Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
PRESENTATION BY THE AUSTRALIAN MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS, MR ALEXANDER DOWNER, OF A GIFT DONATION TO GEORGETOWN LIBRARY FOR THE NEWLY-ESTABLISHED AUSTRALIAN AND NEW ZEALAND STUDIES CENTRE
7 JUNE 1996
WASHINGTON, DC
(Introduction by Father Von Arx)

MINISTER DOWNER: Thanks very much, Jeff, and Father O'Donovan, Your Excellency, the Australian Ambassador and Ladies and Gentleman. Thank you very much for your introduction, Jeff. I am certainly delighted to be here in this world‐famous and truly great Jesuit institution. I have to confess two things. One of them is that my press secretary who is back in Australia at the moment was himself a Jesuit priest but is not anymore. I don't know what one can say about that (Laughter) He is happily married though.

And another thing is, and this is another rather unfortunate coincidence, that if you take the 148 electoral districts of Australia, mine has the smallest proportion of people of the Roman Catholic denomination. That is, of course, a characteristic of South Australia which is very much dominated by people from the Church of England and what used to be the Methodist Church and is now the Uniting Church.

But I am not here to talk about religion. I am here to talk about the Australia and New Zealand Studies Centre which, I think, is a truly excellent initiative and we as Australians are delighted to see this centre of study established and to provide the support we do provide for it. And Georgetown University, as I mentioned already, is one of the really great universities of the world, not just of the United Stated. It has many distinguished alumni including, of course, the President. For us to have this Studies Centre at Georgetown, I think, is something very advantageous to Australia.

Obviously, it is a centre that provides educational ties with Australia and helps Americans understand Australia better than might otherwise be the case. But more deeply than that, I think it is a great opportunity for us as Australians to help to get our message across better in the United States and develop an understanding—a better understanding—of Australia in this country.

It is often said that Australians and Americans have a great deal in common and we share common values and so on. But one of the things we really do share is that as societies we have rather similar but not identical origins. That is, we were countries which had a fairly small indigenous population but with very rich cultures. That Europeans came and settled those societies and totally changed those societies and those societies have subsequently evolved from that point. And indeed, one of the interesting things which is worth exploring is the way the society in the United States has differed somewhat in its evolution from society in Australia. Not, I suspect, as many would easily argue because of slightly different, in fact quite different, migration patterns but because of the different values that the early settlers of those two societies had. And I often argue that it is the values of the early European settlers in a so‐called "New World" that very much entrenched for the long‐term the fundamental values of those societies.

So, although Australia and United States have a great deal in common there are some quite subtle differences in the values of our societies—in their value systems. And if you go back and look at the early history of the European settlers in those societies, the differences in those people in Australia and the United States helps to explain the differences in those values. So, I think this would be very much something that could be explored in this Centre. It is a thesis that, as you can see, I am getting excited about (Laughter) A thesis that I am personally quite interested in and one that can be extended to Latin American and to examine why Latin American societies are so different today from societies like the United States and Australia and New Zealand and Canada. So, it is quite an interesting issue.

These sorts of issues are things we need to have a better understanding of. I also have to say that I think the stereotypical view of Australia which exists in the United States as it does in parts of Europe, or probably most of Europe, is a view of Australia that is, I suppose, reasonably flattering but is an unsophisticated view of a society which is, in fact, a very interesting and sophisticated and successful society.

I like ministers who go out and sell their country and as far as I am concerned, I think Australia is one of the true success stories of human civilisation. As a society it has worked incredibly well. It is a multicultural society with people from 120 or 130 countries settling Australia but they live in relative harmony and they live with a great deal of tolerance of different cultures, different religions, different denominations and even of rather different values. It is a country which has developed, as has the United States, a high standard of living and generally speaking, I think, as a country which you could describe as essentially a very decent country. Australia is a country which has very decent values and I think internationally makes a contribution to the world which underlies the essential decency of Australian society.

So, we are absolutely delighted that apart from the perspective of Australia that somehow is a place with kangaroos, where people play a lot of sport and beat Americans at the Olympic Games, particularly at things like swimming, those truly important exercises. And in tennis, we used to beat the United States at tennis once. That takes you back. That takes you back a long time . . . (Laughter) . . . when we used to beat them in the Davis Cup. But that Australia is so much more than that and is such a rich and exciting country. I suppose there is one other thing I should mention before I finish about Australia that I think is simply not understood in other parts of the world. And that is that of all the countries that I have ever visited—and I am biased about this as the Australian Foreign Minister—of all the countries I have ever visited, I think Australia is one of the countries that has the strongest contribution and the strongest commitment to the Arts. That is an aspect of Australian society which is little understood and little known. But the performing arts and the creative arts generally in Australia are very rich and very strongly supported by the Australian people. I doubt, as a proportion of the population you would get more support for the Arts in terms of consumers in any country than you get in Australia.

So, there is much about Australia which I think is misunderstood. There is much about Australia which is not understood at all. And we as Australians are very proud of what we have achieved over the last 200 or so years and we would like to go out and tell our story and sell our story more positively and aggressively than we have done in the past. I guess we are sort of shy and modest . . . (Laughter) . . . people but I don't think we have anything to be modest about. I don't think we should be that. I think we should be quite outspoken and positive about our really great country.

As I said, we are absolutely delighted with this Studies Centre and I am very happy that the Australian Government has decided to present some books to the Centre. I had a look on the way here in the car at the books that we are actually presenting, or at least a selection of them, and I know that I have symbolically to present you, Father with one of those books. I have decided to present a different one from the one that I was originally asked to present cause I didn't like that one. (Laughter) So, I thought that Geoffrey Serle biography of John Monash who is not only a great engineer but he is remembered particularly as a great general during the First World War would be a more appropriate book to present you with than the one that I won't name. But before I do that I also want to acknowledge Henry Nowik who is here with us today if I can see him out the back there. Henry has himself presented—as I understand it—presented the centre with some first editions of Patrick White's novels. And Patrick White is Australia's Nobel Prize winning novelist and a wonderful and particularly interesting writer. So, I would like to acknowledge what Henry has done. We are very appreciative of that contribution as well.
So Father, it is with those few words it is the greatest of pleasure that I make the presentation to you and symbolically pass you this biography of John Monash.
(Applause)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first of the tax bills introduced by this government. This bill seeks to do three things. First, it seeks to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight to six per cent for 1996‐97. Second, it seeks to ensure that in off‐market share buybacks the full buyback process is treated as consideration for capital gains tax purposes—this measure was announced in the 1995 budget. Third, it extends tax deductibility for gifts to a wider range of organisations. The Democrats will be supporting this bill and we will be supporting the amendment that will be proposed by the opposition later in the committee stage—an amendment which applies to the provisional tax uplift factor.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning Senator Short made a clarifying statement about answers yesterday in question time. The issue related to legislation by press release and the particular component that was in question here was the requirement for Treasury to advertise the starting date of this within seven days. There is another matter which is relevant in this bill. I think you can argue that the share buyback provisions are in technical breach of the Senate resolution of 8 November 1988. This resolution, too, deals with legislation by press release and it requires that legislation by press release be introduced into the parliament within six months to preserve the operative date.

It is related. We are not going to say we are not going to vote for the bill because technically it is in breach. You can argue that this provision was included in the bill introduced by the previous government in November last year. It was just outside the six‐month rule. The bill lapsed. This bill brings it back again. We will not be opposing it, but we are very conscious of the fact that legislation by press release, particularly on tax matters, was abused very much in past years.

BREAK.PARA: The Senate sought to redress that, and we want to give notice that we are going to insist in future on the 1988 resolution. We want it to be rigorously enforced. We do not want a return to the days of a Treasurer's abuse of legislation by press release.

On to the provisional tax uplift factor: this is the third time we have debated this in recent years, mostly because the Democrats have put it on the agenda. In 1984 we moved to reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to five per cent. Despite a number of very passionate speeches from coalition senators including, I recall, Senators Short and Boswell—they condemned the eight per cent figure as too high—they went on to vote with the government at the time to keep it at eight per cent. I remember the wonderful reasons given. I will remember them till I leave this place.

First of all, they said, `It costs too much to the budget,' even though it was revenue neutral over two years. Then they said, `Well, if they don't believe that, it really constitutes blocking supply,' which was nonsense as well. Then they came back with, `We have talked to small business and they don't really want it yet. They can wait. They can wait till we come into government.' Well, they have waited.

The coalition is in government. The bill has been brought forward and the Democrats welcome the fact that the politics of the situation, not the merit, now means that the issue will be addressed after three years of small business groups such as COSBOA describing this issue—the provisional tax uplift factor—as one of the biggest issues facing the small business sector.

The result of this bill will be the reduction of taxes collected from small business next financial year by $180 million. This is a tax which the previous government continued to collect on income which small businesses had not in fact earned. The impact of the $180 million impost on small business cash flows, on employment, on tax compliance costs and so on, as the Senate committee found, has been very significant.

We believe that this impost should have been removed years ago. We are disappointed that that was not able to happen. Small business has been extremely disappointed at the behaviour of the previous coalition in opposition, too. But it was a coalition election commitment. It was one of 23 proposals which we put to this new government some time ago. As a sign of good faith, we said, `Here are 23 issues with which we agree in your policy commitments. We are prepared to support them. You could have one piece of legislation passed through the Senate a day.'

But, no. This is the only issue they have brought forward to this date. They have, as some commentators have referred to, stuck to a self-imposed virility test by focusing on Telstra and industrial relations—issues they knew the Senate was always going to take issue with. I add that this government, even with this bill, has failed to live up to the commitment it gave to small business in the election campaign because this bill is only for one year. At the end of 1996-97, the uplift factor will revert to 10 per cent. We will have this debate all over again.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this matter of public interest debate today to raise an issue of great importance to post-secondary education in Australia; that is, the development of learning pathways—allowing students access to post-secondary education across all its various levels, from learning centres right through to universities.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the former Labor government's rhetoric in this area, learning pathways in Australia have not yet evolved to very sophisticated levels. Many of the current structures between the different types of education providers do not mesh properly. Moving between different levels of post-secondary education is very difficult for many students and many of the pathways that are supposed to exist remain very poorly connected. This lack of proper meshing is a major frustration because it wastes the time of students in repeating courses unnecessarily. It also wastes very scarce institutional resources.

As a senator, I have had quite a number of people come to me who have had such pathway problems. One that stands out in my mind particularly is an accountancy student who had completed four years part time of a diploma in accounting at TAFE. That is the equivalent of two years full-time study. When he approached the nearby university to transfer to a degree course in accountancy, he was granted six months out of the two years equivalent. In other words, he was only given a quarter and more or less had to go back almost to scratch. This is despite having spent four years studying part time.
