Those sorts of examples are rife through the system and bring on this need to create smoother pathways from one section to another and to remove the many barriers to articulation that exist in this country.

There have been in recent times some welcome moves on this front. The ministerial council for employment, education, training and youth affairs set up the Australian qualification framework. I emphasise at this stage that what I am about to describe is not in place; it is a plan. It is an objective to get such pathways in place. They are aiming to make national qualifications much more consistent and, particularly in the developing international market for Australian educational services, to make them better understood internationally. They take into account key competency, structure and content, and changes in the vocational education and training courses.

This framework was endorsed by all ministers, state and federal, when it was put to the council. The Australian qualification framework aims to link and mesh our educational sectors to emphasise key competency qualifications and to emphasise skill and knowledge in terms of the levels people are at, not the length of the course. Senior secondary qualifications link in to the vocational education and training level under this scheme and those courses in turn link in to higher education courses. The framework is a very good guide to course developers and it is excellent for an understandable system of qualification registration. We only hope—I will certainly be urging for this to occur—the new government will implement this framework as quickly as possible.

I mentioned that the framework is in the planning stage and not in force across the country. However, there are a number of bright spots that I want to mention briefly where such articulation in the system, such credit transfer, such pathways, already exist in a few isolated spots. They are in my own area of northern New South Wales, so I would like to mention two of them just briefly.

The first is at the Ourimbah campus of the University of Newcastle. Ourimbah, for those who do not know their geography, is just outside of Gosford on the central coast of New South Wales. The University of Newcastle and the Hunter Institute of Technology, which run the TAFE program, have developed a joint development at the Ourimbah campus. They have a single management structure where the vice-chancellor of the University of Newcastle and the director of the Hunter Institute of Technology have devolved responsibility to develop integrated courses and pathways between TAFE and university courses at that site to the director of the central coast campus. They took in their first 50 students in 1989.

I was a member of the committee that was involved in the establishment of that university campus. Now, seven years later, what has developed on this site is absolutely amazing—in terms of facilities, in terms of the programming and in terms of the staffing. Enrolments after 1989 doubled each year and currently there are 3,000 tertiary students on that site, two-thirds of them enrolled in higher education courses with the rest studying vocational education and training.

The campus operates as a single integrated unit. The original plan was to have TAFE up one end and the university down the other end and to have common sports fields, union and library facilities, but they have gone much further than that. You can walk along a corridor and have a TAFE class in one room and a university class in the next one. Staff are all in the same area as well, and it operates as an integrated unit with a very strong emphasis on collaboration across the two sectors. This has assisted potential and continuing students with course choices, articulation of their program and credit transfer.

A federal government working party has now been established to inquire into the further development of this site as a central coast university of technology. The minister has approved a working party to investigate the further development of this concept, which would use not only the Ourimbah site that I have been talking about but also the Gosford and Wyong sites of TAFE, to operate a range of TAFE courses and university courses across all three sites.

There is a very definite need for this in the central coast area. People might not realise it, but that central coast region, Wyong, now has a quarter of a million people. Just to the north is Greater Newcastle, with a third of a million people, and just to the south is northern Sydney, in very close proximity to this campus and with one million people. So it is at the centre of a hub which is well connected by train lines and roads and which will, with this very imaginative approach to post‐secondary education, do extremely well.

A second example of this sort of articulation and excellent credit transfer in the system is further north at the University of the Southern Cross, which is located mainly in Lismore with a number of satellite campuses. They have School of Business courses ranging from the certificate level through to PhD. A lot of these courses are tailor‐made to industry needs. They have worked, in particular, with leading companies such as Coles Myer and, in the public arena, Telstra to develop courses where people can plug in at these various levels and move up to further levels from certificate through to PhD. The two examples I have given are models which show how learning pathways can be properly connected.

However, despite the value of credit transfer, such bright spots as I have mentioned are fairly rare. We have a very poor history in this country on this whole issue of credit transfer which contrasts with countries like the United States, which are much more generous in their credit transfer arrangements. In the three sabbaticals I have done in the United States I noted, in particular, how generous they were in acknowledging properly the work that people had done in some other way before they came to an institution and giving them due credit for it.

Australia reached its low point on this matter probably in the 1950s, when the University of New England broke off from the University of Sydney and the University of Sydney would not recognise the University of New England undergraduate qualifications for post‐graduate work. Fortunately, we have got past that. In the 1960s my sister-in-law did eight‐ninths of a degree at the University of New South Wales. When my brother, her husband, went to New Guinea she enrolled externally through the University of Queensland and they granted her four-ninths of a degree. She had eight-ninths and she had to go back to four-ninths. That is incredibly wasteful.

How are things in the 1990s? They are not much better. One of my daughters is doing a Bachelor of Business at the University of Newcastle. Her husband moved to Sydney with his job. She went to Sydney and enrolled at UTS. She had 50 per cent of a Bachelor of Business. They said: `We will give you 30 per cent.' She managed to haggle that up to 40 per cent. Credit transfer in 1996 is still a major problem.

The credit transfer agency that I referred to earlier hopefully will overcome some of these problems, but unfortunately that agency, with such high and lofty aims, has two people on staff. It is overworked and grossly understaffed. It is a pity, because it is a false economy. If you look at what happens across the whole system, you will find that it is very wasteful for students to repeat work they have already done. It takes up staffing time, it takes up library time, it takes up teaching time, it takes up institutional space.

I will argue that the new government should give a much higher priority than the last government did to this whole credit transfer business, not only because of the obvious economies to the government in such an arrangement, delivering programs much more efficiently and effectively, but also because of the much smoother pathway that it creates for training in our community for individuals, many of whom have been disadvantaged, to achieve their full potential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright, Sen Thomas

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public interest that I wish to rise upon concerns a trip which I made last week to the Western Desert or, more correctly, to the Great Sandy Desert in Western Australia, and consultations which I had with the traditional owners of the land out there in two communities in particular—Parnngur and Punmu—in relation to their views on the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of explanation, because I am a member of the uranium committee which has been set up by the Senate and because my time is very short, I decided that I wanted to visit the major potential sites for uranium mining within Australia. I had the good fortune to go to Roxby Downs or Olympic Dam with the caucus committee last year. So I went up to Kakadu and took my environment adviser with me, at my expense, to talk to the people there. Then last week, taking the opportunity of the break, I went out to the Great Sandy Desert to talk to the people around Kintyre, again taking my environment adviser with me at my expense.

PARA.BREAK: The reason I want to raise this matter with the Senate now is that I believe we need to be extraordinarily sensitive on the question of relations between traditional owners of the land and our white politics and their black politics. I am grateful to Senator West and Senator Mackay, who have given up their time today to allow me to speak on what I believe is a very sensitive issue. I will approach this whole matter with great trepidation, very much aware of the fact that the mismatch between white politics and black politics can lead to a great deal of abuse and unfairness in regard to the black population when it comes to representing their views. Nevertheless, I found that going to the West ern Desert was by far the most important thing that I have done.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Northern Territory you have a different situation. Statute already allows for the views of the traditional owners to be taken into account. Through the Northern Land Council they are able to make their voice heard, and they have an important voice in whether mining goes ahead at Jabiluka or Koongarra. But in the Western Desert the situation is far more confused. I would like first to set the scene as far as the traditional owners are concerned. The Martu people were part of the groups of Aboriginal people who during the 1950s and 1960s were rounded up when they were children and moved on to missions. The missions had a sorry record through the 1950s and 1960s and then, moving into the 1980s and 1990s, they were disbanded.

What has happened with the Martu people is that they have gone back to the land—the traditional land of their forefathers—and have sought to set up their communities again. They have a great desire to see their children grow up on the land on which they were born and which they believe is rightfully theirs.

In the two communities that I went to—the first of which was the community of Parnngur, which is 1,200 kilometres north‐east of Perth and about 400 kilometres inland from Port Hedland—it is truly remarkable to see what these people have been able to achieve. In this regard, when people are talking about ATSIC and whatever deficiencies they might see in ATSIC, it is truly amazing to see what can be achieved by traditional owners—given a reasonable amount of funding—to re‐establish themselves on their land. I think the job that ATSIC has done in both of those two communities is truly remarkable. It is one of those things that really makes you proud to be an Australian and to see that there is some hope and some prospect of reconciliation in this country.

In particular, I would like to thank Teddy Biljabu, who organised the meeting in Parnngur. He is a man of remarkable intelligence, remarkable experience and considerable dignity. He is a man who has the clear respect of the people whom he represents, and a man who is keenly aware of the cultural identity of his people and has a very strong desire for that to continue.

In the Punmu community—which I also visited, at Teddy's suggestion—I met a lady called Patricia Fry, whom I desperately wished worked as an organiser for the Labor Party. I think anyone would be proud to have this woman as an organiser. Her ability to round up people, get them off their behinds and get them to come to a meeting to express their views was truly remarkable to see. I came back with an enormous respect for her intelligence and her commitment to her own people. The other person I would like to particularly mention is a man who was introduced to me as `Longman': I think that was because he was the tallest person there. He also was a person of considerable dignity and was treated with considerable respect by his own people.

The first and most important thing that they had to say to me had nothing at all to do with uranium mining, but related to Mount Cotton, which is a hill which exists immediately behind the community of Parnngur. That is the most important thing to them, and anyone who goes to that community should rightfully reflect that. It is not the other issues that we are concerned with; it is the issue of Mount Cotton, for two reasons.

First of all, Mount Cotton is a very sacred site for them, as far as the women are concerned, and has all sorts of importance associated with their cultural traditions. The second reason is that immediately behind it—as they took pains to show me—is their own burial ground, which has been there for many thousands of years and in which they all hope to be buried.

It is the subject of a mining lease by CRA. It has been drilled, in the past, for exploration. I hope that CRA and everyone else involved in that area leaves it alone from now on. There can be absolutely no doubt about the importance that the local people attach to that particular area.

I was mentioning before that ATSIC had done a great job in establishing these communities. I should also give credit to the teachers in the schools, particularly the teachers in the schools at Parnngur—three people who are prepared to live in the middle of absolutely nowhere. There is very little there except a salt lake and sand dunes. But they work there, teaching the children of the community in the way that they wish to be taught. One of them happens to be a linguist who is teaching them to read and write in their own language.

There is a third community, called Gigalong. Senator Herron had been to visit that community about a week before I arrived. I think that Gigalong should be put in context with the other two communities. I do not know what point Senator Heron wants to make about his visit. He did mention it in question time yesterday.

It is important to see that Gigalong was one of the original mission communities. There are three of these communities in a triangle—Gigalong being one, and Parnngur and Punmu being the other two. The latter two have been established in recent times, as people have taken the opportunity to go back to the land and re‐establish communities on the land on which they were born and which they all have vivid memories of being taken away from as children. Gigalong is one which is in decline, given its mission heritage.

In all of this, there is a very complex and difficult legal situation. I was greatly aided by people who worked for the Western Desert Corporation Legal Centre—which is known locally as `Woodpac'—including, in particular, Grahame Powell and John Ford, who did a great deal to assist me in getting to the communities and organising the meetings. But at the present time, so far as I can establish, there is no direct legal ownership between the people there and the mine which is proposed by CRA at Kintyre.

However, Woodpac is in the process of putting in a land claim on behalf of those people which will be registered within days. The relationship between that land claim and the mining lease at Kintyre is going to become a very crucial one. But whatever else is said about it, the views of the people are very clear indeed.

As I said, I went there with a great deal of trepidation and I think, Madam Acting Deputy President, you, of all people, would recognise that there is this difficulty and sensitivity in dealing with black people and their politics and the mismatch, or potential mismatch, between their politics and white politics.

But let me say that anyone who goes there is left with absolutely no doubt that the people within those two communities do not want uranium mining to go ahead. It is not a question of me or anybody else not being able to understand their politics, their views of expression, or anything else. They make it abundantly clear that it is something that they do not want. They do not want it because they do not understand it.

I would not suggest to the Senate that these people are as expert in the issues of uranium mining as I am, or others are, but they know that it is dangerous. They know that it threatens the things which they hold most dear: the water and the air. They do not believe that they know enough about it to be able to make a decision on what they know is a crucial question and for that reason, they do not want it to go ahead.

It is important now because I know the pressure that the uranium companies are under at the moment. There is a narrow window of opportunity for new leases to be signed, given the cessation of supplies from the former Soviet Union. But it is a very short‐lived opportunity, and the pressure will come upon these people and on the government between now and the end of this year to have leases granted and deals signed.

I must impress upon the Senate that these people want much more time to understand the issue and to have all of these things taken into consideration before they have any idea of signing leases or giving their permission for mining to go ahead. It requires all people involved in this, particular the media, to be particularly sensitive to this situation. Nothing could be worse than a bunch of people going out to these communities with TV cameras, poking microphones into people's faces and saying, `Are you for or against this issue?' That would be the worst prostitution of the black political process.

The only way to do it is to do as I did: to sit down in the red dirt with these people and listen to their views. I must say that their views are very strong. As they said to me,`How many times do we have to tell you white fellas that we do not want this to go ahead.' They made it clear to me that they do not want the money. As I have said to you, ATSIC is providing sufficient funding for them to establish their communities and they certainly see no need for the money and they are not in the slightest bit interested in compensation. The land, as it exists at the present time, is infinitely more valuable to them than any amount of money that could be offered to them.

They do not want the jobs either because they do not see the jobs as meaningful. They have had an experience with jobs and mining before. As Teddy put it to me quite clearly: all of the white fellas get the good jobs in production where they can be trained and get transferable skills, and all of the blackfellas are put outside to dig holes, plant trees, water them, and so on. They do not see those jobs as real and useful.

If you talk to the women, their views are even more strongly expressed. They ask why the men should go away for two weeks from the community. The money would be paid to the men—whereas presently, the income for the community is paid to the women—and the men would spend it on alcohol. They would bring the alcohol and all sorts of other social problems back to their communities, and for what reward? They are acutely sensitive to their own social organisation and to the impact that outside forces have on it. They have seen what happened after they were herded away from this land before, and what has happened to their communities on the coast which is where they all ended up after the missions collapsed.

So their views are very strong. They are not views that take any great understanding of voodoo magic or anything else. They are view of sensible, intelligent people who do not understand the issues involved in something which they can clearly see is a very important and threatening prospect for them. They want to be taken seriously. They want to be informed, and they want sufficient time allowed for them to be informed before any questions are raised about whether the uses for the land that they hold as desperately dearly as they do, should be changed.

I think all of us approach traditional Aboriginal owners in this country with a great deal of humility. We recognise the sins that have been committed by white people before us, and I think all of us are sensitive to the needs and aspirations of Aboriginals. But, in this area, their views are clear. They are the views of sensible and intelligent people and they deserve a right to be heard. I hope the Senate and the government takes due regard of their views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to place on record some of my concerns about the current gun debate following the resolutions agreed to by the Australian police ministers at their conference on 10 May. In summary, those concerns are: firstly, to correct the mistaken impression that far right extremists are running or driving the debate, they are not; secondly, to state that gun owners have every right to put their case and to have the new laws clearly explained; and, thirdly, to state that getting the first two wrong will have the paradoxical effect of driving decent Australians unwittingly into the arms of extremists.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to my first argument, I will quote from Malcolm McGregor's column in the Australian Financial Review on 12 June. He refers to those with concerns about the gun control resolution as the `detritus of the Bjelke‐Petersen army' and `Queensland's political fringe dwellers'. He implies that they have a single digit IQ, and that they form the lunatic wing of the National Party constituency—the `ratbag fringe'. This is far from true and grossly offensive to the hundreds of thousands of gun owners throughout Australia, the National Party and, I might add, the Bjelke‐Petersens.

As many in this parliament know, and as the press gallery would know, I am no friend of the far right. In 1988, I gave a speech in this chamber which exposed their groupings, their modus operandi and their offensive agendas. While not exactly endearing myself to some parts of my electorate, this speech contributed to dampening the efforts of the far right in the late 1980s. I have continued to head them off whenever I have noticed them surfacing again. I ask you to believe, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I know what I am talking about when it comes to the far right in Australia and that I am not afraid of taking them on.

Of course, it would be more convenient for all of us if the debate was being driven by the far right. We could dismiss their concerns, as McGregor and others have done, but that is the easy path. In this case that would be to walk away from the many ordinary, law abiding Australians who want nothing to do with extremism. I say quite emphatically that the far right is not driving the gun debate in Australia. The attendance at the gun rallies over the last couple of weeks attest to that. At the Melbourne rally there were 70,000 to 100,000 people, definitely not Queensland fringe dwellers, Sydney saw 35,000 people, Brisbane saw 5,000 and so on.

If all of these people were aligned with the extremists then Australia would be in big trouble, but they are not. It is most offensive to have the label `right wing ratbags' thrown at them. Writing them off like that is wrong. They are Australians like the rest of us. The overwhelming majority are not anti‐Semitic, racist, or believers in conspiracy theories about one‐world governments. As every day Australian workers, it is their right to take to the streets. It is their right to have their voice heard and it is their right to be given a fair go.

They are clerks, salespeople, panel beaters, doctors, professors, school teachers, computer operators, small business owners, train drivers and so on—responsible, law abiding citizens. Are we to dismiss them by diagnosing them as suffering from `ignorance . . . with lashings of personal paranoia and religious fundamentalism', as suggested by Geoffrey Barker in the Financial Review on 11 June?

PARA.BREAK: There will always be ratbags who align themselves with a cause in order to pursue their own agendas. This happens on all sides of politics and on all issues. But let us not confuse the ratbags with the average Austral ian. As always happens, the ratbag element is more colourful and sensational than anyone else so they capture a greater proportion of the media and public attention. That is, after all, what they set out to do. If we give them a profile that they want, who is the bigger fool? They are parasites who live on the hard work and sweat of honest Australians. They see an opportunity and they try to jump on the bandwagon.

SPEECH.PARA: The atmosphere of most of the gun rally meetings has not contained the hysteria and rantings of the far right renewal of the 1980s. That movement was driven by extremists. They were the ones who organised and advertised the meetings, booked the halls and drove the debates. It was their extremist literature which was sold on trestles at the back of halls, and it was their own speakers who addressed the crowds.

Most of the gun rally groups, on the other hand, have been at pains to distance themselves from the obvious extremist elements. They have not always succeeded, but they have made great efforts that should be on the public record. The far right groups are very wily in insinuating themselves at these meetings. It is difficult to keep them out, but I am satisfied that there have been many attempts to restrict their presence at the major rallies.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party (Mr Fischer) recently commented that there was not enough done to sell the gun control agreement. That is true. It is also a fact that, until the states legislate on the agreed resolutions, it is difficult to know precisely what the detailed ramifications will be. The translation of resolutions into legislation is not straightforward, as any draftsman will tell you. There will be bumps and bruises along the way, as is to be expected.

In light of these considerations, it behoves all of us to keep the debate temperate and reasonable. Surely, the legacy of Port Arthur should be unity of purpose in working out how to reduce violence in our society. `Working out' does not mean driving people into groups. Indeed, for the resolutions to work, they will need the cooperation of the very people who are being ostracised as extremists. Pointing the finger at every gun owner in Australia and saying `You are a redneck' will not help us learn from Port Arthur.

As I said in my speech in 1988, the groups to the far right thrive in times of frustration and dissension. Many times, that means that extremists flourish when parliament is not doing its job properly. There are two ways to put a stop to the influence of these groups. One way is to have good government policy, clearly enunciated, with a good opposition to ensure that the voices of all Australians are heard in these chambers. The other way is to know the extremists for what they are, so that citizens can make an informed choice about whether to have anything to do with them.

We have to be wary of isolating gun owners from reasoned debate, because they then become prey to extremists. If we group them all in the one net, not only are we being unjust and effectively censoring reasonable debate but we are also running the risk of giving the extremists a ready‐made audience. Who are the real extremists? Ian McNiven is very small time, and all gun owners and industry representatives that I know will not truck with him. Every time he opens his mouth, he indicts himself. There is no fear from that quarter that he could drive any debate further than his own backyard.

Tony Pitt is another long‐time fringe hysteric. Apart from putting together the Cap publication Fight, he has popped up in other extremist publications, such as Lock, Stock and Barrel and The Strategy. He now runs a splinter group called The Australians, and it is a very small splinter at that. Ron Owen, gun shop owner and publisher of Lock, Stock and Barrel magazine is another loudmouthed stirrer. His magazine is a menagerie of conspiracies, revisionism, racism and anti‐Semitism. In its pages, you can read interviews with all the far right luminaries of our time, from tired old Eric Butler and Jeremy Lee of the League of Rights, to Perry Jewell of former Cap fame, and Dennis Stevenson of CEC and LaRouchian notoriety.

Ron Owen has distinguished himself by inviting donations to the AWB, the white Afrikaaner resistance group, which has terrorised black South Africans. You will even find that Scarlet Pimpernel of the lunatic fringe, Michael Darby, contributing his disturbed ramblings from time to time. In the August‐September 1994 issue of Lock, Stock and Barrel, Darby says families should practice drills in the event of Indonesian occupation. This involves learning rules such as:

Never attack an individual unless you can be absolutely certain of killing him without witnesses; never attack a group or unit unless you are absolutely certain of killing everyone in that group or unit.
He recommends stockpiling poisonous snakes and spiders and states:
An enemy soldier who offers to change sides rather than be killed, should be killed.

Despite all these nasties, I would think that most of the revenue from Owen's magazine sales comes from government and other people buying it to keep an eye on what he is doing. People like Owen, MacNiven, Pitt and Darby are two‐dimensional cartoon characters who make for entertaining reading one day and sink back to political oblivion the next. If we give them leadership status in the gun debate, we only serve their agenda and boost their appeal.

The Graeme Campbell story is a bit different. Here you have a member of the Commonwealth parliament with the associated profile, resources and political acumen to buy more credibility than Owen and his ilk. Here you have a man who was thrown out by the socialists and who still kept his seat. He has been fawned upon by the Eric Butlers and Denis McCormacks of this world until he believes what they tell him—that he can found a successful new political movement in Australia. So he develops a three‐paragraph manifesto which generalises about manufacturing and immigration and that old nectar of the far right, CIR. He is not really setting the world on fire, even if he is making a few bucks selling his book through extremist networks.

Then along comes Port Arthur and the gun control issue: a hell‐sent opportunity. Most Australians still think of Graeme Campbell as being that maverick Labor guy from Western Australia. They cheer him on because he got stuck into Keating. But he is more than that. His long‐time political buddies, Australians against further immigration, are bedfellows with most of the extremists in Australia.
One AAFI candidate in the Melbourne Herald-Sun on 15 April 1994 said:
My policies on refugees and illegals is to reopen the second Yallah meatworks, creating up to 500 local jobs, and convert them to blood and bone.

In January of this year, before the last federal election, Eric Butler and Jeremy Lee of the League of Rights held a meeting on the Gold Coast to drum up support for Graeme Campbell's political movement. They already had their sights set on the 1999 elections. One fellow was to run a candidate training school for Campbell candidates. Eric Butler waxed lyrical about Campbell, likening him to Menzies. Butler said Campbell had similar policies to the League, for example immigration and CIR. He said that there were women at recent Melbourne meetings who said, `Oh, if we could just touch him.' Jeremy Lee sold Campbell's lecture booklets for $5 a touch.

There is a more disturbing link between Campbell's friends and American extremists. Let me remind the Senate what Campbell has said about the AAFI's Denis McCormack. In a letter to voters in April 1992, he wrote:
I have no hesitation in recommending Denis McCormack as an intelligent and courageous Australian.
On Australia Day this year, Campbell, in conjunction with the AAFI, made a policy launch speech, in which he said:

In the state of Victoria, I intend to endorse the AAFI candidates in places 1 and 2. I think Robin and Denis are excellent candidates and Denis, as Number 1, has an excellent chance of being elected. I believe he deserves to win and, believe me, Australia needs him to win.

The same AAFI were a significant presence at the Melbourne seminar by Jack McLamb. Denis McCormack, amongst others, attended. The Australia Israel Review 's Adam Indikt reported in the December 1995 issue that AAFI cassettes and Campbell's book, Australia Betrayed , were on sale.(Extension of time granted)

Adam Indikt says that `several of those involved in the McLamb event had also helped organise and been present at a public meeting held by AAFI at the Lilydale Motor Inn on October 27'. Jack McLamb's visit was allegedly organised by Ray Platt, the editor of the extreme publication Strategy, which is a haven for various fringe elements, including the AAFI.

Jack McLamb is an American militiaman. He is a partner with Bo Gritz, a one‐time Vice‐Presidential nominee on the ticket of former Ku Klux Klansmen David Duke. McLamb is a notorious figure amongst US citizen militia groups, ready for armed insurgence against the global planners in their government. After the Oklahoma bombing incident, the American media profiled groups with similar conspiracy leanings as the accused bomber. McLamb and his associates all featured prominently.

The Pittsburgh Post Gazette of April 23 1994 reported that McLamb `cites racial intermarriage as religiously offensive and part of a one‐world conspiracy'. The Denver Post on 30 April 1995 described McLamb as `one of the nation's most militant militia organisers' and said that he had `purchased an 80‐acre parcel adjoining Gritz's white supremacist land development project where, if you buy an allotment, you also get military training thrown in'.

What this man can contribute to Australian society I do not know. But the real point is that Campbell's friends, whom he has repeatedly and publicly endorsed, obviously believe the Jack McLambs of the world should be encouraged. Mr Campbell has tried to distance himself from another American extremist, Lyndon LaRouche, who went to gaol for robbing old ladies of their life savings. Much as he tries, however, Campbell can never get himself away from the fact that he signed a petition calling for the exoneration of Lyndon LaRouche. It is in black and white on the back of several CEC newspapers.

This group is really weird. They blame Prince Philip for the genocide in Rwanda; in the United States they have associations with everyone from the Ku Klux Klanners to the Teamsters Union and Manuel Noriega—a real nice bunch. Do not insult the intelligence of thousands of gun owners by telling them that those lunatics are driving the gun debate. They hamper it. They do not drive it.

My attitude to the gun control resolutions is, I hope, a reasonable one. Let's communicate with all the legitimate stakeholders so we can make the resolutions work. A positive approach, not a punitive name‐calling one, is needed. Attacking gun owners will meet with nothing but resistance. It must be accepted and known amongst the community that people at these rallies give near unanimous support to the banning of semiautomatic military assault style rifles. Like it or not, it is apparent that gun ownership is widely spread throughout our community, both rural and urban.

Accepting significant changes to a deeply embedded cultural icon was never going to be easy. Irresponsible comments which alienate stakeholders from either side of the debate just make it more difficult. Port Arthur did not happen so that Australian society should go backwards and become more divided, and provide a platform for extremists. If anyone is allowed to use the tragedy to further their political career we have lost the plot. Port Arthur demands workable remedies, not political opportunism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Boswell on much of his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time now, the Liberal and National parties have asserted that the public sector must be reduced and that the role of the public sector should be revised. This ideological drive for less government support for the people of Australia remains a debatable issue.

Immediately following the March election, the new government announced that two per cent would be cut from public expenditure. This was followed by the apparent discovery of an underlying budget deficit which has been the dubious justification for the coalition government's cuts of $8 billion over two years.

What we did not know was that the states would bear the brunt of the cuts and that the negotiations with the states would turn to farce. In a paper distributed by the University of New South Wales, John Quiggin examines from where the apparent budget deficit has appeared. The conclusion is that the figures are derived from revised, lower estimates of economic growth which are not convincing and the impact of which is exaggerated. Quiggin states that the deficit is amongst the lowest in the OECD and that the levels of debt are far from unsustainable.

So this conservative government has fabricated a debt for its own purposes and is foisting that debt onto the states. To put it bluntly, the states are getting done. The outcome of the Premiers Conference last week can be put simply: the states have been done for $2 billion over two years.

By forgoing indexation of the financial assistance grants, the states will lose $644 million in the first year. The three per cent cut to special purpose programs—excluding universities, that is—amounts to about $400 million in the first year. Combined, that is $1 billion each year for two years. Therefore, the states have accepted cuts of $2 billion which, for the government, is supposed to represent a quarter of the mythical debt. That means the states will have been asked to contribute one‐quarter of this mythical debt.

One billion dollars per year translates into 50,000 jobs, which includes the multiplier effect. Tasmania's proportion of that is 1,500 jobs in one year and 3,000 over two years. Why would the states accept this? One reason is that they were given no choice. Another possible reason is that there is an as yet unannounced sweetener in the untying of the tied grants, giving the states greater discretionary powers over the moneys required for matched funding.

It is important to ask what these cuts will do to Tasmania. Full sales tax will be imposed on executive vehicles, with a cost to the state of $3 million. There will be a three per cent cut in specific purpose payments, being about $11 million. Where specific purpose payments are paid through the state to others—for example, for higher education, non‐government schools and local government—the three per cent maximum does not apply, so cuts probably will be greater than three per cent.

BREAK.PARA: The states had been promised increases in financial assistance grants. The states have forgone these so as not to lose full sales tax exemption. What is the cost to Tasmania? It will be $16 million this year, $17 million next year and $8 million the year after that. That is in addition to an already anticipated state budget deficit of about $30 million.

How is Tasmania going to cover this? Several options have been suggested. One is to increase taxes and charges. Another is the sale of the Hydro‐Electric Commission. The third is a possible Costello‐style levy. To put it in perspective, the proposed cuts are equal to 40 per cent of the running cost of the Tasmanian police force. We are talking about potential job losses of 1,500.

Why did the premiers not challenge the whole concept of the mythical debt? Why did the premiers not see that the federal government was using unsubstantiated financial claims to rake moneys from the states? Why did Tasmania's Premier Tony Rundle not put Tasmania's case? Why did Premier Rundle not point out that, because Tasmania's economy is running at one‐sixth the growth rate of the other states, Tasmania simply cannot afford to wear cuts at the same rate? The states did not expect that the government would act in such an incompetent manner on these issues—or did we understand all along that the Liberal and National parties are incapable of offering effective and responsible government?

Let me just remind you of what is being done to Tasmania. I have already mentioned the loss of sales tax exemption and the cuts in both specific purpose and financial assistance grants. There is also the slashing of our vital labour market programs, the threats to our only university, and whatever will come from the devolution of responsibility for aged care and other services. What is being done to our vital public sector is appalling. As of 5 June, we know that 9,588 public sector jobs will go in the pre‐budget round. Two thousand of those jobs are going from the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Of these two thousand, 800 people are losing their jobs to pay for the department's aggregate redundancies. That is 40 per cent.

This department is responsible for, amongst other things, the delivery of Working Nation programs. One of the principles of Working Nation was to provide greater resources for training for the long‐term unemployed in those regions with the highest levels of unemployment. Tasmania is one such region. Madam Acting Deputy President, over the last two years more than two‐thirds of the drop in unemployment in Tasmania has been in the long‐term unemployed category, which is directly attributable to Working Nation programs. Also, by extrapolating the figures known from cuts to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, it is disturbing to calculate that, of the 310 redundancies from the Commonwealth departments in Tasmania, 124 of these job losses will be instituted simply to fund the redundancy program. In other words, over one‐third of the cuts in Tasmania have not been carried out for any functional reasons, but simply to fund the aggregate redundancies. This is, bluntly, incompetent fiscal policy. This demonstrates the inept and callous nature of this government, where individuals have become expendable and where valuable people are being used to meet the government's ill‐constructed financial bottom line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on 13 June this year I attended the opening of the Law School at the University of Notre Dame in Fremantle, Western Australia. Notre Dame is Australia's first Catholic university. It commenced teaching in January 1992. Notre Dame has two campuses, one in Fremantle and the other in Broome, Western Australia. One of the features of the university is that its academic year differs from that of other Australian universities because of its relationship with the University of Notre Dame in the United States. The academic year commences in early February, with its first semester lasting until May. This is followed by a winter term, which runs from June until mid-August, with the second semester beginning in August and ending in December.

SPEECH.PARA: The university was set up by an act of parliament in Western Australia in 1989 and is owned, controlled and operated by a board of trustees and a board of governors. The university has a close relationship with the University of Notre Dame in Indiana in the United States, and it has drawn much of its founding inspiration and philosophy from that university. It is worth while to note, whilst we are looking at the question of funding for higher education institutions, that Notre Dame is not funded by the Commonwealth. In fact, that university is a living example of what can be done by the private sector in eduction. The fee in relation to Notre Dame is $690 per unit for full-time Australian students and $1,220 per unit for full-time overseas students. Needless to say, the service of overseas students is a growing area, and the export of education generally is a growing area for Australia.

At present there are 1,000 students enrolled, and law enrolments will not be opened until next year. As I understand it, the university, in contrast to Bond University, is more economical in its costs and overheads in relation to the cost per student per annum. Having visited the Notre Dame campus, I can say that much has been done to economise on expenditure without any sacrifice in quality. This is perhaps something that public universities could well take heed of.

In closing, the university aims to be faithful to the intellectual and spiritual ideals which have been the foundation of the great Catholic universities of the world. Like them, Notre Dame Australia seeks to be a leader in scholarship and education. Basically, there are four main objectives of the university: first, to provide, through teaching, pastoral care and personal development, for the total education of its students; second, to support an academic community noted for its excellence; third, to support the role and work of the church in Australia; and, fourth, to make a special contribution to the economic and social development of Australia.

At present, the university has four colleges—namely, arts and sciences, business, education, and theology. The two campuses contribute greatly to the local communities in Fremantle and Broome. I believe Notre Dame, as a university, will contribute greatly to the future of young Australians. I look forward to the intake of law students at the law school in 1997 and I congratulate all the staff associated with its development, especially Geraldine Byrne, the law school secretary, and Mary Eileen Gaunt, the registrar. I believe that the opening of this law school at Notre Dame will be one of the steps along the way in the success story that will be Notre Dame Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is examining a re‐writing of the tax act. As I understand it, the first instalment of that will be introduced into this chamber shortly. What I raise today relates to the need to redefine and to correct some of the problems that have emerged from some elements of tax law, particularly those that were used improperly in the House of Representatives in respect of criticism of me.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may recall that last year the House of Representatives passed a resolution condemning me for, allegedly, revealing a tax file number in a document presented to this chamber. Apart from the political stunt involved in that activity by the previous government—it was in fact the then Treasurer, Mr Willis, who moved the resolution—the reality is that at no stage was the number ever identified as a tax file number. It was claimed in the House of Representatives at that time that I was protected from the consequences and the penalties of such an offence by parliamentary privilege. Of course, that is totally false, but it was among a whole range of false accusations made at the time.

If there are to be offences for revealing a tax file number, it is absolutely vital that the tax file number be identified as such. In the law, as it stands at present, there is no requirement for a tax file number to be identified on a document as a tax file number. The document that I presented to this chamber had a whole series of other reference numbers in front of what turned out to be a tax file number. I can evidence the fact that this would not necessarily be identified as a tax file number by referring to evidence given by a tax officer to a Senate estimates committee. I asked the tax officer:
Will you explain to me what the words `our reference' mean on an Australian Taxation Office letter?
This was the particular letter that I had tabled.
For example, the letter states `our reference' then `13/BA51' followed by a series of numbers. What do the words `our reference' mean?
The tax officer responded:

That would be an in‐house identification of the source of that document. I do not know precisely what the `13' or the `BA' stands for. The `BA' may be the initials of the writer. The `13' may indicate the branch office from which the letter came. I would imagine the numbers to which you did not refer possibly were the equivalent of a tax file number.
His words were `possibly were the equivalent of a tax file number.' I went on to say:
So that may include some numbers which could possibly be a tax file number? I am just summarising; is that basically what you said?
I wanted to get it absolutely clear from the tax office that that was the situation. His response was:
It could, yes.
I then went on to ask:
So is revealing our reference number, which may possibly include a tax file number but which is, in fact, your internal reference number, an offence?
The tax officer responded:
I would have to take advice on that particular issue. I would imagine that if the item of information was not described as a tax file number it may well be hard to prove that it was an offence.

That was the tax office advice. If it was not identified as a tax file number, as it was not in this case, then it might well be hard to prove that it was an offence and, in fact, you might well not know by looking at it that it was a tax file number.

It is the concern of the tax office that in fact revealing a tax file number when it is not evidently a tax file number may make it very difficult for the tax office to proceed against someone who makes such a revelation. Clearly, it is both in the tax office's interest and in the interests of people, such as I, who innocently gave a reference number which included a tax file number, that on both accounts we be protected by a better law.

The tax office will clearly have great difficulty pursuing people for breaking the law in relation to tax file numbers unless the tax file number is identified as a tax file number. How curious it is that the tax office is saying, `Yes, it is a bad situation and it makes things difficult for us. Yes, it may possibly not be recognisable as a tax file number.' How different that is from the resolution, passed by the House of Representatives, which condemned me. In part, it reads:
(d) Senator Baume, in seeking the leave of the duty Minister and the Senate to table the documents in question, did not draw attention to the tax file number identified therein . . .

That is a simple, uncomplicated lie. There was no tax file number identified therein. Mr Willis, the minister, knew that perfectly well at the time, and it was a fact reinforced by the opinion given to the Senate estimates committee by the tax officer who appeared before that committee. There was no identified tax file number. The basis on which I was condemned by the House of Representatives—and, I might say, also criticised in this chamber—was totally and absolutely false.

It seems to me that it may be appropriate for that chamber, now that it is no longer dominated by people who seek to make political capital out of a stunt like this, to withdraw that quite improper condemnation of me for doing what was right and what was clearly legal at the time. It is incredible that the minister, Mr Willis, accused me of indulging in what from any other person would be a criminal action; yet we have just heard that the tax officer involved said that it would be very difficult to establish that, and that it was only `possible' that the figures revealed were the equivalent of a tax file number, maybe. In other words, the present law is absurd.

But even worse, it seems to me, than the absurdity of the present law, is the way that the previous Labor government misused it in a personal vendetta against me simply on the grounds, of course, that I had offended the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating, by revealing information he did not want revealed about his extraordinary misuse while Prime Minister of his office to enrich himself as a result of personal activity and personal investments. It has been a tradition in this place that this sort of thing should not take place, and in the past it has not. But because of this personal vendetta against me, we had the House of Representatives being grossly misused and, as I said, Mr Willis was prepared to say things like this about me:
His actions engaged in by anyone outside this place would amount to criminal behaviour—
not `may', not `might', but—
would amount to criminal behaviour and may even amount to criminal behaviour by him.
And yet we know perfectly well that the tax officer said, `It may have been a tax file number but it was not identified as such.' At no stage was it identified as a tax file number.

Of course, it may well be that Mr Willis was simply relying on the extraordinary and politically very convenient advice he received from another officer in the Taxation Office. I have already expressed my concerns about the way that particular officer, Mr P.E. Simpson, the second commissioner, was prepared to go on the record as saying in a confidential memorandum which, in my view, was grossly and improperly tabled by Mr Willis:
the tabling of the information, which I understand included a TFN—
`I understand', he said, `included a TFN'—
by Senator Baume is prima facie an offence under section 8WB and possibly of section 8XB.

No, the second commissioner did not understand too damn well because when he said that he understood that it included a TFN, it was not a TFN identified as such. It was part of `our reference number', and it included a whole lot of other figures, as I have already outlined to this chamber.

The fact remains that the use of this device as a way of beating me around the head because of the way I have been effectively pointing out the improper behaviour of Mr Keating and, in particular, his partner—to whom Mr Keating had given his power of attorney several years before that—is clear evidence, I believe, of a misuse of that chamber.
The tax officer then followed up his quite improper recommendation to the minister, by saying:
There has, however, clearly been a breach of section 8WB and that breach has a number of dimensions
and one of the dimensions that relates to me is
. . . the disclosure of that information by the Senator.
As I said, it is simply ludicrous that the law should be so badly worded that it is an offence to reveal a tax file number without the tax file number being identified as a tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ludicrous.

—Absolutely ludicrous, as Senator Abetz has just interjected. He was at the Senate estimates committee at the time and he heard the responses from the tax officer indicating that it may possibly be identifiable, but not necessarily identifiable, as a tax file number.

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of this nonsense, Mr Willis, whom, I must say, I have always found to be a decent chap, went on to say:
Senator Baume's action is obviously exceedingly serious. It undoubtedly amounts to disgraceful behaviour and, indeed, criminal behaviour . . .

That is simply false and it is recognised to be false except, of course, by all those sitting opposite, who have a particularly one‐eyed view of how to take smart alec political points without regard for decency and integrity and for the duty of people in this place to reveal what should be revealed for particular purposes. He went on to say:
His action amounts to criminal behaviour . . .

I am continually being accused by the Labor Party of criminal behaviour with no evidence whatsoever to support it. On the contrary, evidence in Senate estimates committees has clearly shown that it is baseless because, in fact, the tax file number was never identified as a tax file number. There is an obvious need not only to clear up the disgraceful attack on me but also to clean up this legislation so that no-one else ends up in a situation of being improperly accused of criminal behaviour and of being saved from criminal prosecution because of parliamentary privilege. The facts are that the tax office said:
I would imagine that if the item of information was not described as a tax file number it may well be hard to prove that it was an offence.
The tax department itself said:
. . . it may well be hard to prove it was an offence.
There is clearly a need to ensure that that sort of nonsense is not allowed to continue. An inadequate law has to be corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to bring to people's attention what is happening within some specialist sections of the Public Service. In particular, I refer to the provision of services to mining companies in this community, to the regional areas that they service and to the effects of this on the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, otherwise known as AGSO.
—A very important body.
—You are right, Senator Sherry; it is very important. An article from the New Scientist dated 1 June says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the latest casualty of the government's aim to slash expenditure on public sector science.

A paper distributed to staff at a meeting on 13 May said the AGSO budget is likely to be reduced from this year's $55.5 million to $37.8 million in 1997‐98. That is a budget cut of more than 30 per cent over the next two years.
This means that somewhere between 102 and 132 staff will be losing their jobs, and these are the scientists that are involved in the geological mapping of this country.

An article from a newspaper last Sunday in New South Wales outlined the benefits that are going to accrue to this country from a Newcrest mine at Cadia near Orange. I understand that Newcrest were encouraged to look further in this area at Cadia because of the geological mapping. They have found one of the richest gold deposits in this country. This will do not only wonderful things for the Australian balances of payment and trade but also wonderful things in the local area in terms of employment and infrastructure, and in general boosting morale in country areas.

Of course, that is not the only mine that has been discovered as a result of this geological mapping survey by AGSO, in cooperation with the states. It is very important and I think it is a thing that we can ill-afford to lose. I draw attention to an article that appeared in the Australian on Monday, 3 June, which said:
Strong protests over the cuts have been lodged by mineral firms including Mount Isa Mines, Normandy Exploration, Equinox Resources, Cable Sands, Orion Resources and Paladin Resources.
They warned Australia was still extensively unmapped and unexplored in geological terms, and cuts of the order envisaged would deter future mineral exploration and send many companies offshore.

This is what this government is doing to the minerals and mining industry in this country. It is encouraging the industry to go offshore because it is not doing anything to enhance this country's base knowledge, which is necessary for mineral and mining companies to undertake research and further exploration. The government is to be condemned for this. I will continue to pursue this issue because it is vitally important.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, you have already acknowledged that you misled the Senate yesterday in relation to the statutory seven‐day period for providing public notice of sales tax changes. Why did you also mislead the Senate when you stated, `The Treasurer's first announcement was an offer made to the states.' The press release issued by the Treasurer on 11 June commences:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has decided to remove the exemption from sales tax currently enjoyed by Commonwealth, State and Territory and Local Governments.
It continues later:
The removal of the wholesale sales tax exemption for general purpose road vehicles purchased or leased by Commonwealth, State and local governments is to have immediate effect.
Did you fail to read the Treasurer's press release, or was it just too difficult for you to understand? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone in Australia believes that I misled the Senate on the basis of the Treasurer's statement of 11 June. I tabled documents in this place this morning, including a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation, who admits that the advice conveyed to me yesterday in good faith by a senior officer of the Australian Taxation Office—which I, in good faith, presented to you, Senator Faulkner, at the conclusion of question time—was an opinion on which the taxation commissioner, Mr Carmody, who became aware of it after the event, took a different view.

ANSWER.PARA: In a situation like that, when there is a very legitimate difference of opinion within the Taxation Office between the senior officers who provided the advice which I provided to the Senate and the tax commissioner—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your comment about an offer?

—Do you want to hear the answer or not? In a case like that, the commissioner's advice obviously prevails. He has apologised to me, and I have apologised to the Senate that, as a result of the incorrect advice that his officers provided to me, I inadvertently misled the Senate yesterday. I have apologised for that. The commissioner has apologised for that. Indeed, the commissioner himself recognises that he has not met the provisions of section 130B of the sales tax act. We have come clean on that.

ANSWER.PARA: At the first available opportunity this morning I advised the Senate of the incorrect advice that had been given. I could not do any better than that. No reasonable person would expect me to do better than that. Your hypocrisy in throwing this up when, in government, time and time again you and your colleagues misled the Senate—I would have to say not inadvertently, more often than not—gives you little basis to make such shoddy allegations. As I say, and I repeat again: I have acknowledged the mistake I made yesterday. The commissioner has acknowledged the mistake he made yesterday. He has apologised, through me, to the Senate. There is nothing more that I can reasonably add or be expected to add on that point.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to Senator Short in my question that you, Senator Short, stated yesterday that `The Treasurer's first announcement was an offer made to the states.' I repeat: the press release issued by the Treasurer on 11 June says:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government has decided to remove the exemption from sales tax currently enjoyed by Commonwealth, State and Territory and Local Governments.
It continued:
The removal of the wholesale sales tax exemption for general purpose road vehicles purchased or leased by the Commonwealth, State and local governments is to have immediate effect.
Why did you mislead the Senate on that matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I want to make clear to the Senate at the very outset is that the whole reason that this matter has arisen in the first place is because the fiscal irresponsibility and incompetence of Labor in government in Canberra for 13 years led to the development of a massive hole in the government's books—an $8 billion black hole that is wholly and solely attributable to the Labor government. Everyone knows that. That was the basis for the discussions at the Premiers Conference.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased, and the government is pleased, that the Commonwealth, the states and the territories all took a mutually responsible attitude to this matter. The one group in the whole Australian community that is not prepared to be responsible in this matter in trying to recognise and heal the wounds the former Labor government made to the finances of this country is the now Labor opposition of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the minister's attention to the tax increases in New South Wales announced yesterday by Mr Michael Egan, the Treasurer, and attributed to the policies of the Commonwealth government. Can the minister inform the Senate of the government's response to the claims made by the New South Wales Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be clearly attributed to the previous Commonwealth government because this is part of the states' effort to meet a share of the burden we all face arising out of the Beazley black hole.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor scoffs, but it was Labor's inheritance. That is what you gave us. Labor gave us a forecast budget deficit of $8,000 million. This is after Labor assured us time and again that there would be no forecast deficit at all. Senator Cook in the Senate said, `Don't worry about it; it will be in surplus.' During the election, Mr Beazley said that it will be in surplus. Mr Keating said that it will be in surplus. When we said, `Open the books', they said no. Furthermore, they said that if you open the books, you would not see in any event; the results would not be there. But the day after the election, there they were. Labor hid it from the Australian people—$8,000 million of forecast deficit. That is what we inherited and now we have a responsibility to do something about it. We expected the states to take a part of that burden.

ANSWER.PARA: It was interesting that at the end of the day at the Premiers Conference the premiers basically said that they recognised their responsibility also. We all saw them on the television at the end of the day. They said that they recognised the problem that the new coalition government had inherited—the Beazley problem, the $8,000 million deficit—and that they would each have to play their part in filling that black hole.

What does the New South Wales Labor government do? It immediately reverts to type. When it has to find extra revenue, what does it do? Does it look at whether it can cut its expenditure? Of course not. It inflicts further taxation pain on the people of New South Wales.

Who should New South Wales voters hold responsible for this extra burden? It is Mr Beazley, the Minister for Finance at the time, the person with his finger on the financial pulse, the person responsible for the assurances that were given during the election that this deficit did not exist at all. That is who the New South Wales voters ought to be angry about in this instance.

It is just part of this ongoing legacy of financial incompetence that Labor continually demonstrates. We saw it with the last federal government. What did you do? Whenever you were in trouble, you either put up taxes or borrowed more.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, your government succeeded in doing both at once. You remember Mr Keating saying in the 1993 election that he would not put up taxes. In the subsequent period of government the increase in Commonwealth taxation rose by 30 per cent. What a big broken promise!

ANSWER.PARA: On the other hand, you also ran budget deficits for the same period of $40 billion. You put taxes up 30 per cent and still ran budget deficits of $40 billion. It is not surprising that many were sceptical about your assurance that there would not be further budget deficits. The reality was that there were—$8,000 million. We have to meet the responsibility of filling that Beazley black hole. We expect the states to do it and we regret the fact that the New South Wales Labor government is behaving exactly the way that the former Commonwealth Labor government behaved by putting up taxes and expecting the people to bear further pain.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. In your answer to Senator Wheelwright on Monday you stated:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The sales tax will apply to privately plated vehicles of employees of Commonwealth, state and local governments.
By way of contrast, the Treasurer's statement of 14 June said:
Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration . . .

Why did you mention the registration status of the motor vehicles, given that neither the Treasurer's press releases nor the Commissioner of Taxation's media releases mentioned these matters? What is the correct position? If you as a minister cannot understand the position, how can those in the motor trade possibly understand what is proposed?

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic principle which the Treasurer has espoused, which I have espoused and which I think everyone other than the opposition seems to understand, is that the new sales tax measures will apply to motor vehicles that are provided wholly or partly for private use as part of the remuneration of the employee. It is as clear and simple as that. It is no more complicated. I do not understand your continual lack of understanding of that. It has been made clear by all spokesmen for the government, it has been made clear by the Treasurer, it has been made clear by the Prime Minister and it has been made clear by me. You only have to read the clear print, and there you go.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. On Friday the Treasurer announced his changes to the tax structure, with the unprecedented qualification that further details will be announced as soon as possible. You claimed on Monday, in answer to Senator Wheelwright again, that the application of the tax is quite clear. You have claimed it again today. If it is quite clear, why is the government to announce further details? Why have the further details not been announced five days after the Treasurer's statement, unless they are very complex?
—You could not have got a clearer statement than that which the Treasurer made on Friday in his statement following the Premiers Conference. He said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments to take effect from 11th June.
Then he said, as you correctly say:
Further details will be announced as soon as possible.

On that point of 11 June, Senator Sherry, you will see from the taxation commissioner's press statement of yesterday, that I tabled here today, that he confirmed that 11 June is the operative date, as it has always been and been intended to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts concerns Telstra. Is the Minister aware of recent comments by the Leader of the Opposition regarding the impact of telecommunications privatisation on the local telecommunications equipment industry? Secondly, in particular, what light does the New Zealand experience throw on the matter? How has the New Zealand telecommunications equipment industry fared since 1984?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read an interview in the Weekend Australian , which resulted from what was described as an Australian-American leadership dialogue involving participants from both nations. One of those participating was Kim Beazley. One would have thought that with all his experience as a previous minister for communications, and as someone who professes to strut the world stage, he would have at least a basic understanding. I was absolutely appalled—and I am sure other senators will be as well—at what Mr Beazley had to say in this interview with Paul Kelly. He started off by saying:

ANSWER.PARA: I've got a view on Telstra which is distinct.
I can assure you that that is a masterful understatement. He said:
My view is that Telstra performs a function in Australia that there is no equivalent of in the United States.

I thought Telstra delivered telecommunications services and telephone calls. I would like to know what Mr Beazley was doing when he was in the US. Was he living in a tent? Was he communicating with his American colleagues by smoke signals or carrier pigeons? Was he simply not even aware that they have telephones in the United States? It is a pretty extraordinary start to an interview, I would have thought. Then he goes on to say:
Without Telstra . . . we have no investment in R&D.
There is no electronics industry in Australia without a publicly owned Telstra—
Telstra constitutes about 38 per cent of the electronics industry in Australia—
just as there is no electronics industry in New Zealand.

The fact is that New Zealand at the present time is going ahead in leaps and bounds. In 1990, its export of telecommunications equipment totalled $43 million. In the year to June 1996, its exports are expected to exceed $200 million and by the turn of the century $400 million. So to suggest that somehow the privatisation of Telstra New Zealand has led to the demise of the electronics industry is absolutely contrary to any possible understanding of the facts.

Mr Beazley trotted this sort of nonsense out at the ALP state conference in Victoria a few weeks back. I can perhaps understand him telling a few porkies to the party faithful. That is one thing, but to go onto the international stage and make a complete fool of himself, in the way that he did on this occasion, is very damaging to our international reputation.

These people are entitled to think that if you are attending a leadership forum you would at least show a bit of leadership. They did not expect some bloke to go over there, dragged by the ear by the trade union movement, pandering to fear and ignorance in Australia and somehow pretending that he has an understanding of what is going on in the country. He went on in that interview to say:
If you try to simultaneously privatise and introduce competition, you'll compromise one or the other.

The fact is that we introduced competition in this country five years ago. Do you know who the minister was at that time? Kim Beazley. I do not know what his defence is. Is he saying that he read the bill but did not look at the contents? Is he somehow not even aware of what has been going on in Australia in the last five years? Is he not aware that our electronics industry depends entirely on Telstra complying with licence requirements which obligate it to use best endeavours. That is precisely what will happen after Telstra is privatised.

This is a major international embarrassment for Australia. You blokes have some hard thinking to do if you think you can get away with a leader like this, who should never be allowed out of the country again until he has undergone a re‐education program. It is simply not good enough to go to the sub‐ branch of the Lenin institute for public ownership of everything that moves.

What he needs to do is talk to some people who have a real understanding. There is no point in him going to the Australian Democrats, but next time he goes overseas can I suggest that perhaps he might like to go via Romania. The deputy leader of the Romanian Democrats is in the Senate today. He was a former adviser on privatisation to the former Prime Minister of Romania. They commenced privatisation of the Romanian Telecom system some years ago. Perhaps Mr Beazley might learn a bit. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the Minister to statements by premiers and state treasurers indicating sharp increases in state taxes and charges as a consequence of the $2 billion shortfall in federal funding. In particular, I draw the minister's attention to New South Wales's proposals to increase payroll tax, car stamp duty and land tax; Victoria's proposal of a household levy and increased taxes on business; and Queensland's consideration of a rise in tobacco and alcohol tax. Does the minister concede that such increases will inevitably lead to an increase in inflation? What estimates, if any, have been prepared by or for the government on the inflationary impact of such measures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Schacht could have heard the earlier answer that was provided by Senator Hill to a similar question. The fact is that last Friday, 14 June, state and territory leaders reached a very cooperative agreement with the federal government on how to make their contribution to fill the huge hole that was left by your government when you left office in March—the $8 billion black hole for which your Leader of the Opposition was primarily responsible through his role as the Minister for Finance.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that that was a very welcome and worthwhile contribution made by the states. Any further action that is taken by the states in relation to their own finances, as Senator Hill has so rightly said, is entirely a matter for the state governments themselves. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the Commonwealth. It is up to the states to determine their priorities. They know that. All state governments know that. They have all been acting on their own priorities for many years now.

New South Wales has chosen, for whatever reason, to go down the route of increasing taxes and charges, just as Labor did after it won the last state election. It really lied its way to victory by one seat at the last state election by saying, `No, there aren't going to be tolls on roads—nothing like that.' What happened to the toll free project? The New South Wales Premier broke that promise immediately after the election. The actions that he has taken in that regard are in absolute full mode with what he has been doing since he won government. As far as any taxes imposed by the New South Wales government are concerned, those taxes should very correctly be labelled the `Beazley black hole taxes'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is very simple. At the end of my question I asked whether you have made an estimate of the inflationary impact of any of these new state charges that are being announced by the states.

—Senator Schacht's supplementary question shows a further abysmal lack of any understanding of how the economy works. The problem with Labor is that they do not appreciate that an $8 billion deficit in the federal government's budget leads to increased pressure on interest rates, fewer jobs, lower economic growth and lower living standards for all Australians. In the end, measures have to be taken to correct that situation. If you are not going to exercise fiscal responsibility in your budget, you going to compound the problems that we inherited from Labor opposite.
