We are not prepared to continue to sell future generations down the drain at great cost to all Australians, in the way that Labor did for 13 years.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I refer you to the summary paper that you released yesterday on the key provisions in the national heritage trust fund legislation. I refer in particular to the mention made of gifts and bequests being sought for the trust. Point 5 states that all interest earned from the trust, and, indeed, all the public donations to it, will be able to be spent on other environment and natural resource management projects, such as river care and endangered species. Firstly, given that conservation organisations depend very largely on gifts and bequests, are you now going into direct competition with organisations such as the ACF? Secondly, in your summary it appears that there will be no other source of funding, or little other sources of funding, for many of these projects, including endangered species. Is that the case? Will they now have to rely, either partly or totally, on charity to have a chance for survival? Are we moving to the days of lamington drives for the Leadbeater's possum and bingo nights for the bilby?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do find it amazing that, when the government puts before the parliament the potential for a $1 billion investment in the natural capital of Australia, the Democrats come in here and vote it down and then say that we are not seeking to appropriate enough money to the environment. Here they have the opportunity to support the largest reinvestment in Australia's natural capital in the history of this country, and they say no.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason that we want to do it is that funding from recurrent expenditure is never enough. That is the point, Senator Lees. I do not think you appreciate that. We do not think we can get enough money out of recurrent expenditure. Labor could not get enough money out of it. What it needs is a major reinvestment of capital. That is why we chose to sell part of one asset, a telecommunications company, and reinvest part of the capital of that into another project, our natural capital.

It is a sensible, rational policy to achieve the sorts of objectives that you seem to say you want to achieve but then vote down. It is extraordinary. If there is any logic in that, it might be apparent to you but it is not apparent to anybody else.

BREAK.PARA: Apart from that, yes, we said that we would obviously wish to continue recurrent programs. But those programs are struggling. Senator Faulkner will tell you that he had forecast for significantly lower expenditure in this coming year.

You will be aware—if you are not, the Greens are—that there are a whole series of programs under Labor's plans that were coming to an end at the end of this financial year. They are not easy to pay for. They require further funding. You are aware that we are also seeking to fill the Beazley black hole of $8,000 million.

There is continual pressure upon recurrent expenditure. We need a further major capital contribution to the environment to better achieve the conservation and environment outcomes that we would like to see, and which I would have thought you would like to see. So, instead of coming in here and moaning about recurrent expenditure difficulties, why not come in here and support our fund? Come on board and let us do some of these things that are necessary and in the best interests of our natural capital.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with interest the minister's comments about there never being enough. Even if this fund is set up, Minister, it will not have as much money as is available this year, from both the fund and your planned budget expenditure. You will be tens, if not, hundreds of millions of dollars worse off. So, presuming we set up the fund and, of course, fund it from the budget, what is going to happen to the administration of that fund? Is it correct that your department is going to have administrative control over only about 20 per cent of it? Is it the case that about 80 per cent of the money invested in that fund is going to be under the control of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so, but you will get full details of that in due course. You know as well as I do that, for example, money under the current Murray-Darling fund is administered through primary industry. You know that landcare money is contributed through primary industry. If you have read the structure for this fund, you will realise that there will be further money in both areas. What are you shaking your head for? There will be very substantial contribution to the Murray-Darling. One of the major needs of Australia's environment is to restore that river system.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it a even clearer if it is a trouble for the Democrats to understand. The promise was for approximately $1.15 billion to be expended over a period of five years to come through the fund. That would be made up of the major capital contribution of $1 billion, plus recurrent expenditure, plus interest earned. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to a statement made by the Prime Minister, and reported in yesterday's Australian , where he claimed that wage restraint would be justified because interest rates on home mortgages are coming down. Does this mean that the government will encourage wage claims if home mortgage rates go up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Cook is aware of what has been happening to home mortgage rates in this country. I am pleased to have this opportunity to inform him and the Senate of the fall in interest rates for housing that has occurred over recent weeks as a result of increased competition in the banking industry.

ANSWER.PARA: On 31 May, the Commonwealth Bank cut its variable home mortgage rate from 10.5 per cent to 9.9 per cent. ANZ followed suit shortly thereafter. The National Australia Bank did it also, as did the Commonwealth and Westpac by varying degrees. Almost 70 per cent of all home lending comes from those four banks. That means that the cuts in rates from 10½ per cent to 9¾per cent has led to a benefit of $53 per month for a household with a 25‐year $100,000 home loan. That is of major benefit to most Australian families.

It ought to be welcomed by the opposition. It is certainly very warmly welcomed by the government because it is in stark contrast with the interest rate record of the previous government over more recent years. The Labor government had home mortgage rates at 17 per cent in 1990 as part of its quite deliberate policy to engineer a massive recession—the greatest recession we have had since the 1960s.

That caused a whole range of problems through the economy, including pushing unemployment to rates that would never have been believed in this country—that is, above 11 per cent, above a million people unemployed. In terms of the movement in interest rates, they are unequivocally down, which is welcome news. So the premise on which your question is based has no substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I am entitled to ask, `Which bank,' but which government was it that actually introduced the competition that has created the reduction in home mortgage rates—yours or ours? More importantly, would you answer this question: if you slug battlers with tax, are they not able to claim it in wages; if you slug battlers with high interest rates, are they not able to claim it in wages? It has been claimed that if interest rates go down, they ought not make wage claims. So what do battlers do to protect their standard of living?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a couple of good questions there. So far as his first one is concerned—which government?—the origin of the increased competition in the banking industry, I remind Senator Cook, came from the Fraser government through the establishment of the Campbell committee which led to everything that was formed in the 1980s.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know they do not like to hear it but the Treasurer at the time who established the Campbell committee of inquiry, which led to the deregulation of the financial industry in Australia, was the now Prime Minister, John Howard. So that is pretty good news. For Senator Cook and those opposite to talk about tax increases when under their regime and their incompetence over the years before they went out of government they racked up tax increase after tax increase, and broke every tax promise they ever gave to maintain or reduce taxes, is the height of hypocrisy and deserves the answer it received.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the senators' guest gallery of the Deputy Leader of the Democratic Party of Romania, Mr Adrian Severin. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and hope that your visit to Australia is productive and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Newman. I refer the minister to answers her colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, made on 27 May 1996 concerning Aboriginal infant mortality rates. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The crude birthrate and the neonatal death rate are higher. The stillbirth rate is almost three times and the infant mortality rate about four times that of non‐Aboriginals. Nutritional deficiencies in infants under five years of age are also up.

Has the minister's attention been drawn to the announcement that funding for the Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni health project in Kalgoorlie ceases at the end of 1996? Why has the federal government withdrawn funding from the project without reviewing its progress? What steps has the minister taken to review the report of the Western Australian parliamentary committee's inquiry into the project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chamarette for her question. The federal government is committed to supporting effective primary health care initiatives in maternal and child health managed by community controlled health services. I myself have visited them and have a personal commitment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Ngunytju Tjitji Pirni project was established primarily as a research project securing the vast majority of its funds from an NHMRC research grant, although there were other sources of funding, I understand, available to them. I am advised that the federal government has not withdrawn funding. The office of the NHMRC has not received any reports to date from the organisation and has not received a submission for funding in 1996-97.

The Department of Health and Family Services has asked the NHMRC to send a copy of the final summary report and any other reports from the organisation to assist in assessment and negotiation of future funding needs of the service. The organisation also receives funding under the department's healthy women, strong families initiative, which commenced in the last financial year and which will be supported as a recurrent program from 1996-97 with funds provided by the Office for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services.

Finally, I am advised that the Department of Health and Family Services and the Western Australian Health Department have commenced discussions about outcomes of the project and arrangements for a joint review in July this year to determine ongoing funding and service delivery arrangements for the service. If I can just add on a personal note, having seen a number of these isolated communities myself and well understanding the need, I know that Minister Wooldridge has a personal commitment from the time that he spent as a doctor in an isolated Aboriginal community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Finance a question about the Auditor‐General. When in opposition, the coalition constantly argued for the Auditor‐General to be made a so‐called officer of the parliament. Now that the coalition is in government, does it intend to implement its longstanding policy? If so, when will the government take action to make this happen? What difference will it make to the audit office? Can the minister say exactly how this change would be made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coates raises what has been regarded here in the Senate and in the parliament generally as a very important issue for a long time. A lot of work has been done on it, particularly through the Public Accounts Committee. I know that Senator Coates and others—my colleague Senator Gibson in particular—have been following this matter very closely for many years.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of future arrangements in relation to the Auditor‐General, the potential legislative implementation of the recommendations from the Public Accounts Committee on the status of the Auditor‐General and a range of other issues associated with the audit office are under active consideration. I expect that decisions on those matters will be announced in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I get the impression from Senator Short that he does not actually know the answer to the question, but could he at least say whether it is still the policy of the coalition. Is the minister admitting that his party's policy is really a lot of rhetoric and that the government is just accepting the status quo and rejecting the idea altogether? Does the minister have any idea of what he and his colleagues meant by the term `officer of the parliament'?

—As I said to Senator Coates, decisions on this will be announced in the near future. I must say that the question comes pretty oddly from a party that had years to do something about it. You looked at this matter for years and you had neither the ability nor the wit to take the action that you are now asking us to take and on which, as I say, we will announce our decision. You were here for 13 years. You looked at all these things. You did not do a cracker to change the situation. I have to say that a question like that comes very oddly from your side of the Senate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, what is your response to a media release issued this week by the Independent member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson? What is your response to research by Ms Hanson of the benefits available to indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison for his question. Most importantly, I would like to make it very clear that I am disappointed with Ms Hanson's statements regarding financial assistance to Aboriginal Australians. She made the comment:

ANSWER.PARA: Why the financial burdens and hardships of families of comparable income differ due to Aboriginality is a mystery.

I would like to point out to Ms Hanson that, if she cares to look at the research available, Aboriginal Australians are far more disadvantaged than non‐Aboriginal Australians and therefore require greater assistance. Most disadvantaged groups in a democratic society are given some government assistance. That is not to say that we want to encourage welfare dependence. Most fair‐minded people in this country would acknowledge that indigenous Australians are living in appalling conditions and do require assistance.

Over the last three months I have visited many Aboriginal communities that have taken the initiative to try to improve their situation. Many participate in CDEP, a work for the dole scheme, when they would be better off financially by being on welfare. In the Northern Territory I was impressed by a strong women program started by local volunteers to combat domestic violence and reduce health problems. These are two examples of Aboriginal Australians helping themselves to improve their living conditions, but there are many more.

I would like to cite some research taken from the 1994‐95 ATSIC annual report which illustrates just how big the gulf is between Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal Australians. For example, in education, while indigenous participation levels are improving, the gap with non‐Aboriginal rates remains wide. I quote from the report that between 1985 and 1992 the retention rate to year 12 of Aboriginal students rose from 14 per cent to 25 per cent. Rates for other students in the same period, however, rose from 58 per cent to 78 per cent.

In the 1991 census, one in two Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds stated they had left school at age 16 or younger, compared with one in four non‐Aboriginal Australians in this age group. The 1991 census also showed that among 20‐ to 24‐year‐olds the proportion of Aboriginal Australians attending educational institutions was about one‐third of the non‐Aboriginal rate.

As Senator Chamarette mentioned earlier, maternal and infant mortality rates are higher for Aboriginal Australians, with Aboriginal mothers 10 times more likely to die than non‐Aboriginal mothers. At any age, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are twice as likely to die prematurely as non‐Aboriginal Australians. For Aboriginal people aged 25 to 44, the risk is five times greater. The list goes on and on in that regard.

In summary, I want to express again my disappointment over Ms Hanson's comments. She should stop and consider the hardship and disadvantage that many Aboriginal people face on a daily basis, often through no fault of their own.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I refer you to your answer on Monday to a question from Senator Conroy about the application of sales tax to red-plated vehicles. Can you explain to the Senate how a motor trader can possibly know before it is sold whether a motor vehicle will be used partly or wholly for private purposes. Will you guarantee that no small business will have to pay sales tax or penalties because of the uncertainty which continues to prevail due to your government's incompetence on this matter?

—I answered this question earlier today. I said, and I repeat—if the opposition needs it repeated yet again—that this wholesale sales tax will apply to general purpose road vehicles provided wholly or partly for private use as part of remuneration by Commonwealth, state, territory and local governments to take effect from 11 June. I also refer him to the sentence in the Treasurer's statement last Friday, to which he seemed to take exception earlier today, namely that further details will be announced as soon as possible. The point that he has now raised in his question is an important point. I fully accept that.
—Thank you very much.
—It is a pleasant change, I would have to say. It is an important point. It is a relevant question. It is one of those details that will be the subject of announcement in the very near future.

—I ask Senator Short: do you at least acknowledge that there is a lot of uncertainty out there amongst not only motor traders but also professional tax advisers? It is not true, as you claimed earlier in question time today, that everyone understands the changes. The Financial Review , for example, has carried a report about a partner in Arthur Andersen who has been deluged with calls from people who are confused about the changes. Do you at least accept that there is uncertainty and that that uncertainty is as a direct consequence of your government's bungled attempt at handling the Premiers Conference and your government's failure to provide details of these changes?

—I do not accept the assumption in the supplementary question that there is a lot of uncertainty out there. But what I do accept, and what the government and the Treasurer accept, is that there is a need for the final details to be announced, released and implemented as soon as possible, and that is precisely what the Treasurer announced last Friday. That is not long ago. It is five days ago. The final details will be announced very shortly, which, I agree with you, is necessary.
—You agree with me. You didn't agree with me a minute ago.
—I agreed with you. For once in my life I did agree with you because you asked a sensible question. I am telling you that the necessary details will be announced very shortly.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the minister responsible for customs. I refer to a report that shift work is to be cut back in the Australian Customs Service. I ask the minister: does he agree that these proposals ignore the fact that drug smugglers do not work nine to five? Is this measure directly related to the 295 positions the service is to lose as a result of cutbacks in the federal public service? Is this an example of the government's blind cost cutting across the public sector? Can the minister inform the Senate what assessments the government is making to ensure that essential services will continue to be delivered to the Australian community? And is the government prepared to table the results of these assessments in parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler will be surprised to know that the minister does not agree with the proposition—a rather absurd proposition—that any changes to shifts in customs ignores the fact that drug smugglers do not work from nine to five. Frankly, Senator Spindler, your question ignores the very fact that customs work involves a whole lot of risk assessment of the likelihood of the importation of prohibited substances and the like.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, your question ignores the fact that, when planes land at Sydney before 8 a.m. and after 5 p.m., there are customs officers on duty to perform their very important role. I might say that Mr Toohey and others are ignoring the fine work done by the Customs Service and are seeking to take cheap shots without fully acquainting themselves with or acknowledging the way in which customs actually operates. There were four questions asked. That is the response to the first question. The answers to questions two, three and four are no, no and no.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder how the minister can reconcile government accountability to provide essential services with the three noes that he has provided, particularly to the last two, which ask: is the government going to make any assessments as to the effect of the cuts in the Public Service and is it prepared to table the assessments in parliament? Or is the government simply shirking all responsibility?
—Mr President, I have already answered the question. I will take the supplementary question on notice and refer it to the minister. If he has any more to add, I will come back to Senator Spindler.

—I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, why has the agreement between the Department of Finance and the Senate, regarding the funding of Senate committees, been rescinded by an officer of the Department of Finance rather than by the minister? Why has the Minister for Finance requested a joint submission from the five parliamentary departments when the coalition vigorously opposed the amalgamation of parliamentary departments on the principle of immutable division of responsibilities? Finally, do the recommendations of the Department of Finance mean that there is no funding at all in the next financial year for the two latest select committees: one on the uranium mining industry and the second on the Victorian casino inquiry?

—I am not aware that an officer of the Department of Finance has issued that notification to the Senate. I will take that on notice. I will seek the advice of the Minister for Finance. So far as the financing of the Senate and parliamentary departments, including committees, for the year ahead is concerned, that will be announced in the budget.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Whilst not alleging that the crackdown on Senate funding is for political censorship for you to look after your mates, isn't it now a great coincidence that you are taking a million dollars out of the Senate committee system and it is going to impact on the two inquiries that you never really ever wanted to go ahead?

—I have nothing to add to what I already said to Senator Ray other than to say that, if you ever wanted to see an attempt at sheer blatant political manipulation of the Senate for narrow party political ends, you would only have to look as far as the two inquiries to which Senator Ray referred.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator CRICHTON‐BROWNE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I apologise that I have not given him prior notice, so I will understand if he is not equip ped to answer the question immediately. I refer the minister to the admission by Mr Ian Viner QC that he sought and improperly obtained an unprocessed court document from the Ministry of Justice in WA and that he provided that and other equally unlawfully obtained documents to Mr Eoin Cameron MP, who then had them photocopied and widely distributed immediately prior to my preselection.

QUESTION.PARA: I remind the minister that the clerk who provided the documents has been convicted, demoted and transferred from the Department of Justice. I further remind the minister that the improperly obtained documents related to the private affairs of my wife. I further remind the minister that Mr Ian Viner QC obtained knowledge of the document through his client-lawyer relationship with my wife. Given that Mr Viner has demonstrated a reckless disregard for ethics, confidentiality and common decency, I ask the minister: if Mr Viner cannot keep white women's secrets, how can he possibly be expected, as a member of the National Native Title Tribunal, to keep black women's secrets? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am not sure that this is in the minister's area of responsibility, but I will leave it to the minister as to whether he wants to answer it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to reply to that, Mr President. I think that properly is a question that should be addressed to the Minister for Justice, and I will refer it to the Attorney-General.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the Australian Taxation Office's announcement recently that taxpayers would not be penalised for honest mistakes that they make in preparing their tax returns using the Tax Pack . In view of this commitment by an arm of the Treasury department for which you have responsibility, Minister, can you explain why the tax office does, in fact, intend to charge interest in circumstances of honest taxpayer error in using the Tax Pack ? Can you also explain what the rate of interest will be and what the anticipated level of revenue being raised by charging this interest will be? Can you also explain what action will be deemed to be an honest mistake and who will make that judgment?

—As I would expect Senator Bolkus would know, the administration of the tax laws are by statute the responsibility of the Australian Taxation Commissioner. Mr Carmody has the statutory responsibility for administering the laws, and that includes the points that have been raised by Senator Bolkus in his question to me. I will refer his question—
—This has got widespread publicity. Why don't you know?
—You have asked me a specific question. I will refer Senator Bolkus's question to the commissioner, who has the responsibility in these areas, and provide you with his response.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Is public housing threatened, as claimed in a letter to the editor in the Australian today by Stephen Nash from the Inner Urban Regional Housing Council of Victoria? Will the government's plans for housing reform devastate our community, and will the changes mean a decrease in public housing funding in real terms? Does the minister agree with Mr Nash that if low income households are banished from inner urban public housing, they will remain in a poverty trap?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention was drawn to the article. I find it quite strange how close some members in this chamber are to the views that Mr Nash was propounding. But it is really rather sad, because Mr Nash's group has not been one of the many groups with whom I have consulted over the government's proposed changes to housing.

ANSWER.PARA: As you would remember, Mr President, there were not too many members of the opposition who wanted to listen to the long list of women's organisations with whom I had consulted on women's issues. Perhaps they might be interested to know that I have met with ACOSS, the National Shelter, the Community Housing Federation of Australia, the National Community Housing Forum, the Housing Industry Association, and the list goes on. Unfortunately, perhaps due to my newness in the portfolio, I was not aware of Mr Nash, but I would be very happy to see him if he would like to make an appointment.

The interesting thing is that housing and community groups did not express concerns about these proposals when they were announced last year by the previous government. Their response to our proposals this year has been positive as well, because they are very positive for tenants whether they are in the private sector or the public sector. It is going to mean flexibility for people as to where they live. It is going to mean a reduction in the waiting lists of people in public housing, because the 200,000 people who are currently waiting for a home will be given a higher level of financial subsidy. If they want to rent in the private sector, then they are able to at the moment. They have an opportunity to live near where they can find work or where they have family support, et cetera.

There is a huge discrepancy at the present time in the assistance that goes to renters in the private sector and the renters in the public sector. For example, at the moment the average Commonwealth rent assistance for those in private accommodation is around $1,500 a year. But, if you live in public housing, you receive an average annual subsidy of $4,000 a year from the state housing authorities.

People renting from the private sector are the people who are paying high rents. They are the most disadvantaged members in our community. It is important and imperative that we give them more equity and justice. Far from being caught in poverty traps, as they are now, these people are going to be able to exercise real choice because the money will be in their hands for them to be make a choice between public and private. They are not going to be banished to the outer rim of the city. They are going to be able to make a choice to live where their support network or their job opportunities are. They will do that because they have a higher level of rent assistance if they choose to rent privately.

Mr Nash also claims that rental subsidies are the most expensive form of housing assistance. I say to him that maintenance of ageing housing stock is the most expensive form of housing assistance you can give. For the state housing authorities, which have been slipping further and further behind in many states in the maintenance of their housing stock, housing assistance will give them an opportunity to get better rents for their housing. That will mean they are going to be able to keep those houses in a better state of repair. Also, the private rental market will get a boost and so will the construction industry. It seems to me, whether you are in the private or the public sector, whether you are a state or in private enterprise in the building industry, there is a win‐win for all. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 23 May Senator Bolkus asked me a question in relation to the Australian Federal Police special reference branch and Senator Ray subsequently asked a question with respect to the practice that any investigation into a federal politician is notified to the Attorney‐General. I seek leave to incorporate the answers from both ministers in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—
Senator Bolkus asked me the following question without notice on 23 May 1996:

1. I ask the Minister whether she can confirm that the Australian Federal Police Special Reference Branch is investigating possible fraudulent activities by a South Australian Senator? Further, can the Minister guarantee, given Senator Chapman's views as expressed in this Chamber over the past few years, that this investigation will be free of political interference?
Further, on 23 May 1996 Senator Ray asked me the following supplementary question:

2. Would the Minister confirm the longstanding practice that any investigation into a Federal politician by the Australian Federal Police would be notified to the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, Mr Williams?
The Attorney‐General has provided me with the following answers:

. The Australian Federal Police, as part of its responsibility to investigate offences against the Commonwealth, at times receive allegations that prominent persons, including Members of Parliament, are or have been involved in criminal activities.
. In accordance with longstanding practice the AFP advises its Minister of the allegations.

. Once an investigation has commenced it is the practice not to comment publicly or indeed confirm or deny an investigation is under way. There are sound and proper operational and privacy considerations which make this approach essential.

. It is a fact of public life that prominent persons at times are the subject of allegations that they have been involved in what could be termed criminal activities. The AFP where these matters relate to offences against the Commonwealth or are against Commonwealth interests investigates the allegations fully.
. Frequently such allegations are found to lack substantiation and are sometimes malicious in their intent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 June Senator Lundy asked me a question which contained several parts and I undertook to get some additional information for her. I have that information now seek leave to have it incorporated.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles
Questions directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short by Senator Lundy (Senate, Monday, 17 June 1996)
1. Given that sales tax will apply to privately plated vehicles controlled by the federal government, can the minister inform the Senate:
. How many such vehicles will be affected?;
. What revenue will be raised?;
. Will departments be supplemented as they were for fringe benefits tax?; and
. What will be the administrative cost of removing this exemption?
Responses:

Of the 50,000 or so vehicles in the Commonwealth sector, about half have already been purchased with sales tax paid. The exemption from sales tax on purchases by Commonwealth trading enterprises such as Telstra and Australia Post was removed in May 1987. This included their exemption on cars.

DASFLEET manages a fleet of about eighteen thousand vehicles. Of these, only about two and a half thousand are provided for private use as part of remuneration and therefore will be affected by the Government's announcement. Based on this estimate, and assuming that some 60% of these vehicles are replaced annually, about $10 million is expected to be raised from this measure.

Based on the best information currently available, the preliminary estimate of the impact of the measure across the whole of the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local government sector is in the order of $50 million to $100 million. This compares with the revenue estimates reported in the press, which are in the order of $80 million to $100 million.
The extent to which Commonwealth Departments and agencies will be supplemented for this additional cost is a matter for consideration in the context of the forthcoming Budget.

The administrative cost of removing the measure is not considered to be significant. There will be some reduction in the administrative costs of motor vehicle dealers as fewer exemptions will be claimed and there will be a corresponding reduction in the paper work they need to process. For Government bodies there will be some increase in administrative costs as particular bodies assess which vehicles they are entitled to purchase free of tax. In many cases this assessment will be straightforward. In others, it may be necessary to consider the purpose for which the vehicle is being purchased whereas previously all vehicles were purchased free of tax.
2. Further on the issue of the exemptions:
Response:
. Minister, can you guarantee that the exemptions administered by your department will continue to apply to TPI pensioners?
TPI pensioners will retain their existing entitlement to sales tax exemptions on the purchase of motor vehicles.

That is, those pensioners (for example veterans in receipt of a special rate of pension as a result of being totally and permanently incapacitated from war‐caused injury or disease) will continue to be eligible to apply for motor vehicle sales tax exemption under sub‐item 96(1) in Schedule 1 to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992 as before.

The very day that Mr Titelius, a known political opponent of mine, the clerk in question, ejected Mr Gaspar from Mr Cameron's office, as he had Mr Nick Nolan, a close personal friend of Mr Cameron's also—that very same day—he provided the order to Mr Viner.

And that very morning, because my wife had learnt of Mr Viner disclosing private conversations, she rang him, and, on my advice, she wrote down verbatim down what he said, and what she said. And she said, `Ian, have you betrayed my trust in you as a lawyer'? And he procrastinated and she asked him the question again, and he said, `No, I have not'. Within one hour of that conversation, Mr Viner QC, on the National Native Title Committee—that's why I raise the question—went down to the court and convinced this clerk—I must say it wasn't too much to convice him—to give him the document.

PARA.BREAK: The legal practitioners complaints committee thus far has sought to draw a distinction between the fact that Mr Viner, when consulted by my wife, referred her to somebody else. To me that is analogous to a woman going to a GP, being referred to a gynaecolo gist and then the GP going around and discussing the private and intimate details of the health of the patient who went to see him. In some quaint, curious way the legal practitioners board thus far—they will find themselves in court as a result of it if they do not review their position—drew that distinction. Can you honestly believe that that is the distinction that they drew?

ANSWER.PARA: Let me read very quickly from the transcript of the appeal that poor old Mr Titelius put in. Talking about Mr Viner, he said he did not have an emotional interest in it because as he was requesting the order, he told me details about the incident, not the whole incident, but he was familiar with what had gone on. He said:
I wasn't telling him something that he didn't know already.
In other words, he was going down there using his prior knowledge. He said:
I gave him the order and he went off, and that was the last I—I also said, because Ian Viner was sort of like a third party—
that means, by definition under the act, an interested party—
to take into account the needs of Esther Crichton-Browne—because although it was a public record—
which, of course, he knew it was not—
just to be sensitive to her needs and be very careful with how you use the document. Then Ian Viner said, "I will use this document with the utmost discretion".

He then gave it to Mr Cameron's son, who then took it back to Mr Cameron's office which then photocopied it in hundreds in coloured paper and distributed it like confetti around the place, including to members of this chamber. It was distributed widely, together with a filthy, disgusting, diabolical, criminally defamatory dirt sheet as well. There are two copies that I know of. One was sent to Senator Bob Collins, which he had the decency to return to me, without even reading it, I believe. The President of the Senate showed the integrity for which I respect him by also sending his copy back to me as well. Mr Viner said:
I will use this document with the utmost discretion.

That tells you where we are. Except Mr Viner did say, curiously, that he wanted this information because my preselection was coming up. This is something that happened six years previously, which he knew of from my wife. He said, `I just want it in case it comes up at his preselection.' Why would it come up in my preselection if it was not for the fact that a dirty, filthy, grubby sheet was distributed using a database provided by at least one senator in this chamber and then produced by Mr Viner and Mr Cameron like confetti around the place?

That is not the sort of standard I would expect of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party. The Prime Minister at the time, Mr Keating, said on 6PR radio that he was disgusted. He thought it was filthy and it is not the sort of thing he would condone, but he would rather condemn. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

INTERJECT.PARA: Report No. 29 of 1995‐96—Performance Audit—Management of the Commercial Estate—Australian Estate Management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report contains some quite significant implications for the government and for potential expenditure on government buildings. It raises some serious problems that have been left over from the previous government—multimillion dollar problems. Section 9 of this report, dealing with valuations of office estates, shows the consequences of the changed arrangements—and I might say sensibly changed arrangements—under which Commonwealth departments will no longer necessarily be tied to occupancy of what might well be inappropriate government owned offices. They will have the opportunity, basically, to get the best, and in many instances the cheapest, option, which may well not be the occupancy of a government owned building.

During the course of the audit by the Auditor-General into the management of the commercial estate, it was observed by the Auditor-General that the Australian Valuation Office, acting under instructions from Australian Estate Management, had revised the 1994 valuations for the government's 20 most valuable properties. The 1995 change to the 1994 valuation basis required that valuers not assume indefinite Commonwealth tenancy as they had done in 1994 but value the properties on the basis of specific tenancy commitments. On this basis an open market value which reflects net realisable value is determined.

As a result of this, there has been a massive write‐down in the value of Commonwealth properties, particularly in Canberra. Some of these involve write‐downs of well over $20 million per building. For example, the administrative building in Parkes was valued in 1994 at $53 million. Its current valuation is down by $25 million to only $28 million. We have the Campbell Park offices at Pialligo down from $67 million to $42.6 million—a $24 million cut. The Edmund Barton building in Barton is down by $11 million. The Benjamin Offices in Belconnen are down by $15 million. The Cameron Offices in Belconnen are down from a value of $65 million to only $39 million—a $26 million cut. The Jessie Street Centre in the CBD of Sydney is down by $13 million to $112 million. Casselden Place in Melbourne, which has been the subject of some controversy in recent times, is down from a valuation of $123.8 million to $103.9 million—down about $20 million.

Substantial write‐downs, not of the same dollar amount but certainly very large percentage amounts, have occurred in other buildings. For example, the George Knowles building in Barton is down from a valuation of $3.35 million in 1994 to only $700,000 as at 30 June 1995—almost an 80 per cent reduction in value. These reductions in values are obviously of some significance. I commend the Auditor-General for revealing them.

The technique in valuation also incorporates a forecast of capital requirements associated with the asset as part of the valuation process. There are very substantial capital expenditures to come, as revealed in this audit report. As the audit report states:

The 1995 review of the annual valuation of the properties highlighted a significantly lower valuation, which reflected the lack of executed tenancy agreements, and also the significant capital needs in the ACT property portfolio. The ACT values reflect a building portfolio that features many old buildings needing extensive refurbishment. In addition, valuations in a number of regions were recalculated on the basis of month by month tenancies being in place rather than a long-term tenancy agreement. This depresses property values until fixed‐term tenancy agreements are in place.

The Auditor‐General says that the completion of core occupancy agreements and further occupancy agreements is essential—and I underline that word—to ensure the improved certainty in the valuation process.

So the present government has certainly inherited some serious problems. In terms of the capital expenditure required on these buildings over the next five years, the audit report reveals that forecasted capital requirements over the next five years are `substantial'. There had been an existing capital funding requirement over this period totalling $308 million and a forecast need for additional capital amounting to $540 million after taking into account offsets and property sales proceeds. That makes a total for capital requirements of $848 million on government owned properties over the next five years.

BREAK.PARA: This government has to find the money from somewhere. It has inherited another problem. The additional capital funding of up to $194 million will also be required to meet the forecasted shortfall in funds required to meet the Commonwealth's liability at the end of 2008 in concluding a major finance lease, which is a very complicated one that is outlined later on in this audit report.

There is no doubt that these very expensive property commitments do raise interesting questions about how best the government's property should be handled. In fact, it raises a significant question as to whether the government really has no requirement to hold properties of this kind, whether it in fact might not be better off disposing of them so that it does not end up with the sorts of massive writing‐down of property values and massive capital commitments that are revealed in this audit report. I commend the audit report to the Senate.

CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1996

The Customs Amendment Bill 1996 introduces changes to Part XVA of the Customs Act 1901 in relation to the Tariff Concession System and to by‐laws and determinations relating to certain Policy By‐laws under sections 271 and 273 of the act.
THE TARIFF CONCESSION SYSTEM

The changes to the Tariff Concession System stem from an evaluation conducted in 1995 which found that while the System was making concessions readily available to importers, Australian manufacturers were being adversely affected by its operation. It concluded that Tariff Concession Orders should only be made where there is no Australian manufacturer of goods substitutable for those imported.
This position was accepted by the former government, and the Tariff Concession System changes in this bill are essentially as they were announced last year.

The purpose of these changes is to more closely align the operation of the System with its aim to make concessional entry readily available without adversely affecting the tariff assistance given to Australian manufacturers.
I will now outline the amendments contained in this bill in more detail.

The most important change is the removal of the significant adverse effect clause, the so-called market test, from the core criteria. This occurs in item 4 on page 4 of the bill. In practice, the existence of the market test has meant that Tariff Concession Orders have been granted to the detriment of Australian manufacturers, contrary to the stated intention of the System. It is, in any case, very difficult for an Australian manufacturer to prove prospectively that the market for its good will be adversely affected by the duty free importation of a substitutable good.
In 1991, when the Industry Commission reviewed the predecessor of the current System, the Commercial Tariff Concession System, it recommended against the inclusion of a market test.

Once the market test has been removed, the remaining core criterion will be the substitutability test. The Australian Customs Service will not grant a Tariff Concession Order where it is satisfied that substitutable goods are produced in Australia. A concession will therefore only be made where there is no Australian manufacture of goods substitutable for those which are the subject of the tariff concession application.

The definition of "substitutable goods" is also qualified in item 3 on pages 3 and 4 of the bill to ensure that a de facto market test cannot be implied into this remaining provision. Without this change, the benefits of removing the market test are unlikely to be achieved.

The system to date has placed a considerable burden on Australian manufacturers to prove that they produce substitutable goods and that the importation of goods under the Tariff Concession Order would cause significant adverse effect to them. In future, the onus for demonstrating that there are no substitutable goods produced in Australia will rest, in the first instance, with the applicant for the Tariff Concession Order.

It will be the responsibility of the tariff concession order applicant to research the existence or otherwise of Australian manufacturers of substitutable goods prior to lodgement of the application with Customs. If the application does not adequately establish that the research has been done, Customs will reject it as not meeting the requirements of the legislation. This appears in items 7 and 8 on page 5 of the bill.

The application will also have to provide the name of the importer seeking the concession. The importer's broker or agent's name only will not suffice. These details will also be Gazetted, consistent with the requirement already in existence to notify applicants of the names of Australian manufacturers claiming they produce substitutable goods. Item 9 on pages 5 and 6 of the bill refers.

It is important that in processing applications, Customs be able to utilise the considerable knowledge of bodies such as industry associations and other prescribed organisations in determining whether substitutable goods are produced in Australia. The information contained on the application form will therefore be made available to such organisations for this purpose. Item 12 on page 7 of the bill refers.

The time allowed for applicants to propose amendments to their application will be extended from 14 days to 28 days in item 10 on page 6 of the bill. Such amendments will, however, be limited to narrowing the description of the goods within the tariff classification cited in the application. The amended wording will be Gazetted, with objections allowed for up to 14 days after gazettal. If, however, Customs is not satisfied that the amended wording meets the requirements, the proposal will not be accepted and the application will be processed with its original wording as if no amendment had been suggested.

The present legislation requires the Attorney‐General's Department to provide advice on the correct tariff classification in case of error. However, in recognition that Customs is the expert agency in the area of tariff classification, Customs, rather than the Attorney‐General's Department, will in future determine the correct tariff classification. This is accommodated in items 13 and 26 on pages 7 and 9 of the bill.

I turn now to the date on which a Tariff Concession Order becomes effective. The present legislation allows the commencement date of a tariff concession to be backdated to 28 days before the lodgement of the application. This is a carryover of a provision in the Commercial Tariff Concession System which was terminated in 1992. There is now no rationale for backdating Tariff Concession Orders, and items 16 to 23 on page 8 effectively remove this. Making orders operative from the date of lodgement of applications should encourage importers to lodge applications earlier.

This bill will also enable Customs to commence revocation action for Tariff Concession Orders where there are Australian manufacturers of substitutable goods, and where the orders have not been used for at least two years; that is, they are obsolete. Revocation of Commercial Tariff Concession Orders will also be considered under the new Tariff Concession System criteria. Items 24 and 25 on pages 8 and 9 give effect to this change.

The definition of "made to order capital equipment" will be amended to allow concessions only for equipment made on a one‐off basis to meet a specific order rather than being the subject of regular or intermittent production, and to exclude goods made as a result of production runs.

Customs decisions with respect to the Tariff Concession System will remain subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. However, amendments in item 31 on page 10 of the bill will limit persons who have standing to appeal to the AAT to those directly involved in the decision (that is, the applicant and those who have lodged submissions with Customs). Customs will be required to Gazette any application to the AAT. A person wishing to be joined as a party to the AAT proceedings must apply to the AAT within 60 days of the Gazettal notice or satisfy the AAT that they were not reasonably able to apply within the 60 day period.

Any document on which a party intends to rely at the AAT hearing must be filed with the AAT and served on the other parties not less than 28 days before the date set for hearing unless the AAT otherwise orders. In considering whether to make such an order, the AAT will consider whether there was a reasonable cause for the material not being available 28 days before the hearing.
These changes should ensure that the external review process is not subject to unreasonable delay and excessive costs.

The proposed changes will also ensure in items 32 and 33 on pages 11 and 12 of the bill that tariff concession orders remain generally available by requiring the description of the goods for which the Tariff Concession Order is to apply to be generic. Where either directly or by implication an application is for goods of a particular brand name, model, or part number, that application will now be rejected.
I turn now to transitional arrangements for the Tariff Concession System which are covered in detail in Part 2 of Schedule 1 of the bill.

All applications lodged with Customs but which have not been decided on the day these changes come into effect will be decided under the present legislation, that is, the legislation in force before these amendments come into effect.

However, if the application is for goods which are substitutable for goods manufactured in Australia and the application is successful because of the operation of the market test, the Tariff Concession Order will be valid only up to the day that these amendments come into force. This appears in item 37 of page 13 of the bill.

Decisions referred to Customs for Internal Review or to the AAT or which are on appeal to the Federal or High Court in relation to applications for orders lodged before the commencement of these amendments, are to again be decided under the present legislation. Any orders made, however, where the market test results in a tariff concession order being granted will be taken to have been revoked from the date the changes come into effect.
I turn now to changes to the Policy By‐law System.
THE POLICY BY‐LAW SYSTEM
The Policy By‐law System are those concessions which apply to items 43, 45, 46, 47, 52, 55, 56, 57, and 60 of Schedule 4 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995.
The government announced its reforms to the Policy By‐law System in a press release on 8 May 1996. The changes will revamp and streamline the administration of the Policy By‐law System.

Concessions under items 43 and 52 will be restricted to concessional entry for the split consignment of whole goods unable to be transported on a single vessel or aircraft because of the size of the good or because of an inadvertent delay in shipment.

Consistent with past practice, the Chief Executive Officer of Customs will publish guidelines in the form of an Australian Customs Notice, setting out new guidelines for persons wishing to seek concessions under these by‐laws.

The guidelines will implement the reforms announced by the government on 8 May 1996, including the provision of concessions under items 45, 46 and 56 for projects with a capital equipment value of more than $10 million.

Accordingly, concessions under items 43, 45, 46, 52 and 56 of Schedule 4 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 will be revoked on the day this bill comes into force. This appears in item 42 on pages 19 and 20 of the bill.
Any request for a concession under these items which has not been finalised on the day this bill comes into effect will be considered under the new guidelines.
Transition provisions in item 43 on pages 20 and 21 of this bill will preserve access to a revoked policy by‐law concession for these 5 items provided:
1) Goods which have been imported on or before the date of revocation, are entered within 28 days of the date of the revocation of the Policy By‐law; or
2) Goods on direct shipment to australia before the date of revocation of the Policy By‐law provided they are entered within 28 days of importation; or

3) In relation to goods which are made to order capital equipment (as defined for the Tariff Concession System and amended by this legislation), provided such goods are imported and entered under one of these Policy By‐law items until 15 February 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1), 1996 proposes tariff rate changes consequential on the substantial administrative and legislative reforms to both the Tariff Concession System and the Policy By‐law system contained in the previously referred to bill, the Customs Amendment Bill 1996.

This tariff bill introduces changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to amend from free to 3 per cent the concessional duty rate applying to Tariff Concession Orders under Part XVA of the Customs Act 1901 (item 19 and item 50 of Schedule 4 to the Act) and to Policy By‐law items 47, 55, 57 and 60 of Schedule 4 of the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I thank all those who participated in the debate—Senator Cook, Senator Spindler, Senator Evans, Senator Cooney, Senator Margetts and Senator Schacht. I would like to respond by making some remarks about issues raised by senators in that second reading debate.

BREAK.PARA: Firstly, Senator Cook raised concerns expressed by industry to the Senate committee on the potential for the bill to lead to increased red tape. The government certainly does not intend this to be the case. The Senate noted Austrade, the agency responsible for the administration of the EMDG, is working with industry to ensure that this will not be the case. For example, the draft 10‐page document, which the senator referred to, would replace similar existing paperwork, which was actually nine pages, rather than be a big piece of additional paperwork.

Secondly, both Senator Spindler and Senator Margetts made comments on the grants entry test. I would like to make the following points with regard to that. Regarding some of Senator Spindler's concerns, Austrade operates an efficient counselling and referral system for exporters. The grants entry test and the registration will enhance Austrade's ability to provide these services and give Austrade a greater opportunity to support the export development of Australian companies. All grants applicants have access to those services.

Thirdly, this test does not alter the fundamental open access nature of the scheme. The general principles that anyone can apply, that the number of grants are not limited and that every claimant who meets the eligibility criteria receives a grant still apply. The bill will not enable Austrade as administrators to specify or limit the number of grants to be made. Decisions about whether claimants pass the test may be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Austrade is actually projecting an increase in the number of first time claimants who will receive a grant next year. Also, Senator Cook suggested that this government has not consulted with industry. I bring it to the attention of the chamber that both the previous government and Austrade consulted extensively on this bill, which has been in circulation for over 12 months.

Finally, as noted by senators, the test itself may be disallowed by the parliament if it considers it to be inappropriate. Austrade will be developing clear and appealable rules for the tests, and this will be done in consultation with industry. As senators noted, discretion will be required to ensure that companies, particularly the SMEs, are not disadvantaged by rules which cannot take account of individual industry needs. The government does not agree to the opposition's amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

—by leave—If Senator Spindler were to indicate that he was prepared to proceed with the committee stage, that might give us time to get organised. If Senator Spindler is not ready or has nothing to contribute, I am at a loss.

—by leave—I understand that there is some confusion about coming back to the Export Market Development Grant Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. It was agreed last night—the opposition whip will confirm this—that the bill would come back on—
—At a later hour.
—Yes, it was agreed last night that we would have second reading debate this morning which would be postponed to a later hour of the day.
—We didn't know when that was going to be.

—I said it would be after question time. I asked if there were any questions about that. There were none, so I presumed that the arrangement would go ahead. If there is a problem now, I would like to know about it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade, Senator Brownhill. My first question relates to the fact that at the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee's first hearing I asked Senator Brownhill a question which he may have passed on to Mr Oliver, representing Austrade, and answered by Mr Oliver at the time. That question related to the cost of administering the claims for EMDG.

BREAK.PARA: The source of my inquiry was the written submission lodged with the Senate committee by the Tourism Commission. I do not have to hand the document that the Tourism Commission provided me—I cannot find it among my papers at the moment—but the question, as I recall, cited this passage from the Tourism Council of Australia's submission:

In relation to the administrative costs, the Tourism Commission finds it alarming that these have increased significantly—that is, around 130 per cent over the last three years from $3.3 million in 1993‐94 to $7.6 million in 1995‐96.

As I understand Mr Oliver's reply to my question seeking verification of the increase in administrative costs, he was not able to confirm the figures that the Tourism Council gave. I have gone back and checked with the Tourism Council and I am advised that those figures were given to a Senate estimates committee in August last year when the Department of Trade's estimates were before it.

My question now is: can the parliamentary secretary confirm that increase in administrative costs? If that is not the figure, can he tell us what the figure is? Given the extra responsibility placed on Austrade by the requirement of the export ready test that this legislation confers, has the government undertaken any estimate of what additional cost there will be in administering these claims?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —To the best of my knowledge, the figures given at the hearing are correct. I cannot see any reason for them not being so. With regard to the administering of the grants entry test for first time claimants—I have already made the point in my reply to the debate—there has not been a great increase in the number of pages as far as the grants entry test requirements are concerned. I would not envisage that there would be any increase in costs, to the best of my belief and knowledge. I will definitely get a comment from my advisers on that. That is the way it is. There would be no increase at all for claimants, and Austrade would get approximately $2 million per year to administer the scheme.
—In view of that answer—I want to be clear about this; I am not being difficult—I just want to get what you are confirming clear for me.
—I will help you, too, Senator.

—We are talking about big figures here. Are you saying that what the Tourism Council said is true—that is, that there has been around a 130 per cent increase in costs from $3.3 million in 1993‐94 to $7.6 million in 1995‐96? Is that, in fact, true? Is that what you are saying?
—I do not know whether I could add a lot more to what I have already said, Senator. I think I have answered as best I can. I do not think I can add anything further to what I have already said.
—Well then, what did you say? When you said yes, you think those figures are right, is that what you meant?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —(4.16 p.m.)—If you look at the previous figures, there was an increase in staffing levels, so that would account for those figures that the tourism association were talking about. There was a growth in claim numbers. There was the introduction of new markets and the six‐monthly claim provisions. In the previous scheme there was an increased complexity of claims related to the companies test and also the introduction of tourism. There were 21 staff involved in the implementation in 1994 of the ANAO review recommendations, and $1.58 million was provided in 1995‐96. There was also a growth in the AAT cases. Does that help you with those figures that you asked for? Does that explain it a bit better?

—What it explains is why there would be a cost blow-out. The Tourism Council have said to me that they got the figures they included in their written submission from evidence adduced at a Senate estimates hearing on the EMDG scheme last August. There is nothing tricky in this, but can you advise me, from the best knowledge that you have, that those figures are verified? As I say, I just want some indication. If they are not verified by you because you do not have the information in front of you now, will you undertake to the Senate to provide that information to us?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be able to help a bit, and I am sorry if I have not been as succinct in answering as I could have been. I hope I have been, but to get it a little bit clearer for you, the projected cost for 1995-96 is below $7.6 million, and 1995-96 is not concluded yet because we have got a few weeks to go until the end of the financial year.

—I assume, therefore, that three years previous to the 1995‐96 figure of almost $7.6, which you have just acknowledged, the tourist authority was right in saying that it was $3.3 million. Over the three‐year time span it has gone up by that amount. The question that I want to ask now is—
—That is what you assume.

—You might deal with my assumption in your answer. It is a matter of fact, and we will find it out one way or the other; I can go back to the records and we can find it out, but it would save time if you could just confirm it. The real question I am coming to, and the question I want to again ask, is: given that this bill imposes extra complexity which will require further administrative responsibility by Austrade, has there been any estimate of whether there would be an extra cost of administration that would be incurred by Austrade if that were the case? If so, what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Ener gy)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator, I do not agree with your assumption that there is extra complexity. Therefore, I do not believe that there will be an increase in costs because of extra complexity. I cannot see where there is a raising of extra complexity within the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an extra administrative cost of about $2 million, but there are efficiency offsets against that, and I would imagine that those efficiency offsets will actually reduce that quite dramatically. I do not believe, Senator, that this bill has got in it the extra complexities you have alluded to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot quibble with a belief. If you believe that, that is what you believe. What the facts are, and whether they correspond to the belief, is another matter, and we can debate that. However, I just point out that the Australian Business Chamber, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Book Publishers Association, the Australian Institution of Export (New South Wales) Ltd, the Australian Information Industries Association, Blades Mi‐Sporting Products Pty Ltd, the Council of Small Business Organisations, the Metal Trades Industry Association—Australia's manufacturing, engineering and construction industry association—Sunlover Cruises, the Tasmanian apple and pear growers association and the Tourism Council of Australia all believe—this is their belief—that there is extra complexity, and that was the evidence that was adduced in the hearing.

PARA.BREAK: So that might be your perception, Senator, but their perception is different and their perception is unanimous. We will see what the truth of the matter is if these provisions are passed—and we have given an indication that we will support them as a government measure—as to whether extra complexity arises. I would find it prudent for any organisation faced with these measures to have undertaken some sort of estimate of what the extra costs to their organisation might be. I would have thought Austrade had done that. If Austrade have found other savings, that is again a reflection on the superior administra tion of Austrade because they certainly are competent administrators.

SPEECH.PARA: I also point out, as I have said in my remarks in principle, that advice to me is that the Expenditure Review Committee of your government has demanded a 24.3 per cent cut to Austrade's running costs budget, which would diminish its running costs by a quarter. The extra efficiencies they have found will have to go to covering that gaping hole as well as meeting the demands of extra complexity imposed on them by this bill. In those circumstances, a prudent organisation should be able to at least give this parliament an answer on what the extra costs and what the extra changes in Austrade will be, and it should be able to do it for the reason that it needs to assure the Australian business community that those costs are not going to unduly delay the payment of reimbursements under this scheme.

As we heard in evidence in the committee, many companies have taken loans to cover the time gap between incurring the cost and receiving the reimbursement. If, by virtue of so-called savings in Austrade, the time between cost being incurred, reimbursement being sought and reimbursement being paid is blown out, it could well be that some companies will be adversely affected in their financial affairs. It could be that the export effort is diminished considerably as a consequence as companies act conservatively to avoid being trapped. It could also be, and very probably will be, that some companies will be financially embarrassed. Some may even go to the wall. That is the basis of my concern and the reason for my questions.

The other point I want to ask though is, given this government's election commitment to reducing red tape and compliance costs on Australian small business by 50 per cent, can you give me any sort of guarantee that the 10-page document that Austrade is circulating for business commentary on how to meet the export ready test will, in fact, be simplified and made easy for business? By your courtesy—and I acknowledge that—Austrade made available to me, as I believe they have made available to the minor parties, a document which I think is still in draft form but which consists of 10 pages. Unfortunately, I do not have it with me at the moment, but I could show it to you again. Several questions in that document go right to the heart of a company's financial security: its products and services, its administration, its marketing capability, its evaluation of its competitors and its appreciation of market conditions in foreign countries.

Companies are expected to fill this out in order to demonstrate compliance with export readiness, as required under this act. That stands as an extra imposition on business. For small business, with little discretionary time available to meet the demands of red tape requirements such as this, this is a further imposition. My question is from the small business perspective and on how Austrade will administer this. Can you give me a guarantee that this quite extensive requirement will be reduced and made more simple?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think your last question was already required by the previous export plan, but I will just go through a couple of the points that you have made in speaking to this bill in the committee stage. I think the bill actually clarifies a number of issues. The bill will be longer, but it will be clearer. I think there will be a minimal cost to claimants. Basically, I presume we will go through the grants entry test when we get to that stage of the bill, Senator.
—I think we are taking it as a whole.

—We can discuss the grants entry test now, if you like, and that might clarify some of the issues. It is envisaged that the test will cover five fundamental areas of business planning—I think Senator Spindler would also have an interest in this—and that will be based on the financial resources to survive, human resources to do the job, marketing and distribution arrangements, supply and production arrangements and research development innovation to provide sustainable competitive advantage.

BREAK.PARA: The test will be designed to ensure that claimants meet accepted standards for entry to government facilitation programs. In the case of this test, it is the intention to ensure that the claimants have suitable levels of planning and forward thinking to avoid grants being paid to businesses that will subsequently go out of business. The grants entry test will be a disallowable instrument under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

I have read through the draft grants entry test, which was circulated to you and also to Senator Spindler for help within this debate. I think that is a courtesy sometimes extended by people to make the debate on the bill better, especially when the bill obviously was introduced by a previous government. Now we are going through the clauses. We did not have the opportunity to go through them because we had an election that interfered with the movement of this bill.

I believe that, if you go through the entry test in a fair mannered way, you will see that it is not an onerous one to fill out and it only adds, as I said, one more page and a couple of questions that were not in the previous act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue, I believe, in this particular question on the entry test is not so much the general information that needs to be provided but the test that is to be used by the government that, as the minister says, will be subject to a disallowable instrument. I would like to ask the minister: when will that instrument be available?
—Within the next two weeks, as I understand from the advice that I have here, Senator.

—I trust the government will take on board the comments made in the chamber which require a clear, detailed and objective test, because it was on the basis of that understanding that the Democrats decided not to proceed with the amendment to knock out that particular section in the bill and we advised both the government and the opposition that we would not be proceeding with it on that basis. The Australian Democrats—and really every other speaker—have pointed to the value of the export market development grants scheme. Can the minister confirm that the government is taking cognisance of what was said? Does the government now appreciate a little better the value of that scheme and can the government give the Senate some assurance that it will not proceed to abolish the scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, we are dealing with a bill that has been in place for over 12 months. I cannot conjecture what will happen in the future. All I can say is that, yes, the government does understand the value of the export market development grants scheme and it has been well documented.
