But you will have to wait until the budget in August to see the results of that. I know that deliberations I have had with you are on the basis of the bill. As far as this bill is concerned, there are no implications to it whatsoever to my knowledge.

—In view of the answer that Senator Brownhill has given to Senator Spindler on when the disallowable instrument will be tabled in the Senate, I understand that Austrade consulted on the draft—which is the document I have referred to—with industry. I think all of the organisations that made submissions to the Senate committee of inquiry into this bill raised concerns about its administrative complexity. Will the consultations that Austrade is undertaking be with those companies as well as more broadly with industry associations, or will they be confined to a consultative process that is already in place? My question really is: given that these people have raised the issue, will they be talked to about how it will be dealt with? I ask that question because some of them have said they do not believe that Austrade has consulted them, although they do have some views about it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Ener gy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the consultation process that has been in place in the past will continue. I believe Austrade has been a good organisation, is a good organisation and will remain a good organisation as far as our trade is concerned. Just this morning I was in Melbourne helping launch the CeBIT event that is going to take place in Hanover next year. I believe that Austrade has always been a hands‐on organisation and that it will continue to consult with people as it has in the past and, I am sure, will in the future.

—I say amen to your sentiments about Austrade. That is certainly my experience but I note for the record that their chief executive, Mr Ralph Evans, is not renewing his contract and is leaving and I note the disquiet that has been leaked to the media about possible cuts to government programs, in particular the running costs cut that I have referred to. I take your answer to be that Austrade will continue to consult with the organisations that they would normally consult with. My question is: will they consult with the organisations that gave evidence to the Senate committee that raised questions about the difficulty and complexity that I have referred to?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give you an assurance that they will, because that is a normal fact. The test has been formulated in consultation with industry, so the consultation has been there. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is one group that was consulted, as were the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, Australian Business Ltd, the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia Ltd and the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. So I believe that there has been consultation and I believe that there will continue to be.

—I am not saying that there has not been consultation, but I just want to be sure that those who raise the question of complexity—for example, the Tourism Council of Australia was not referred to in that list you read—will be consulted. Can you give me an assurance that those who have taken the time to write a submission and appear before the Senate committee to raise the question of complexity will be consulted about the regulations that are to be imposed on them before it is put up as a disallowable instrument?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would imagine that to be the case, yes.
—Is that a yes?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Brownhill) read a third time.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —When we suspended this debate earlier today I was saying that this bill is welcome, even though it is three years late. It is more than three years late, but it has been on the agenda for three years. I was pointing out that it only goes part way to honouring the coalition government's election commitment because at the end of 1996-97, under this bill, the uplift factor reverts to 10 per cent. So all we get is one year's reduction.

SPEECH.PARA: This contrasts with the coalition's small business policy, which says, `The provisional tax uplift factor will be reduced by two per cent to six per cent which is more in line with nominal growth in the economy.' This does not say, `We are going to reduce it for one year only.' It sets down the principle of being in line with nominal growth in the economy.

BREAK.PARA: I believe it is to be a permanent reduction. Mr Howard announced this. He said, `We are the real friends of small business.' He made good political capital out of it. He said, `This is going to assist small business to employ more people. We are going to solve employment problems. Small business is going to do it all.'

The point I make is that small business cannot do it all if the uplift factor is only going to be reduced for one year. That is the issue. That is why in committee we will be supporting the opposition amendment to make this a permanent commitment, to make the coalition government honour its election commitment in a permanent way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) and the provisional tax uplift factor. In speaking for the Labor opposition on this matter, firstly, the bill proposes to decrease the current provisional tax uplift factor from its current eight per cent to six per cent for 1996‐97 only. For subsequent years, the uplift factor will revert to 10 per cent unless parliament otherwise prescribes.

SPEECH.PARA: Provisional tax is levied on individual taxpayers who earn $1,000 or more in investment income—interest, dividends, rental income. It does not apply to salary and wage earners, who fall under the scope of the PAYE scheme. Provisional tax is levied in order to bring forward future estimated taxation revenue from future income earnings.

Quite often, certainly when we were in government—and I am sure while we have been in opposition—small business made significant representations about the drain on their cash flow that can occur as a consequence of the provisional tax uplift factor. They argue that it can affect their cash flow as they have to pay tax on current year earnings and then pay provisional tax on next year's estimated earnings. The provisional tax payable is based on the previous year's income being increased by the provisional tax uplift factor and then calculated at the prevailing income tax rates.

BREAK.PARA: Prior to the election, the then opposition, now the government, stated that the reduced rate would be of benefit to small business. I can recall on a number of occasions the now Prime Minister, John Howard, personally extolling the virtues of the now government's policy in his appeal to small business. I have here a copy of the Liberal‐National coalition's small business policy entitled A new deal for small business. It states:

It is inexcusable that the Labor Government continues to apply to provisional tax assessments a provisional tax uplift factor of 8 per cent which is in excess of growth in the economy and incomes. We will return these funds to their rightful owners—small business.
It goes on:
Under a Liberal/National Coalition government:
. the Provisional Tax Uplift Factor will be reduced by 2% to 6% which is more in line with nominal growth in the economy. This measure will have a one-off cost of $180 million.

That is their policy. But what do we have here in the legislation today? Any reasonable reading of the Liberal-National parties' policy would lead a person and, I am sure, the hundreds of thousands of small business persons around Australia to believe that the tax uplift factor was being reduced to six per cent—full stop. But what does this legislation do? It does not just drop it from eight per cent to six per cent. It returns it to 10 per cent after one year.

This is a massive breach of faith in the commitment given at the last election by the new government—a massive breach of faith. It will affect 800,000 small businesses and investors around the country, who will have to pay not just a reduced uplift factor for one year. To really rub salt into the wound, it will not be lifted back up to the eight per cent, which is what it is at the present time, but to 10 per cent, which is above where we had it. It is an outrageous breach of faith. I can assure the government that there are thousands of disillusioned small business people around Australia who are appalled at the breaking of the election commitment given by the government.

It is interesting to look through some of the speeches given by now members of the government on this matter. I am going to quote just a few of them because I think it is worth while reminding the government what their position was in opposition. Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer, struggling with a range of issues in his portfolio at the moment, said on 10 October 1994:

The other major item in this bill—it is a controversial one—is the reduction in the uplift factor for provisional tax from 10 per cent to only eight per cent—a relatively small reduction. That is being done at a time when inflation is being forecast by the government to be something like 2¼ per cent and there is an average earnings growth of about 3.5 per cent. So there is certainly a major discrepancy between the uplift factor and inflation.
I will return to that fact a little later. He went on:

By reducing the uplift factor further below the limited reduction to eight per cent, the government would not lose revenue in the longer run but would delay and reduce its collection this year and therefore put more money in the hands of business and less in the hands of government. At a time when capital expenditure is important for small business, this tax slug, which takes cash out of firms' hands and puts it into the government's pocket for 12 months, will only hinder the opportunities for small business to expand.
He goes on and on, complaining about the tax uplift factor. Senator Panizza stated:

I would now like to address the provisional tax uplift factor. I have said time and again in this place that the provisional tax uplift factor should reflect Australia's economy, our inflation rate and those allied things that affect the sort of profit businesses will make.
He went on in his speech complaining, very bitterly in fact, about the provisional tax uplift factor. Senator Ferguson, who I think was on the Senate Economics References Committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the chairman.

—I am glad you informed me of that, Senator Calvert. He was in fact chair of the committee that prepared a report on the tax treatment of small business, entitled A question of balance , which refers to this issue as one of the major concerns of small business. In his contribution to that debate Senator Ferguson said:

BREAK.PARA: On 20 October 1994, the Senate referred to the Senate Economics References Committee for inquiry and report the matter of the tax treatment of small business. This matter arose following concerns about the appropriateness of the level of the provisional tax uplift factor that the government was proposing to apply to the provisional taxpayers for the 1994-95 financial year.
He goes on and says:

The most complex issue that the committee had to deal with was the provisional tax uplift factor. Of all the issues raised by small business in the inquiry, it is fair to say that the uplift factor was almost universally considered unfair, not the least because most small businesses do not experience a growth in income as great as the uplift factor expects them to. This is why the committee majority recommends that the uplift factor be set at a level no higher than the current or expected annual movement in the consumer price index.

Again, he went on with a very significant range of complaints about the tax uplift factor. If we look at the membership of that committee we see that Senator Ferguson was the chair and there were other members of the now government—Senator Chapman, Senator Crane and Senator Panizza—altogether four members from the government. It will be very interesting to see how they vote in this Senate on the amendment that will be moved in committee by the Labor opposition on this matter. It is outrageous that a promise was given by the now government before the election—I have read out its promise on this issue—to reduce the uplift factor from eight to six per cent and then one year later the government takes it, not back up to eight per cent, which would be a breach of promise in itself, but to 10 per cent. It is no wonder small business is absolutely outraged by what the government is proposing.

In pursuing our opposition in committee we will be moving that the provisional uplift factor remain at six per cent, as the coalition promised when it went to the election. By moving that amendment—I hope it is accepted by the Senate and I certainly hope to see a number of now government senators cross over this side of the chamber and vote in favour of our amendment—we will be saving, if it is carried, small business $360 million, on the government's own costings, in the 1997-98 financial year and a further $360 million in 1998-99, by the time of the next scheduled election. I hope small business, in three years time, if that is when the election is, remembers the massive breach of faith by the now government in this area. We will certainly be reminding them of that massive breach of faith.

If our amendment is carried it will mean an additional $540 million going back into the hands of small business as a consequence of what the Labor Party has done in opposition in this Senate. We are going to hold you to your commitment and your promise on this matter. It is outrageous. The speeches I referred to continually refer to the need for the uplift factor to be reduced to the economic growth rate, the inflation rate. All of those sorts of basic economic fundamentals have been referred to by now members of the government about where the uplift factor should be reduced to. It is not as though inflation is high. When this matter was debated two years ago, projected inflation was 2¼, 2½ per cent. Look where inflation is now. If anything, the government should be reducing the uplift factor even further below six or seven per cent on its own arguments, on its own contributions, on the record, in the Hansard in this place, in the report prepared by the Senate Economics References Committee. On its own argument it should be reducing the factor down below six per cent, but what are they going to do? This is a massive breach of an election promise made here in writing. I have read it into the Hansard.

Senator Watson has just come into the chamber. The provisional uplift factor is being debated today. You should be ashamed of yourself, Senator Watson, for being in a government that promised to reduce it to six per cent. Where does it say that you are going to up it to 10 per cent after the first year? Any reasonable person reading your policy believed it was going to stay at six per cent. That is what the many small business people who have been ringing my office and ringing Gareth Evans's office, the office of the shadow Treasurer, have been saying. They are deeply disillusioned about what you have done on this proposal.

Senator Watson, one of the more responsible members of the government, should be sitting where Senator Short is. He could probably answer some of the questions on sales tax and the other issues we have been raising with him. As one of the more responsible members of the government, I am sure you have been contacted by outraged small business people who are going to be ripped off to the tune of $540 million when this uplift factor returns to 10 per cent.

We are going to defend small business in the Senate. We are going to return $540 million. I look forward to you, Senator Watson, living up to your comments on this matter when you were in opposition and crossing the floor, along with the other senators who have spoken on this matter in the last five or six years, and supporting our amendment on this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry has a very short memory because in terms of the legislation the 10 per cent fallback figure has been there. I think the Labor Party introduced that concept. We are honest. We want to review it each year and, given the prevailing circumstances, if it can be lowered from the current six per cent we will certainly lower it next year with the full support of business.

SPEECH.PARA: The hypocrisy of the people opposite is somewhat astounding. The legislation concerns three amendments that I want to address. There is reducing the provisional uplift factor, which has been very well received, contrary to the earlier remarks. There are the off-market share buybacks and the deduction for gifts. I want to confine my remarks essentially to the first two aspects, the provisional uplift factor and the off-market share buybacks. The reduction of the uplift factor on calculated provisional tax is the fulfilment of an election promise that this government gave to small business. It has been well received, contrary to earlier remarks.

We went to the election on 2 March on a promise that we would reduce the uplift factor for small business. The coalition's policy document, A new deal for small business, released on 18 February 1996, announced that there would be a reduction in the uplift factor from eight to six per cent for the purpose of calculating the 1996-97 provisional tax, and that is exactly what the government is doing in this bill. That is 100 per cent commitment.

BREAK.PARA: By contrast, the Labor Party went to the election of 1993 and said that they would not increase taxation. They were not committed to reducing it; they just promised that there would be no increase in taxes. But, as we all know, they did not even hold themselves to that. Not only did they not reduce it; they actually put up taxes.

The coalition gave the electorate a commitment, not simply to keep taxes at the same level. It gave a commitment to reduce the tax burden in relation to provisional tax, and now we are keeping that commitment. It believes in honouring promises. It is reducing the provisional tax from eight per cent set in previous years under the previous government to six per cent in the 1996-97 financial year. If no legislation was being introduced, provisional taxpayers would be paying 10 per cent under the legislation designed by the Labor Party—the default level if parliament does not provide otherwise. The coalition will not allow that default 10 per cent to operate in the 1996-97 financial year. It is delivering on its promise. It will not allow the default to operate next year either, unless the Senate intervenes.

Small businesses are the backbone of our economy. The potential for job growth is greatest in the small business sector, but they need encouragement. In 1995, the number of bankruptcies in Australia increased at an alarming rate under the previous government, from 3,305 in December 1994 to 4,050 in December 1995—a 22.5 per cent increase. Businesses desperately needed to be relieved of the onerous and unfair taxation measures. The application of this bill will go some way to alleviating their plight.

Labor's record in this field has been appalling. The uplift factor they set was quite out of proportion to any realistic measures of ability to pay or prediction of economic growth. Senate committee reports have examined this from time to time. It was just another way in which the Labor Party grabbed revenue from those making an honest living to fund the Labor Party's ill-managed government expenditure. Under Labor, the provisional uplift factor exceeded the actual rate of growth in income subject to provisional tax in every year between 1991 and 1994-95. The provisional uplift factor was set by the previous Labor government at eight per cent for each of the last four years, including 1994-95.

The level of aggregate income that should be subject to provisional tax can be difficult to predict. We all acknowledge that. Therefore, in regard to the uplift factor for subsequent years after the 1996-97 financial year, the new coalition government will set it when the most accurate information is available, and that is the right time to set it. It will be set at what is a realistic figure for the time and the circumstances so that small business people, self- funded retirees and other provisional taxpayers will be treated fairly.

We will not lock those people into situations where they may be penalised because of changing economic circumstances merely to get revenue for government but, rather, we will set a rate which is a reasonable reflection of the growth in income of provisional taxpayers. This is actually what is being done for the 1996-97 financial year. For subsequent years, an assessment of the economic circumstances will be made at the appropriate time.

The report on the consideration of provisions of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) by the Economics Legislation Committee recommends that the bill be agreed to. Unfortunately, I think the terms of reference for that particular inquiry were a little bit limited. However, all members of the committee wholeheartedly endorsed the reduction of the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. The report draws attention to the fact that the amount of tax for which provisional taxpayers are finally liable will not be affected in dollar terms by the uplift factor, regardless of the amount or the form. What is at issue is the timing of the payment to the tax office. It is this aspect which can be a deterrent or an incentive for small business.

If provisional taxpayers think their income will not increase by the predicted uplift factor or that their taxable income will decline during the remainder of the forthcoming year, taxpayers of course can lodge an application to vary their provisional tax. A penalty, however, is incurred if that variation understates actual income by more than 15 per cent, unless the taxpayer can justify why his or her income was underestimated.

Three submissions were received by the committee in relation to this question of the uplift factor—all of which applauded the reduction to six per cent. Concerns that it will revert to 10 per cent in the absence of parliamentary provisions otherwise naturally were expressed. What needs to be more clearly understood is that it is the government's intention to review the circumstances each year, according to the economic prevailing circumstances. The default 10 per cent may never be imposed. The intention is to review the factor in the appropriate economic climate, as was the practice of past Labor governments—it is not surprising that Senator Sherry has now left the chamber—although they seldom moved that rate, and this was the interesting factor, as reflected in the various determinants of unearned income.

The minority report from the Labor members of the committee condemns the 10 per cent after 1997. What they chose to ignore for their own political purposes is that the government has quite appropriately left open the option to review the factor. My Labor colleagues would have us locked in without any possibility of adjustment in the light of changing economic factors. There must be provision for more flexibility. For that reason, we will not be supporting the Labor Party amendment.

A submission from the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants drew the committee's attention to the fact that provisional taxpayers are often reluctant to submit a provisional tax variation as the cost of doing so—doing the appropriate estimates—coupled with the 15 per cent variation tolerance allowed is a real deterrent. A submission from the Association of Independent Retirees expressed a similar psychological factor which may cause anxiety, especially amongst the elderly. It must be remembered—I think it was during the Labor Party administration—that the factor was previously 20 per cent in terms of the estimates and was reduced some time ago to 15 per cent.

The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants actually suggests that the uplift factor be linked with the economic growth factor put forward by the Treasury in its budget consideration each year. An alternative suggestion put forward by the Taxation Institute was that the factor should be automatically linked with the rate of inflation. Both of these suggestions are worthy of more serious consideration in the future deliberations on the uplift factor. The important thing is that the coalition seeks to provide flexibility and a determinant at the most appropriate time when all the circumstances are best known.

The second aspect of the bill that I want to address is in relation to the off‐market share buybacks. These will apply to off‐market share buyers. The amendments are intended to deter companies from avoiding tax by arranging off‐market share buybacks. The amendment will ensure that the full buyback price of off‐market shares is treated as consideration for ordinary income tax purposes and for calculating any gain or loss on the disposal of the shares. Relief from double taxation is provided by reducing the amount of the buyback price that is a dividend included in assessable income or paid out of profits, not including revaluation reserves.

Under the previous law tax could be reduced by the amount of the buyback that was treated as a dividend, even if the dividend was exempt or paid from an untaxed source. Companies could gain a tax advantage by buying back off‐market at a higher or lower price than the market value of the share. They could also create artificial capital losses and allowable deductions or these could be increased by rebatable dividends in certain circumstances.

The proposed amendments that our government is putting forward will not change the calculation of that part of the purchase price of a share in an off‐market buyback that is a dividend. What will change, however, is the amount that is to be treated as disposable consideration for the purposes of calculating ordinary income or capital gain or loss. If there is a difference between the purchase price in respect of an off‐market buyback and the market value of a share at the time of the buyback, a market value rule will apply. The share's market value at the time of the buyback is the amount which would have been the market value of the share at the time if the buyback never occurred and was never intended.

If the purchase price of the share is less than the market value of the share, the difference between that price and the market value will be treated as consideration for ordinary income and capital gains purposes. It will not be treated as a dividend. This means that the taxable gain will not be artificially reduced and a tax loss will therefore not be created. If the purchase price is more than the market value of the share, the amount of the purchase price that is treated as a dividend is the amount that exceeds the sum of the paid‐up capital of the share and the amount debited to a share premium account. The dividend component of the purchase price which is attributable to the excess over the market value of the share, however, will not be frankable, no matter from where the funds used to buy back the shares are sourced.

This proposal was announced by the former Labor government on 9 May 1995 as part of its 1995-96 budget. In this bill it is proposed that the closing of this loophole take effect quickly and will apply to all share buybacks that took place after 7.30 p.m. on 9 May 1995. Arrangements which were announced and which were acted on well before this date will be exempt.

It is important that a taxation scheme does not encourage Australian investors to send their money outside Australia. This measure, amongst other things, will deter resident shareholders receiving tax exempt dividends from the off‐market buyback of shares held in a foreign company where the dividend is not paid out of profits.

Those on the other side have made much of a hyped‐up speculation of possible cuts to this or that government expenditure over the past few weeks. They have carefully skirted the reasons for which savings in government expenditure will have to be made. They ignore the fact that the coalition government inherited this $8 billion deficit which must be funded. Under good management, good controls and greater confidence in our ability to manage, that figure is now substantially less than $8 billion and will continue to fall over the next few years. The Labor mismanagement of government finances over the last 13 years means that the government is now faced with a huge debt and a huge interest bill on our borrowings.

This opportunity for dodging tax should have been closed quite a number of years ago. In the Taxation Institute of Australia's submission to the Economics Legislation Committee the suggestion was made that the market value of the share at the date of the agreement under which the share buyback took place be adopted. If the market value is to be adopted, it should be set at this earlier period. I think there is some substance in the suggestion. I commend it to the minister. The institute suggested that this would avoid the unintended consequence where there is an arms‐length transaction involved in situations where the market value differs from the actual consideration provided.

The institute submits that the adoption of a market value in the buyback provisions should be subject to an arms‐length exclusion. A taxpayer should not be assessed on an arms‐length transaction on an amount that may never be received. If, for example, the share buyback price is set in advance under an agreement, there may be subsequent fluctuations in the market value of the shares. If the share price increases, the share buyback provisions will be automatically attracted.

The institute's submission also draws attention to a problem which may arise as a result of the application of the legislation to many employee share acquisition schemes. There may be a need for specific exemption in the share buyback provisions for these schemes to avoid a situation where the employee will derive a gain on the differential between the market value at the date of the share buyback and the original acquisition price.

I say to the minister that both these points do have merit and I believe they should be given further consideration. They do not, however, conflict with the general thrust of this legislation, which is to close loopholes in the taxation system whereby clever companies and their advisers can avoid their taxation obligations by making special arrangements with regard to their off‐market buyback arrangements.
I therefore support the legislation. I seek your comments, minister, on my suggestions that were originally put forward by the tax institute. I thank the Senate for its attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. This bill contains a number of measures. The one I wish to address my remarks to this afternoon is the provisional tax uplift factor. I acknowledge that the government's expert in taxation matters, Senator Watson, has just spoken, and I want to respectfully disagree with his remarks about the provisional tax uplift factor. But I am reminded, now that I have seen him take the chair, that I ought to do so in a continuing mode of respect, as, of course, I always would.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem the government has to grapple with on this subject is that, for much of the debate on this matter, the government is still exhibiting a mentality of opposition. That is to say, they are attacking the previous government and they are arguing that what we said and did in government are things that we ought to do now.

This is an interesting point, because we do not have a mandate that was endorsed by the electorate. What we are doing in this debate is simply holding the coalition government to its mandate—which Australians everywhere think they ought to be held to and which they ought to honour. It is no good saying to us what our views were. We put our views at the election. Unfortunately for us, they did not prevail. What is expected to prevail is the coalition's views. That is what Senator Sherry's amendment is about—to ensure that the views of the coalition, presented to the electorate back in the election, are now honoured in government.

The coalition, in the run-up to the election campaign, made a great deal about small business. Small business is, of course, the vital wellspring of economic growth in Australia. The advantage the coalition seized on was to simply repeat facts about small businesses as if they had made new discoveries. They have not made new discoveries. We have been arguing those things all along. But in the election campaign, there is no doubt that the coalition made a feature of that and there is no doubt that we will hold them to that. There is also no doubt that many of the things they said swayed votes.

It is interesting to note that the Bureau of Industry Economics, that body which is now going to be broadbanded into the Productivity Commission, whatever that might end up being, in its most recent industry survey for the March quarter made some interesting observations about the behaviour of the small business sector. One of the remarks—and I do not have it in front of me, but I will paraphrase it—relates to job growth.

In the election campaign, the now Prime Minister, Mr Howard, railed that Labor had let down small business and stunted job growth. The BIE report shows that there was massive job growth in Australia during the previous period, including the March quarter, created by small business under the Labor administration, and that all of the new jobs effectively created in the economy came from small business, which, I might say, was a Labor achievement.

It also points out that on current trends future investment by small business in expanding their capacity is estimated to be below the levels of what occurred during the Labor period. While it is true that the surveys of business confidence showed business and small business having high confidence—the sort of halo effect you get with a change of government—nonetheless, what they say and what they do are two important distinctions to be made here. According to the BIE survey, it is likely that investment by small business in the future will be below the levels of last year, as presently indicated. I hope that changes, but they are the facts as they stand. It does not, therefore, reflect the confident surveys that the government has been lauding.

In the election campaign, small business growth was to improve unemployment, to increase economic growth and to improve the current account deficit. One of the promises made by the government was to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor. I have to say straight off that at the end of the day the full level of tax due to a small business is paid, whatever the provisional tax uplift factor. Therefore, no-one is here talking about reducing the level of taxation. We are talking about the timing of payment of the level of taxation in this respect.

That is important. It is important because the more you pay in provisional tax as an uplift factor, if the factor is not cast at the right level, the more money you do not have use of in your business. For small business, which is always cash strapped and always overpressed, that is an important consideration.

It has always been a consideration of mine that the best uplift factor is the factor which most accurately predicts what will be the ultimate payment in taxation, because there is a downside in having too low an uplift factor. The downside is that when the tax year ends a small business company can be visited with a requirement to pay out a large amount because they have not paid, in their tax year, sufficient in the provisional uplift. That can come as a bit of a surprise to a company. Given that small business is always teetering on the brink, it can knock some of them over the edge.

I have always thought that the sensible thing here is not to run in a cheer chasing mode, trying to pretend that somehow you are reducing taxation by changing the uplift factor, but to actually tell the truth about the best way to strike the most reasonable level of uplift factor. That has been the consideration that I have followed. However, as I have said, the government in the election campaign made a big feature of reducing it from eight per cent to six per cent. They were elected. This bill enacts that undertaking.

It does much more than that. It continues, for the outyears, to return the tax uplift factor to 10 per cent. I am absolutely certain, because small business have told me, that this is not what small business thought was being promised. When one looks at the fine print of the election undertaking, the fine print just having been recited by Senator Watson in the chamber here a moment ago, one will see that the promise was not to reduce the uplift factor to six per cent—as is commonly understood and, in terms of media presentations on the television, radio and in the campaign literature, was said many times by responsible figures in the government, including the Prime Minister and the then shadow Treasurer—but was, in fact, to reduce it just for the 1996-97 year. The fact that that was in fact the promise, which is relied on now because of the fine print, will come as a surprise, and it has come as a surprise, to small business.

In a recent interview, a journalist asked the Prime Minister: if there is a clash between what you have promised at the election and cost‐cutting to fill the alleged black hole, will you repudiate your election commitments in order to fill the black hole? It was a very pertinent question. The Prime Minister said, `No, we will stick by our election commitments,' in so many words.

The election commitment here is for the 1996-97 year. Our view is that that election commitment should be honoured and that the outyears ought to be a matter of calculation, and it ought to be a matter of being advised as to the appropriate level after consultation with small business so that there is a clear understanding as well.

Senator Watson in his remarks referred to the coalition document A new deal for small business. The coalition made a great play of saying that in the first 100 days what they would do for small business is hold a small business summit. They have held it. They held it just outside of the 100-day limit, but one would be somewhat unfair to make a significant point of that.

The fact is that the small business summit that was promised would be held was held, but it was really not a summit. It really was a ministerial council meeting. What it consisted of was relevant federal ministers and relevant state ministers, with some local government people along for the ride, and small business being hand‐picked and invited to make set speeches to the so-called summit.

At the end of the day it was a total fizzer. It did not come down with anything that would reduce the burden of compliance costs on small business as it was mooted it would. It did not come down with any hard changes. What it came down with at the end of the day was a decision to meet again in another year and see whether or not in the ensuing period the changes that had been lauded at election time can, in fact, be delivered. I know that there is a lot of disquiet among small business about the unhappy outcome of that summit.

One of the other promises that the government made at election time in that new deal for small business was to cut compliance costs, that is, to reduce red tape by 50 per cent. Unfortunately for this debate right now, the immediate bill preceding this one, the EMDG bill, has been on. All of the major business organisations, including the small business organisations, gave evidence to the Senate committee inquiring into that bill that the compliance costs and red tape would massively increase with the passage of that bill.

The government has set up a committee to look at compliance costs. What we are now getting is a promise on the never-never, in the hope that that committee will examine it and find a way through it. What we are now getting from the responsible minister is a back-pedalling and a softening of his language as to whether or not compliance costs can be reduced and as to whether or not the burden of red tape can be cut at all.

I make the point for this debate, because small business will be watching this debate very carefully, that, whatever the level of compliance costs and red tape that the government inherited when it came to office, it has now added to them. It has now added to them with the passage of the most recent bill, the EMDG bill. That is the opinion of business. That is the opinion as adduced in the Senate committee hearing, and it is widespread.

Let me now turn to the provisional tax uplift factor. My colleague Senator Sherry has pointed out that, by going back to 10 per cent in the outyears after 1996-97, there will be an extra burden of $540 million imposed on small business. That is what this bill does. The government should not have done that. Senator Sherry is right to say to all the government senators in this place, who last year and the year before stood up and made pretty speeches about how they were going to slash the provisional tax uplift factor, that they should cross the floor and vote for this amendment. If they do not, their words do not count for anything. In fact, their reputations are being held out to dry by the government treating them as backbenchers and as mushrooms in this case.

It has also been said, rightly, that the Senate Economics Legislation Committee, which conducted an inquiry into this legislation, received three submissions and that, in those submissions, the cut from eight per cent to six per went was widely—I quote the word used in the report—`applauded'. That is an accurate description of what the submissions did say.

But they also referred to the increase from six per cent to 10 per cent. In those submissions, the organisations—the Australian Society of Chartered Practising Accountants, the CPAs, the Association of Independent Retirees and the Taxation Institute Of Australia—said that they condemned the move to 10 per cent. The report itself, in reflecting the evidence before it, refers to that view as `the move was widely condemned'. That is a quote from the report. So it is not a matter of saying that we, the opposition, are saying that this is condemned; the responsible organisations that had made submissions to the inquiry have condemned it. On the basis of their condemnation, we are trying to give effect to their view and the decision of the government in the election campaign.

The reason why we are is that, of course, a 10 per cent provisional tax uplift factor will fall hardest on small business. It will be a repudiation of a government claim. No amount of obfuscating will change that. No amount of saying that we are putting it in the act for machinery reasons and that we will come to it each year and deal with whether or not it should be 10 per cent or some other figure will calm the disquiet among small business.

It will not calm it because the 10 per cent will be sitting there as a legislative fact and small business every year will have to mount its lobby to try to persuade the government what the reasonable level will be. So every year small business will form itself into a battalion, march on the government, knock on its door and say, `Do what you promised in the election.' That is the political dimension.

The practical business level dimension is more important, which is this: what a government should do for the business community, and which is absolutely desirable in all cases, is give long and strong reliable signals to industry as to what the parameters for their activities will be. Tax is an important parameter. The government should give long, strong signals about what its tax intentions are. Industry should be able to believe them so they can then conduct their business activities within those parameters.

If they want to talk to their bank manager about how much they might have available next year to take out a loan to finance business expansion, they ought to be able to know what the tax uplift factor will be. With the 10 per cent sitting there, not the six per cent, business is bound to take the 10 per cent as being the likely outcome and, as a consequence, reduce the amount of investment they might have made in expansion. If it is not 10 per cent—it could be any damn figure—they would take the conservative course and protect themselves rather than be pushed into believing it might be lower when it in fact turns out to be 10 per cent. In other words, they might invest only on the basis of 10 per cent.

The government, by leaving that in this bill, is in fact sending a very bad signal to industry that the long, strong signals—the certainty—that it requires are not there. It is a variation year to year. This government is going to exercise its right to vary it. Against this background, business, in particular small business, expects the figure will be six per cent.

I make those remarks because I hope the minister at the table, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), when he replies, will deal with what small business should do. Should small business, given the remarks of Senator Watson, believe 10 per cent? Should it believe it will be eight per cent? Should it think it might be six per cent? How does it plan its next out year? What does it say to its bank manager or its loans office when it tries to finance its own further business development?

They are important questions for small business. I hope the government can answer them. In the meantime, I will vote for the six per cent. I will support Senator Sherry's amendment to make that the level because I believe absolutely that is what the government told the people of Australia and that is what the people of Australia expect the government to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly today on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. Before I talk about the Greens' position on this bill, I want to respond to some of the issues that were raised in Senator Cook's presentation. There is obviously a growing concern amongst small business in Australia in relation to compliance costs. But, before anyone deals with that issue, it has to be recognised that a lot of that has to do with the growing trend towards self‐assessment in taxation. It is not just a problem for small businesses, though obviously small businesses feel it as a cost comparative to their output much more than large businesses or corporations do.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also a fairly major worry for many individuals. A record number of people, we are reliably told by professional tax associations, now feel compelled to employ a tax accountant to do their ordinary tax. The Tax Pack does not actually work for most people, and many of the people who do not use a tax accountant are those who cannot afford it or have no income to speak of.

We have a growing situation in Australia where we are expecting the people who can least afford it to spend the most on assessing their tax, comparative to their wage that is. One wonders whether some study has been done of what the extra cost would be. If we provided enough staff within the tax office they could advise individuals and small business especially of their tax obligations. In that way people would not be tied up in knots of worry and concern over the threat of tax audits and somebody else saying, `It's up to you but anywhere up to, say, seven years down the track we can check and you have to have all the details on hand to justify whatever decisions you have made.' I know, from speaking to people in the regions of Western Australia, that that is a concern to a great many people and a great many small businesses.

The Greens (WA) have a preferred position where in time we think the whole of the tax system ought to be subject to a comprehensive review. The starting point of that review would be: what do we think tax revenue in Australia should pay for? What are we hoping to achieve from tax revenue? From there, once you have worked out your priorities you would then work out the best system to provide that tax review. We make changes bit by bit and in the end just simplifying the wording of tax legislation, which we have done in the past, does not address that; it simply makes onerous obligations of self-assessment clearer. That does not help necessarily if you are the person who is worrying about trying to do the right thing—that is, paying the correct amount of tax.

The actual cost to Australia would be huge, if that has ever been assessed. Perhaps the minister might enlighten us as to whether there has ever been a study. Maybe someone knows whether there has been a study of what the actual compliance cost across Australia is, whether it is increasing and how that might be mitigated, not by just lopping off taxes but by actually working out a system whereby people can be notified of what their tax obligations are instead of their having to work it out themselves.

I turn now to the details of the bill. This bill contains two issues that were already included in a tax bill of the previous government: the tax deductibility of donations to certain organisations and some changes to avoid double taxation in relation to share buybacks. The first is a routine issue and the second concerns a complex area of financial dealing but does not actually address share buybacks themselves just their tax treatment. Since I have not heard of any objections or problems in relation to these areas I will not waste time speaking about them, although I may take up the issue of share buybacks at a later time.

BREAK.PARA: The third element is the change to the provisional tax uplift factor. Since 1991 the underlying, or default, uplift factor, as Senator Cook mentioned, has been 10 per cent. During the last three years that certainly has been too high. It is my view that, as a basic rate, it is too high. There is no reason to build in an expectation that consultancies or small service business will grow at 10 per cent per annum, especially when the economy is not growing at anything like that rate.

In the past I have said that a fixed default rate is not the best way to go. I think it would be better to work out a formula based on indicators such as CPI or gross domestic product change, perhaps modified by some figures about the state of small business growth. With that as a default amount, the parliament could vary the rate, but it would be less likely to require legislative correction with such a method.

As it is, the default rate is high and has required downward correction each year that I have been in this place. I worry that if the rate is left where it is the status quo will be maintained. Any amendment the Senate puts to a different bill could be removed by the House of Representatives.

We have supported a lower rate in the past. We think the proper way to go is to have a rate which, while it might be low, the government can argue to raise, rather than having a rate that is almost always too high and leaving the Senate to lower it. For that reason, the Greens (WA) will support the opposition amendment to change the default rate to six per cent.

I reiterate: in the end, we think that the tax system needs changing. The starting point should not be: what is business prepared to pay? The starting point should be: what are we hoping to achieve in various policy areas? Many groups should be involved in that decision making process. Perhaps the community should have a say as well.

The starting point for a new tax system should be: finding out what the important things are on which we want to spend tax; what people think is a reasonable amount of tax; and looking at the various groups which pay tax and at what relative tax contributions they should be making. That is a fairly novel idea. The tax reviews we have seen so far do not go anywhere near looking at the system, at what we are paying and how we are doing it. As I said, we will support the opposition amendment and, with that change, we will support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by thanking all speakers in this debate—Senator Sherry, Senator Kernot, Senator Cook, Senator Margetts and you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will not take up too much of the Senate's time at this second reading stage. There are some items which we can take up in the committee stage. However, there are a few points I would like to take up in response to the contributions that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I reiterate that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 deals with three separate elements. The first element, the deduction for gifts, relates to several new deductions under the gifting provisions and the extension of one or two other gift provisions that have already been granted. There was no comment really on that one way or another from any of the speakers.

The second element was that of share buybacks. Again, there was little disagreement on that issue and it was not widely touched on. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, raised certain issues and I give you an assurance that we will look carefully at them. As I understand it, you raised two main issues in relation to the share buyback amendments.

The first was that the market value rules should not apply to arm's length transactions. The second was that the share buyback amendments might operate inappropriately in relation to certain employee share acquisition schemes. I will come back to you and to the Senate with a fuller response to the latter point. I assure you and the Senate that it has been carefully noted and the government will have a careful look at it.

I have a couple of comments to make on the first issue that Senator Watson raised. Firstly, as I am sure Senator Watson would agree, it is often very difficult to determine whether parties are dealing with each other at arm's length. The market value rule is an effective, objective test for determining whether parties are dealing with each other at arm's length. Secondly, irrespective of whether parties are dealing with each other at arm's length, it would not be appropriate—Senator Watson did not suggest in any way that it would be appropriate—to allow a capital loss to be created by buying back shares for less than their true value. I make those comments at this stage but undertake to give the matter fuller and more careful consideration.

The third element, and the main issue dealt with, was the provisional tax uplift factor. I will address most of my remaining remarks to that but, before doing so, I would like to pick up on Senator Margetts's point about compliance. As I understood it, Senator Margetts was talking about compliance with taxation generally. I could not agree with her more on that matter. One of the greatest problems we have with our taxation system today is the huge growth in taxation legislation that has occurred, particularly under the 13 years of Labor rule. I think I am correct in saying that during those 13 years the income tax act went from something in the order of 1,700 pages to something over 4,000 pages.

The situation now is that the taxation system generally—and the sales tax act bears eloquent testimony to this as well—is so immense and complex that I defy anyone, even the most expert tax practitioner, to have a full comprehension of the details of the tax act and the taxation laws. They have grown like Topsy over decades now. They have been added to, layer after layer, and that is something that we believe is in major need of rectification and reform. Indeed, I or my colleague Mr Miles in the other place will be introducing legislation, if not today, then tomorrow, to take a first step along the way to the simplification of the income tax laws.

The point is that the cost of compliance is made far too high. One of the major objectives that we have in government is to reduce the compliance costs for taxpayers generally but for small business in particular. Senator Cook, in his comments on this bill—and I will come back to some of those—cried crocodile tears for small business, as if the Labor government of which he was a senior member had been the champions of small business during their years in office. As small business well knows, and as I think most Australians know—I know Senator Cook does not want to listen to this, but it is true—small business suffered more grievously under the burdens imposed by the Labor government than under any government in our history. So the Labor Party should not come in here in opposition and tell us about their advocacy of small business when they all but strangled it to death—and in fact did strangle thousands and thousands of small businesses into debt, bankruptcy and insolvency during their years in office.

One of the key issues on which the last election was fought was the question of which political party was best equipped to give small business the opportunity to breathe again, to grow again, to create more jobs, to create more income and wealth, so that the living standards of all Australians could be increased and improved after the depths to which they had sunk, particularly in the early 1990s, as a result of the most severe recession since the 1930s, which was brought on deliberately by the then Labor government. So let us not hear too much more hypocrisy from the Labor Party in relation to small business.

The main point that was raised by opposition speakers in the debate was the question of the uplift factor and the government's commitment to reducing the uplift factor to six per cent. There were allegations from both opposition speakers that somehow or other the coalition had broken its election promise to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor.

It is very interesting that opposition spokesmen do not really seem to be able to get their act together on this. They do not really know what they want to say. On 22 May, the assistant to the shadow Treasurer, Mr Latham, put out a press statement, the first sentence of which claimed:
The Federal Government has broken its promise to small business and self‐funded retirees to set the provisional tax uplift factor at a permanent rate of six per cent.
I will come back to that. On 14 June, however, Senator Cook, in one of the weakest press releases I have ever seen, said:

BREAK.PARA: Reducing the Tax Uplift Factor is one promise the Howard Government will keep, but very sneakily.

So while Senator Cook was saying that we have kept the promise, the shadow spokesman in this area, Mr Latham, said two or three weeks earlier that we were breaking the promise. The opposition needs to get its act together as to what it believes on this point.

The fact is that the coalition's commitment was confirmed in its policy document called A new deal for small business in which it gave a commitment `to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent'. It was never said by the coalition during the election campaign that we would permanently reduce the rate to six per cent. What we said, and what we are committed to, is having a provisional tax uplift factor regime which sets the uplift factor each year at a level which is more in line with the nominal growth in the economy. That is our long‐term commitment. So far as our specific election commitment is concerned, the commitment was to reduce the figure from eight per cent to six per cent. That is precisely what we have done and that is precisely what this legislation is all about.

Under a longstanding provision of the act—and I will go through the history just briefly—there is a so‐called default rate of 10 per cent. One would think, from listening to opposition speakers in this debate, that that was either something that had not existed before today or that a 10 per cent figure was something that had been fixed by this new government.

That is simply not the fact. The facts of the situation are that a default rate was established in the Income Tax Assessment Act, and I think I am correct in saying that it was in 1990. That rate was set by the then Labor government, the Hawke-Keating government, and it is a default factor which has existed ever since.So it was Labor that put the 10 per cent default rate into the act. For it now to say, `Let's reduce it,' is an extraordinary act of further hypocrisy, given that the default rate has been argued over in the ensuing years. Never did the then Labor government give any indication that it was prepared to consider varying that rate.

The fact is that the rate is essentially not operative, although it was the uplift factor that was provided in the first two years of operation under a default uplift factor. The provisional uplift factor that was set in 1990-91 and 1991-92 did coincide with the default uplift factor of 10 per cent. The uplift factor was reduced in 1992-93 to eight per cent and remained at eight per cent for the ensuing four years, including the year that we are now in, 1995-96.

That figure at eight per cent was set and maintained by the then Labor government, despite the attempts by the then opposition last year, the now government, to reduce the figure to six per cent. We, then in opposition, moved an amendment in the House of Representatives last year to have the uplift factor reduced from eight per cent to six per cent, and that was thrown completely out of court by the then Labor government.

The fact is that, so far as the operation of the default factor is concerned, there is never any particular reason, or likelihood for that matter, that the default uplift factor of 10 per cent will be the figure to be adopted. It has for many years been the prerogative of the parliament to determine each year what the uplift factor will be for the ensuing year. That is why the actual uplift factor for the last five or six years has been well below the default rate. It is a rate that only applies if for some unforeseen circumstance—and it is difficult to foresee such a circumstance—the parliament was unable to set an uplift rate for the following year. It has never happened in the past, and I can see no reason why it would happen in the future. Therefore, the default rate really is in many ways an irrelevancy.

But to reduce the rate, and I will say a little more on this in the committee stage, from 10 per cent to six per cent really does not seem to be a sensible way to go for any reason. In fact, it could well create more problems than it solves.

So far as the six per cent uplift factor is concerned, we believe that that is a figure which is more in line with the nominal growth of the economy. So long as we continue to have, and I stress this, a provisional tax regime, we believe that the provisional tax uplift factor should be—and it is always hard to judge these things in advance—closer to the nominal rate of growth of the economy.

That is what we are doing. That is what we undertook to do during the election campaign. We have completely met our election commitment and, despite what Labor spokesmen may say, it is a fact that it has been very widely welcomed by small business. Small business has not fallen for this trick that the Labor Party is trying to put around that somehow or other we are going to go back to 10 per cent next year. That is a nonsense. Everyone knows that, apart perhaps from those who have been peddling it on the opposition benches.

As I have foreshadowed, and I will say a little more in the committee stage, we will not be supporting the opposition amendment in relation to the default factor. I do welcome the fact—and I thank all senators for this fact—that the government has decided to meet its election commitment to assist the taxpayers of Australia who are subject to provisional tax. That includes most, if not all, of the small business people of Australia—the lifeblood of the Australian economy who in many ways have been squeezed for many years now by the former Labor government in terms of having too high a tax uplift factor. We have kept faith with them, and we will continue to do so in the future. So I thank speakers again, and I commend the bill again to the house. I am glad to see that it will have its second reading passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed in my speech in the second reading debate, I want to move the amendment that has been circulated in the chamber. I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (lines 5 to 11), omit the item, substitute:
1 Subsection 221YA(1)(definition of provisional tax uplift factor)

SPEECH.PARA: provisional tax uplift factor , in relation to a year of income, means, until the Parliament otherwise provides, 6%.

I do not intend to speak too long on this matter. I did outline the reasons why the Labor opposition is moving the amendment. As I said earlier, it is an absolute disgrace that the new government is breaking yet another promise. The coalition's policy made it very clear that the tax uplift factor would be six per cent, full stop. We are presented with some legislation which makes it clear that at the end of the year it goes back to 10 per cent, not eight per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are only jealous.
—Senator Calvert says we are only jealous. It is eight per cent at the moment, going down to six.
—That is right.

—Why are you putting it back up to 10 per cent? That is the intent of your legislation. You are an absolute disgrace. You have been in government for only three months and already you continue to break promises.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, we intend to save small business hundreds of millions of dollars over the two financial years prior to the next election, whenever it is scheduled. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, went all over the place around this country with a bleeding heart for small business, saying, `We will defend small business. We have a policy to reduce the uplift tax factor down to six per cent.'

TALK.START.PARA: —We have done it.

—You have done it for one year. With the support, I hope, of the Democrats, the Green senators and Senator Harradine, we are going to pass this amendment to keep you honest to your election commitments, to ensure that small business in this country is protected and looked after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to support this amendment.
—Of course you would.

—Of course we will. We tried to do it ourselves. We tried to get you to support it when we moved it before. I remember all the things Senator Watson said about `blocking supply' at the time I gave my speech in the second reading debate, but I do not need to revisit all that. Let us look at why it is appropriate. Back in 1990 when this was set, inflation was running at 7.7 per cent and average earnings were rising by about seven per cent. According to Treasury, in 1996‐97 inflation will be just three per cent, which is 4.7 per cent lower than it was in 1990, and average earnings will rise by just four per cent, three per cent lower than 1990. We are now in our 19th quarter of low inflationary growth and the likelihood of Australia returning to the high inflation days of the 1980s is becoming fairly remote. Thank goodness for that! So while the 10 per cent might have been appropriate in 1990, a six per cent figure is far more appropriate in 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: If things change dramatically, then you can come back to the parliament and ask us to review the rate, not just keep it there for one year so that you can put out a glorious press release and then do what you want the year after. Let us do what you said you wanted to do for small business, that is, put it in place permanently and come back to review it as you can prove that the circumstances warrant it, not the other way round.

We recognise that, if the uplift factor is set too low, there is scope for underpayment of tax. We will cooperate on that matter. We also recognise that, if the uplift factor is set at too high a level, obviously taxpayers pay too much—and that is what they have been doing. Relying on those Treasury figures, I do not think there is any reason why the government should vote against what the opposition are proposing in this amendment. I would like to hear their rationalisation. I heard Senator Watson's speech earlier. I have been here three times and heard what you lot have said on this matter. The last time you tried it was a great con—`Can't afford it, small business doesn't want it, it's blocking supply.' Come on! I hope you have something better to say about that this time.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say that it is curious to see the Labor Party in this debate. I do not think they have to remain in Coventry thinking, `We can't say this because we had a different position when we were in government.' It is good to see them proposing this amendment. I hope they are going to revisit a lot of other things they did in government, too, like privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main thing I want to revisit is the benches over there.

—You might if you keep going like this. You might convert the small business sector. It was interesting to hear the Prime Minister's attack in question time today. It was also interesting to hear Mr Beazley say that the opposition was going to introduce its own unconscionable conduct law, better business law.

BREAK.PARA: That is another commitment that you lot aren't going to honour, are you? What is your solution? A lot of words, a small business summit—as if they did not have enough of them, as if we do not know what the problems of small business are—and a few committees, and you are going to have the rely on the Labor opposition or the Democrats to introduce a bill which will protect small business from the unconscionable conduct of their big business end of town mates.

It is just too much for you to claim you are the friends of small business when you are not prepared to do anything more than introduce this one measure for one year. That is why I am supporting the opposition amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think people opposite should be reminded of the situation when Labor was actually in power. Under Labor, the provisional uplift factor exceeded the actual growth in income subject to provisional tax in every year between 1991 and 1994-95. The provisional uplift factor was set by previous Labor governments at eight per cent for each of the last four years, including 1994-95. There was no justification for such a high figure either by the government or by the Treasury officials at committee hearings.

BREAK.PARA: The level of aggregate income that should be subject to provisional tax can be difficult to predict. Therefore, in regard to the uplift factor, for subsequent years after 1996-97, the coalition government will set it when the most accurate information is available. What is wrong with that? It will be set at what is a realistic figure rather than at the unrealistic figures that your government set, Senator Sherry, when you had that absolute grab for money, when you used every piece of legislation available to try to bring forward the timing of the tax collections. So don't be hypocritical now in relation to what is happening.

We are going to set the figure as accurately as possible at the time when the information is available. It is going to be set at what is going to be a realistic growth factor so that small business, which also includes self-funded retirees who are also subject to provisional uplift factors, can all be treated fairly. Of all the people under your administration, Senator Sherry, it was self-funded retirees who suffered the greatest discrimination, and these are the people who are going to get fairness and justice under our system because they will be brought into a tax regime that is equivalent to the thresholds that apply to the full pensioners.

So we will not lock people into a situation in which they may be penalised because of changing economic circumstances but rather set a rate which is a reasonable reflection of the growth of the income of provisional taxpayers. This is precisely what your government failed to do year after year, to your disgrace. So for the 1996-97 financial year a reasonable figure will be set in relation to the economic expectations of the time. I support the stand made by my colleague Senator Short. I reject the arguments as well as the amendment that have been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson, I have to remind you, after that little outburst of rhetoric, what the truth was about what happened last time. You accused Labor, and rightly, of the unfair level at which the uplift factor was set and the information we had in the last couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: When we put those arguments to the Senate, what did you do the first time? You said, `Oh! Can't vote for it, sorry' for all of those spurious reasons. What did you do the second time? After you were embarrassed because of the pressure of COSBOA, the small business coalition and others, what did you do? You came with us, Senator Watson, and what happened? You refused to press the amendment when it came back. That was your commitment to small business. So please let us not rewrite the record.

All of the reasons you gave are very valid and they are valid this time, too. What you did not address was: if it is a reasonable rate now, why can't it go for more than one year? You did not address that at all. We can have accurate figures next year as we have this year and as we had last year and the year before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson gave a splendid speech in support of our amendment. It was a splendid speech, Senator, and I invite you to come over here and vote with us, along with all of your other colleagues who, over the years, made speech after speech about the uplift factor. It was a splendid speech, Senator Watson. It is a pleasure for the Labor opposition to congratulate a government member for his contribution in supporting us on this amendment. It really is a pleasure. As I said earlier, you should be down on the front bench, dealing with these tax matters, because we would get some accurate information.
—You are making him blush.

—I am making you blush. Senator, you said that the figure is being set in accordance with the economic expectations of the time. Unless you are very pessimistic over there about inflation going up to five or six per cent or you know economic forecasts that you are not telling us, not that you are telling us much anyway in question time or anywhere else, if economic expectations are what they are as a result of the legacy of our government—very good eco nomic growth, very low inflation, the highest job growth in 20 years; all of the great economic legacies we left you—then what better time to lock in the six per cent figure to help small business and self-funded retirees.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, this will return over the two financial years 1997-98 and 1998-99 a total of $540 million to the constituency that you claim to represent—small business and self-funded retirees.

It will be with great pride that I will go out representing the Labor opposition—it is good to see Senator Boswell; I hope you are going to cross the floor, too—to the small farming communities, to the small businesses and self-funded retirees, and remind them of this. I will give due credit to Senator Kernot and the Democrats for helping support us in returning $540 million to those essential areas of the small business economy and self-funded retirees. I am new to this position. I have been in this position for three months and I am enjoying it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look as though you are.

—I am enjoying it because I care about small business and I care about self-funded retirees. It is a real pleasure to be here supporting them as the opposition spokesperson responsible for this matter. We will be reminding them in three years when the election comes, if that is when it is held, of what we have done in the Senate to protect their interests. We will remind them of what you did—how you have broken your promise and how John Howard, with his hand on his heart, and Peter Costello and Senator Short and Senator Boswell did this. We will remind them about how you have broken a promise—to rip off $540 million from them. That is $540 million which, with great pride, we vote today to return to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry might be enjoying his job but, by gee, he deals very lightly with the truth in this place. He knows full well that what he has just put to the Senate is not true. He knows full well that the government, proposing the bill that we are, is not in any way saying that next year the rate will go back to 10 per cent. He knows that absolutely full well, and small business knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am absolutely amazed that Senator Sherry should be prepared to deal so lightly with the truth on such an important matter as to so totally mislead the provisional taxpayers of this country, in particular small business. He professes to be a supporter of small business. I say again, as Senator Watson has—I said this in summing up the second reading debate—that if any government ever was guilty of absolutely slaughtering small business in its whole range of policies, tax and other, during its period in office, it was the Hawke‐Keating Labor governments of which Senator Sherry was a member.
