Small business knows the situation. Small business knows that your government killed small business. It sent tens of thousands of small businesses broke, bankrupt, insolvent. You did it year in and year out. You did it as a result of the most incompetent government, financial and economic management that this country has seen virtually throughout its history. For you now to be coming in and parading yourself as the champion of small business is hypocrisy at its highest level.

I come back to the facts of the situation. In response to Senator Kernot's comments, last year it was the coalition opposition that first moved the amendment to reduce the uplift factor for 1995-96 from eight per cent to six per cent. We did it in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you press it when it came back?

—It is true that we did not press it when it came back here the second time. Do you know why we did not press it? There was the real risk that you would have finished up with an uplift factor this year of 10 per cent because the Labor government was not going to accept that amendment. To have rejected it twice would have meant that the tax uplift factor for 1995-96 would have been 10 per cent. Whilst we supported the reduction to six per cent and whilst we urged the government to do so, the fact that the then Labor government was not prepared to accept that amendment meant that the uplift factor would have been 10 per cent. I am surprised that you were not aware of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the claims by Senator Sherry that we have broken our promises in relation to the commitment to reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. He was not here when I spoke earlier so he may not be aware of the complete confusion within the government's own ranks on this issue. On 22 May, the shadow Assistant Treasurer, Mr Latham, put out a statement saying:
The federal government has broken its promise to small business and self-funded retirees to set the provisional tax uplift factor at a permanent rate of six per cent.
He used the word `permanent' there, which was absolutely an untruth because the coalition never said `permanent'. First of all he said that we had broken our promise.

He then went on later in his release to quote the coalition's statement in its policy paper `A New Deal for Small Business', which said that we promised to `reduce the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent'. That seems to us precisely what we are now doing. But Senator Peter Cook just three or four weeks later—on 14 June, last week—put out a statement the first sentence of which was: `Reducing the tax uplift factor is one promise the Howard government will keep.' In other words, Senator Cook is saying that we have kept the promise. Mr Latham is apparently saying that we have not. But you all know full well that we have kept the promise because our commitment was to reduce the uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. That is precisely what we have done. To suggest that it is going to go back to 10 per cent next year, as Senator Sherry has done, is a total distortion of the truth. I am pleased to see that Senator Sherry has a little accepting smile on his face.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I am not smiling at your response and your comments; I am smiling at Senator Collins here and the conversation we are engaged in.

—It did not look like it to me, but I will let that one go. The coalition announced during the election campaign that it would reduce the provisional tax uplift factor to a level which is more in line with nominal growth in the economy. That is our long-term undertaking. That is what we want to do and that is what we will do. That is why this year we have reduced the figure from eight per cent to six per cent. That is what everyone seems to want. The only question at issue seems to be in relation to what you do with the default rate. The proposition that you reduce the default rate now seems to us to have little if any merit because it is too far out to be able to assess the validity or the usefulness of that default rate.

SPEECH.PARA: So you do not achieve anything at all by the measure that the opposition is proposing. For that reason we will not support the opposition amendment. We will maintain our total commitment to the provisional taxpayers of Australia so long as we continue to have a provisional tax regime to set the rate each year when we are better informed as to what the outcome and the prospects for growth in the economy over the year ahead will be, to set the rate as near as we reasonably can at the nominal rate of growth. Fiddling around with the default rate has no relevance to that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that there has been some misunderstanding, perhaps, in listeners' minds as a result of the sorts of issues that have been raised in the debate today. The government is delivering 100 per cent on its election commitment to reduce the uplift factor from eight to six per cent for the provisional year 1996‐97. The concept of a default provision has been around for a number of years, as the opposition well knows. I regret that Senator Kernot in her deliberations and reflections on last year's amendment was a little confused. The amendment related not to the default option but to the actual rate for the current year. My recollection was that the Democrat amendment, which had a lot of attraction, was not the default provision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate heard that Treasury officials at committee hearings were unable to actuarially support the eight per cent. It was the former government's tremendous grab for extra money and the bringing forward of the timing of taxes that were the determinants. The Keating government said that if the Senate pressed the amendment the government would exercise the default option of 10 per cent. The opposition, which was the Liberal Party at the time—knowing Keating's grab for money—was not prepared to place small business at the risk of a default option of the order of 10 per cent and backed down. Senator Kernot well knows why we did not press the amendment that was moved in the House of Representatives and debated here. The Keating government said in no uncertain terms: `If you press this issue, you will have to carry the cross for the additional provisional tax that small business will have to pay.'

We have honoured our commitment 100 per cent. We are delivering on that commitment 100 per cent. We have said that next year and subsequent years we will set that figure annually as it applies to the next year in relation to the prevailing economic circumstances so it can realistically reflect the increase in economic activity and in taxable income and so that there is not this grab for money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson wants to rewrite history again.
—Are you two going to do this all night?

—No, I hope this is the last thing I am saying, Senator Collins. The foreign minister is running around the world trying to rewrite the foreign policy of this country for the last decade. In here we are seeing a little bit of revisionism, too. You have to take one opportunity to at least challenge it.

SPEECH.PARA: Although Senator Watson says the reason the former opposition did not press the amendment was because big, tough Paul Keating was going to threaten them and say, `Look, we're going to exercise the default option,' I can remember the politics of the time. The politics of the time were about an opposition with leadership problems who were doing whatever they could to avoid double dissolutions and being difficult.

What did you change your mind on? Migration bills. You said, `Sorry, we had to change our mind on that one because Mr Keating might take that to an election.' What about the land fund bill? You said, `Sorry, we had to change our mind on that one, too. We can't press the amendments on the land fund bill because Mr Keating might take that to an election as well.' This is the same. This is what this was about as well. It was about the politics. It was not about Mr Keating's threat. It was about the politics. You were backing away at a rate of knots from giving any kind of trigger at all that might have caused a double dissolution.

However, the politics of now mean that here we are debating again. That is great. The politics of now mean that we have got a really constructive amendment from the opposition, so let's get on with it. Let's pass it. Let's send it to the House of Representatives and let's see what they do, but let's tell them that we intend to press it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not agree with Senator Kernot more. It is pleasing to see Senator Ferguson walk into the chamber. He is the chair of the Economics Committee. Are you leaving now?
—I couldn't yell at you from down there.

—I thought you were going to cross the floor and vote with us. I quoted you extensively earlier in the debate, Senator Ferguson. I quoted the fine words and fine contribution you have made over the past few years on this issue, pointing out that the provisional uplift factor should be reduced.
—That is precisely what we have done. It is what the bill is about.

—You are doing it for one year. As I pointed out earlier, the coalition's policy and new deal for small business is that the provisional tax uplift factor will be reduced by two per cent to six per cent, which is more in line with the nominal growth in the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: But what do you present us with today? A bill for one year only. What happens beyond that? Labor is making sure we assist small business and self-funded retirees. That is what we are making sure of today. We are going to lock in the six per cent maximum; we are going to lock it in as a maximum. If the growth rate in the economy continues at current pace, which is very good—a great legacy from Labor—and if the inflation rate continues as low it is, then perhaps this should go lower in future years, not higher as you are proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not proposing that.

—Your proposal is to leave it on the never-never; you are saying, `Let's look at it in a year when we need more money.' What we got last week at the Premiers Conference was another breach of election commitments. You said that there would be no new taxes and no expansion of existing taxes. What did the Treasurer dish up to us last week? A $1.2 billion new sales tax, Senator Watson. You should all be ashamed of yourselves. You should be crossing the floor to support us on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I was not here to hear Senator Sherry's earlier contribution, but I had an important meeting which obviously was more important than the contribution you made. Let me say, Senator Sherry, it is very intriguing to hear you come in here and say that the provisional uplift factor should be reduced to six per cent, and should stay there. What about your own attitude last year? You said eight per cent. We were quite prepared to come down to six per cent last year, but where was Senator Sherry?
—It wasn't our policy; it is your policy.

—It was not your policy. Well, if it was good enough for you last year to suggest that it should only be eight per cent, we have gone further than that. Your policy always meant that it should revert to 10 per cent at the end of each subsequent year, to be reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: You will remember, Senator Sherry, if you took the trouble to read the report of the committee, which looked into the taxation treatment of small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent report; good report.
—It was a very good report.
—It was a Democrat reference.

—The initial reference was from the Democrats, but let me tell you that the terms of reference were expanded quite a great deal before we referred it to the committee. I concede, Senator Kernot, that the initial reference was relating to uplift factor only. By the time that report was finally put down, it dealt with a lot of other very important issues besides the uplift factor and how small business in this country should be treated. What we said prior to the election was that we would be reducing the uplift factor to six per cent, and we are going to do it.
—I quoted you. For one year; that's all you are proposing.
—In 12 months time, if the situation is the same, I am quite sure that the people involved in the Treasury will make sure it is still at six per cent, if the conditions are still the same.
—Economic conditions are going to get worse under you, are they?

—Senator Sherry, you ought to know and remember the decisions that you made when you were on this side of the chamber last year. We wanted to reduce the uplift factor to six per cent because it more reflected the CPI. We would have liked to have gone down further, but we knew the impact that it was going to have on the government revenue, and for that reason we agreed that it should be six per cent.
—And Keating's threat!

—I understand Keating's threat. We knew the impact it would have on revenue, and for that reason we said no, we will only take it down to six per cent; otherwise it would have too big an impact on the budget projections. You would not even come at that. Eight per cent was the most you would come down to when the CPI and the inflation factor were far lower. Eight per cent was as far as you would go.

BREAK.PARA: You ought to remember that, because we wanted it to go to six per cent. In our pre-election promise we said we would bring it down to six per cent, and we are bringing it down to six per cent. It will be reviewed again in 12 months time, just as you used to review it every 12 months, except that when you were in government you would not even consider bringing it down to eight per cent. I can still remember when it was 10 per cent. Small businesses suffered by paying 10 per cent, particularly those with uncertain incomes who were not capable of putting in an adjusted provisional tax return because they could not estimate their income to the extent that they could be sure they would fall within that small limit of error that you are allowed to have in providing an additional return for provisional tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 10 per cent now, Senator Ferguson.
—It is 10 per cent in the legislation, but we are reducing it to six per cent.
—All I am saying is that you don't even need a very long memory.

—You don't need a long memory, but you as a government did not reduce it from 10 per cent for those years. You ought to be ashamed of your own actions in government. The actions that we are taking to bring it down to six per cent for this year ought to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to continue this evening with a topic that I had commenced this afternoon in the debate on matters of public interest—what is happening to the Australian Geological Survey Organisation. I want to go on beyond that, in the time I have tonight, to talk about some of the other attacks on regional programs and regional organisations by this government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Geological Survey Organisation, as I mentioned earlier, is a Public Service body. It underpins Australia's internationally competitive energy and mineral resources industries by maintaining a high quality geoscience knowledge and skills base. I get that definition and wording from the coalition's 1996 resources policy statement. But we now discover that they are going to have something like a 27 to 30 per cent cut in their staff numbers. We are going to be losing that skills base.

The coalition policy states that this is the organisation that provides baseline information and related services to the mining industry and is crucial for the maintenance of an attractive regime for investment in Australian minerals and energy exploration and development.

This government—the same government that four or five months ago was making this statement—is in fact going against what they spoke of in their policy statement. They have obviously just forgotten the value of this organisation. We know, from media reports in the Australian, in the New Scientist and in some other very reputable journals, that the industry itself is very concerned. Everybody in this country recognises the value of the mining and resources industry to this nation. It also has a major benefit to people in regional areas of Australia because that is where the majority of our minerals are.

The maps that are provided benefit not only the mining industry but also land management. This is the government that wants to flog off one‐third of Telstra and put a billion dollars for an indefinite period into the environment because they consider it to be of concern. They want to remove the capacity of AGSO to be able to provide the mapping on which they can base land management in this country. That is absolutely ridiculous. It is a double standard. It is a false economy because the more information we have about the land and the geological make‐up of this country, the better we will be able to manage our land, the more we will know precisely where our mineral resources are and the better we will be able to assist the farming community as well to cope with things like dry land salinity caused by rising water tables.

We are discovering that when water is put into some of our natural geological formations salt is leached into the surrounding countryside and surrounding areas. It becomes vitally important that we continue to know where these areas are. The more research and data we have, the better we will be able to manage our natural countryside. But this government obviously does not care about that.

AGSO provides a base information line from which organisations and companies are able to go out and research. I spoke earlier today about the Newcrest mine at Cadia in the central west. Anyone who read the Sunday papers would have seen the two‐page article on this project and the benefit and value that it is going to bring to the community.

There are other mineral deposits being discovered in other areas of central western New South Wales. I know that AGSO has also been involved in a joint project with the governments of South Australia and New South Wales in the Broken Hill area. They had a plan for a five‐year mapping program. That has been reduced to 2½ years.

Anybody who is familiar with the area of Broken Hill and with Broken Hill itself will be aware that that ore body is decreasing, it is running out. We need to undertake as much research as possible to provide baseline data to encourage and to facilitate the entry of mining companies into further exploration in that area. If we do not, I think that we are going to be criminally negligent in not providing the people in that community with the possibility of further development in the mining industry for which they have the infrastructure and the skills base and for which they are rightly very proud.

Broken Hill several years ago suffered a major problem when Pasminco closed one of the mining shafts because of inaccessibility and low commodity prices. We have to make sure that we do not lose the rest of Broken Hill. If you have cutting of funds to the joint project of the state and the federal governments and cutting back of the project from five years to 2½ years, you have to realise that you will have less information.

Of course, you have to add to that the fact that the skillshares out there are being cut. They do not know what is going to happen to the CES offices. All this erosion of services and facilities in these areas will have a major impact upon these communities. I urge people to be very conscious of the impact that the reduction of funding for, and the reduction of staff numbers at, the Australian Geological Survey Organisation is going to have on people in that particular area.

Another thing that is under threat is the CSIRO station at Chiswick, near Armidale. This involves the CSIRO's animal production division, which has done a lot of research on, and has given support to, the merino wool industry. People are aware that the wool industry is suffering pretty tough times at present. The last thing that they need is to lose this CSIRO research facility at Chiswick.

The research facility ties in and works very closely with the cooperative development centre at the University of New England, at Armidale. There is a synergy between the two organisations. You are getting the scientists and research fellows from both organisations working together and working for the benefit of the local area and for the benefit of the primary producers and the woolgrowers in the area.

During the election campaign, the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said that he would guarantee that this particular establishment would stay open. However, on reading the local media in recent times, it has become quite apparent that he is unable to give that guarantee. He should never have given the guarantee, because he is unable to deliver the guarantee. He, like everybody else, is having to wait to see what the outcome is going to be.

I noticed in the Armidale Express of the 10th of this month that he has urged community support. I would also urge the community around the area and those involved in rural production—the New South Wales Farmers Association and organisations like that—to do as he says, to get in and support the maintenance and the retention of the CSIRO establishment at Chiswick. It is vitally important.

I note also in an editorial from the Armidale Express that they are also saying that it is time for `Sinkers' to get stuck in. In fact, they are calling on him to do something and to make sure that his government, the government of which he is a member, does not close this establishment. It would be to the detriment of the primary producers, to those who are involved in the research and to those who are involved in the nearby University of New England. These sorts of facilities in rural Australia are vitally important. They are just two instances of what is going to be cut by the current government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Association for UNICEF met today to elect office bearers for the term of the new parliament. I wish to congratulate the new president of the association, Mrs Kathy Sullivan, a Liberal member of parliament, and I wish her every success in this important role. Larry Anthony from the National Party was elected secretary of the association, and Australian Democrats Senator‐elect Lyn Allison is our new Treasurer. I remain with the association in the role of vice‐president.

SPEECH.PARA: As is traditional, the office bearers reflect the all‐party cooperation which has always existed in the association. The Parliamentary Association for UNICEF was formed nine years ago and is a group of parliamentarians who support the aim and the work of the United Nations Children's Fund. UNICEF has a long history of providing practical assistance to women and children in the world's poorest countries and is actively involved in areas such as immunisation, literacy programs and seed loans to allow poor families to become economically self-sufficient.

Often when we see images of starving children on television, or hear the statistics of high infant mortality caused by preventable diseases, we feel helpless. The 30‐second news grab that focuses on death or disaster gives us no insight into the good work being done by agencies around the world such as UNICEF, nor do these news grabs convey the fact that not only is progress possible but is actually happening.

Tonight I want to talk about the 1996 UNICEF report, The progress of nations. The report was launched just last week in Sydney by Justice Marcus Einfeld. The progress of nations monitors the achievements of countries around the world in meeting commitments they made at the historic 1990 World Summit for Children. Countries are ranked each year according to the progress they have made in a number of areas including immunisation, poverty, malnutrition, education of girls, health services for women and maternal health.

The good news from The progress of nations report is that immunisation is saving the lives of three million children each year. In 1980, 20 per cent of children in the developing world were immunised. Today the figure is 80 per cent. Oral rehydration therapy—that is, the sugar and salt mixture—saves one million children's lives each year. These sachets are one of the cheapest ways possible to save human life. They cost only $1 for seven packets—seven lives saved for just $1. Yet without this basic care many children die of simple diarrhoea.

BREAK.PARA: The progress made in immunisation and primary health care has occurred in less than one generation. Five million fewer children die each year from the preventable diseases. Fewer children are blinded, crippled or mentally retarded from preventable diseases such as polio.

But, of course, the news is not all good. In poor countries, eight million children still die each year of preventable causes such as measles, diarrhoea, malaria, pneumonia and malnutrition. That is about the total population of New South Wales and Queensland. I must stress that these diseases are preventable. Many can be treated by simple remedies such as oral rehydration therapy, which I mentioned earlier. Others can be inoculated against. Some $75 is enough to save 200 children from blindness with vitamin A supplements, and $26 can buy blankets for 10 small children.

Most children who die, die of five easily treated conditions—measles, diarrhoea, malaria, pneumonia and malnutrition—and 80 per cent of children brought to health centres in developing countries are suffering from one of these five conditions. Eight million children die each year of these causes. Measles kills more people than AIDS. Respiratory infections claim more lives than cancer. Community health workers in these countries can be trained in just 11 days to save these young lives. With 14 basic drugs and referral services, these health workers can successfully meet the needs of 80 per cent of the children brought to local clinics and health centres.

The progress of nations also addresses maternal death. About 600,000 women die in pregnancy and childbirth around the world each year leaving one million orphans. Many of these maternal deaths are preventable. The progress of nations report states that `for every woman who dies, approximately 30 more incur injuries, infections and disabilities . . . maternal mortality and morbidity . . . is the most neglected tragedy of our times'.

Malnutrition continues to be a problem. Half the world's malnourished children are in Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. Some 67 per cent of Bangladeshi children are malnourished. About 700 children can be fed for $105 worth of high protein biscuits, and $45 will buy a week's supply of unimix cereal for 35 children. It is obvious what just a few dollars can do, yet aid spending is at a 20‐year low. Each year since the end of the Cold War, $250 billion less has been spent on weapons yet, tragically, little of the `peace dividend' has been channelled to the world's neediest people. Aid has only increased $1 billion per year in real terms.

Much of the public attention given to The progress of nations report has focused on the issue of child poverty. Child poverty in the industrialised world varies from three per cent in the Nordic countries to 22 per cent in the United States. The progress of nations report says, `In all industrialised nations for which information is available, children in solo‐mother families are at greater risk of poverty.'

The good news about child poverty is that government action can save children from poverty. In 11 of the 18 developed countries surveyed, government action has cut poverty in half. Currently in the United States groups such as Stand for Children are working towards cutting the child poverty rate in that country. About 10,000 concerned citizens marched on Washington calling for continued government support for welfare programs which address the needs of poor children. Children have become a political issue in Washington.

Australia, along with Canada and Ireland, has a child poverty rate of more than 10 per cent. In Australia, half the children living in poverty have single mothers. We must continue to address poverty in Australia and we must be ever vigilant against attacks on our society or its social welfare safety net. It is shocking that a country with as many resources and as much wealth as Australia has any child poverty. It is an indictment on all Australians that we have such a figure.

I do not have time to develop the issue tonight but we as parliamentarians must continue in our bipartisan search for practical solutions. The future of children is too important for any cheap point scoring.

Finally, as Senator David Brownhill, who is the secretary of UNICEF, is in the chamber, I place on record my thanks for his work for UNICEF in the last nine years. I also thank my colleague from the Australian Democrats, Senator Robert Bell, who for quite a long period of time has had the job of being treasurer of UNICEF and has discharged that duty with great aplomb.

I am particularly pleased that Senator‐elect Lyn Allison, who will be following me here as a senator for Victoria, is taking an active role on the committee. SPEECH.PARA: In this debate on the adjournment I want to speak about the revised second edition of a report on human rights abuses against the people of Bougainville compiled by Marilyn Havini. Titled, A Compilation of Human Rights Abuses Against the People of Bougainville 1989 to 1996, Vol. 2, the report is also known as `Marilyn's List'. I give notice that at the end of my contribution I will seek to table the report. It has been shown to all parties in the Senate and agreement for tabling has been obtained.

The report has some 55 pages of incidents, including people being killed, tortured, wounded and raped. It is a horrendous report. It is one that we should take note of, seeing that the incidents it describes have occurred in our region. We must take every action that we can to reduce these horrible crimes.
I can do no better than to read into Hansard the foreword written by Dr John Ward, the New South Wales co‐ordinator of the Medical Association for the Prevention of War. It runs as follows:

To the near north of Australia lie three of the world's many conflict‐ridden countries—Bougainville, East Timor and West Papua. They contain some of the most spectacular beauty and most productive land in the world and should be areas of peace, culture and sustainability.

It is not a coincidence that each contains a resource in great demand in the affluent world—copper in Bougainville; gold in West Papua; oil in the Timor Gap. The rapaciousness of the mining companies and the colonial governments which support them, including militarily, leaves no room for the limited aspirations of the indigenous peoples.

Attempts by the indigenous peoples to protect their environment and culture and to benefit from the resource exploitation of their land have resulted in violent repression. This has been most brutal and calculated in East Timor where approximately 20 per cent of the population have been killed by the Indonesian military forces over the past two decades.

In Bougainville, the killings clearly number thousands but, in addition, the surviving population is forced to live in the most difficult circumstances. Normal food production is sabotaged, resulting in starvation and undernourishment. Health services are almost non‐existent with no doctors, few nurses and virtually no medicines. Many people have been forced away from their villages into the more sheltered mountains, often living in caves. Unfortunately, among the many international trouble spots, Bougainville is of little strategic importance to the major global powers and rates little attention in international fora. The undisciplined PNG military forces are allowed to perpetrate their crimes with little international condemnation.

Marilyn Havini is one of a number of brave, dedicated individuals who work tirelessly to call the attention of the world to the tragic situation in Bougainville. Her documentation of human rights abuses in Bougainville has been an invaluable resource for politicians, negotiators and activists for the present and, hopefully, a record for addressing justice issues in the future.

Australians, in particular, cannot turn a blind eye to the tragedy of Bougainville. Apart from its proximity, Australia is the country with the closest ties to PNG and its major military ally. We provide military advisors and equipment which have, undoubtedly, contributed to the skills and resources of PNG forces in Bougainville. The use of Australian‐made Iroquois helicopters as gun ships and for the disposal of bodies at sea is the most infamous example of our complicity.

It is hard to understand how we have allowed this previously beautiful, abundant, peaceful country to be reduced to terror, impoverishment and disease. It is only possible while we maintain the delusion that Bougainvilleans are, some how, different and less human than ourselves.

The real truth is that it is the perpetrators of this tragedy, and the people who stand aside and allow it to continue who are less than human, not the unfortunate victims. Even less human is the system of greed and overconsumption that places more importance on resources than people.

I hope that the production of this second volume of Marilyn's list jolts the world out of its apathy and forces the PNG Government to seek a peaceful resolution of the conflict. The people of Bougainville have suffered too much and must be allowed to return to their villages, families and peace.

If we cannot resolve this conflict, it augurs poorly for the next century when countries will be disputing over scarce resources such as water and energy. The future of humanity is bleak unless we face the true nature of the behaviour which lies just below our thin veneer of morality.
I believe that those words are a fitting foreword to this report.

In conclusion, I wish to acknowledge the work of Senator Christabel Chamarette on this issue. Senator Chamarette tabled the first edition of this work and I know she remains strongly supportive of the campaign for peace pursued so relentlessly and at great personal sacrifice by Marilyn and Moses Havini and their colleagues. I commend the document to the Senate and seek leave to table it.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I come to the chamber tonight to discuss a matter which I have discussed on previous occasions, and that is the collapse of the Aust‐Home Investments scheme which ran in Queensland some years ago, and which was the subject of investigation by the Australian Securities Commission. The comments I am making in this place tonight I am making here for one reason, which is that I cannot make these comments outside this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been forced to come into the chamber to make these comments because of the number of people who have written to me asking me my opinion of the conduct of the promoters of the scheme. I would have liked to be able to write to those people personally but I cannot do that because, if I do write to those people personally in reply, I could be guilty of defamation because, in the state of Queensland, truth is not a defence to an action of defamation. I want all honourable senators to know why I have gone to this step to do this tonight.

PARA.BREAK: What I intend to do is not give a detailed history of the collapse of Aust‐Home Invest ments and its investigation, but rather give a potted history and pick up the essential problems that existed with this group, with the investigation, and highlight to honourable senators the fact that the people who were behind this scheme are now promoting a similar scheme in New South Wales, aimed at ripping off innocent investors in the coalfields of the Hunter Valley.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aust‐Home Investments scheme arose out of something called the Queensland growth investment scheme, which was an incorporated association which was used by the promoters to encourage people to make contributions to a scheme and seek a tax deduction. It was supposed to be a negatively geared scheme so that people notionally borrowed from a finance company money that was then lent to another company within the group. It was a non-recourse loan and they claimed a deduction in their tax liability for the interest servicing costs. That scheme was closed down. The promoters then rolled it over into a group of companies collectively known as the Aust‐Home Investments scheme. There were a number of companies in this scheme.

In many cases, people claimed tax deduction on the basis of an interest liability which they met. They never actually put up the principal sum that was notionally borrowed, but they did pay the interest and they paid the interest through deductions from their wages. Many of the people who were inveigled into this scheme were coalminers in central Queensland. Other people were dragged into the scheme because the promoters had infiltrated the charismatic churches in Brisbane. Most of the investors, as I said, put up their money because they paid interest on notional loans from the finance company that were on‐lent into the investment company. Some unfortunate investors actually parted with sums of money that were principal, that were capital, as well as paying interest on notional loans.

The promoters came under investigation by the Australian Securities Commission and the investors were also subject to investigation by the Australian Taxation Office. I have discussed this matter in some detail before. Suffice it to say the investigation by the Australian Securities Commission was seriously flawed. It led to a Senate inquiry and that Senate inquiry by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee found substantial failings in the investigative conduct of the Australian Securities Commission. The Australian Securities Commission has amended its conduct in many ways, but not all of the recommendations of the Senate committee were picked up by the previous government.

The promoters of that scheme have infiltrated the fighting fund that was set up by the investors when the scheme collapsed. The fighting fund was set up for one purpose: to represent the investors against attempts by the Australian Taxation Office to make the investors liable for penalties, as though the investors knew that the scheme in which they had put their money was a fake.

The truth is that investors did not know. They honestly believed that there were millions of dollars of investments. The truth was that there were not millions of dollars in investments and the money that those investors paid, which was notionally interest, was skimmed off by the promoters and used for their own purposes. It was a dreadful abuse of those people's trust. So a fighting fund was set up. Through efforts that I had made and through efforts of the fighting fund, an agreement was reached with the Australian Taxation Office that eliminated many of those penalties. Many of the investors were still liable for substantial sums of money to the Taxation Office—but not the penalties.

The promoters have infiltrated that fighting fund and are using it to promote the view that there was nothing wrong with Aust‐Home Investments. Nothing could be further from the truth. This scheme was a sham and the intent of the promoters was fraudulent. The promoters, however, have used the fighting fund and the resources of the fighting fund to tell the investors that there was nothing wrong with the scheme because the promoters were never charged.

I want to tell the Senate the reason why the promoters were never charged. It is because the Australian Securities Commission bungled the investigation, and all of the evidence that was obtained was obtained under derivative immunity. In other words, they got the evidence because the directors produced information or confessed to certain things. But, because of the derivative immunity rule that existed in the Corporations Law at the time, that evidence could not be used in a court of law to prosecute those men.

That is the only reason why the promoters of this scheme were not prosecuted. It is not because they were innocent; it is because the investigation was bungled. That is why I said in the Senate last year that the scheme was essentially fraudulent, not that the investors had a fraudulent intent. In fact, the investors were the victims. The intent of the promoters was fraudulent. I hope that sets the record straight for the investors who have been writing to me.

Now let me move on. One of those promoters, a Mr Trevor Bell, is an undischarged bankrupt as a result of his involvement in the scheme. However, in spite of being an undischarged bankrupt, Mr Bell directs the operations of a similar fraudulent scheme in New South Wales in the Hunter Valley called the Pioneers Trust. He uses the same modus operandi, which is to infiltrate the coalmines and get the coalminers and their families to pay up money which is, theoretically, interest on notional loans which, as far as I can see, do not exist.

He has told the investors in New South Wales, `Do not provide any information to the Australian Securities Commission because they will victimise you.' He has used the unfortunate experience of investors in Queensland, who suffered as a result of a bungled ASC investigation the first time round, to keep those investors from disclosing what they know to the Australian Securities Commission. I understand that Mr Bell is still an undischarged bankrupt and is likely to remain an undischarged bankrupt for a long period of time because of his conduct.

It is also, of course, an offence under the Bankruptcy Act to be involved in the promotion, formation or management of a company—and a company, I understand, is involved in this trust—even if you are not a director, whilst being an undischarged bankrupt. I also believe that the nature of the fund, which he controls through telling the trustees what to do, is fraudulent and is just as flawed as the Aust‐Home scheme. If it is ultimately exploded by the Australian Securities Commission or the ATO, it could lead to substantial tax liabilities on investors.

I urge any investor who has any information about the Pioneers Trust to make that information available to the Australian Securities Commission as a matter of urgency. I also urge them to be extremely wary of Mr Bell. His conduct has left many people substantially worse off. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this adjournment debate to refer to drought exceptional circumstances in the Upper Hunter. The Senate will recall on many occasions through 1994 and 1995 that I pointed out repeatedly the failure of the former Labor government to address this matter. But it was too little too late. It was almost the end of the drought before they finally gave any assistance at all.

SPEECH.PARA: In the other place the other night, the member for Hunter, Joel Fitzgibbon, took to revising history on this matter. I think he largely did this to square‐off some of his father's failings in this area when he was the member for Hunter. The minister for primary industries has revoked some areas for exceptional circumstances drought, and the rural lands protection board in the Upper Hunter has taken off the areas of Denman, Singleton and Scone but left in Merriwa parts A, B and C.

Joel Fitzgibbon used this adjustment to the coverage of the scheme to evoke unnecessary fear amongst farmers in the Upper Hunter. The speech was a dishonest presentation only telling half the truth. The reality is that Merriwa does stay in under exceptional circumstances. For the other areas—and this is the important point—Commonwealth assistance for eligible farmers will remain for the following six months. This includes drought relief payment for living expenses, interest subsidies of up to 100 per cent and Austudy benefits by the exclusion of on‐farm assets from the assets test. The Howard government is providing these benefits to Upper Hunter farmers for a further six months and aid to Merriwa indefinitely.

We recognise that drought recovery is not instantaneous, and our government has set up a special rural task force, announced by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to address ongoing assistance to farmers when household support ends. What the member for Hunter has said is misleading, and it has created unnecessary anxiety for farmers in the Upper Hunter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 18 April 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Could individuals, companies or corporations offering services as `student recruitment agents' be made subject to a licensing or an accreditation scheme through the Australian International Education Foundation.

(2) Have universities, TAFE colleges or private education providers set in place any code of conduct or self-regulation to oversee the provision of services to overseas students enrolling at Australian institutions.

(3) Will investigations along the following lines be undertaken into allegations concerning certain service practices which are `ripping off' overseas students coming to Australia: (a) are some students being charged to fill out enrolment applications when in fact universities make no charge for this procedure; (b) are some student recruitment agencies advising students on study options when they have no capacity or qualifications to offer advice in this area; (c) how prevalent is the practice of influencing students to transfer from one institution to another institution, sometimes after little more than a semester of study, so that the agent can gain a commission from each new enrolment; and (d) is the alleged practice of some agents discounting a proportion of their commission to gain an enrolment sending the wrong signal to international students, namely that Australian education is not as good and more compromising of standards than some other nations.
(4) What evidence is available about an audit of the standards and accountability of `private education providers' in Australia.

(5) What level of follow-up and accountability is enforced to ensure that private colleges offering advanced diploma or associate diploma level awards are maintaining education standards and are not devaluing Australia's education system and reputation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The majority of recruitment agents for overseas students operate offshore and are therefore outside the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth. For this reason, direct enforcement by any Australian agency of Australian licensing or accreditation requirements presents significant legal and practical difficulties.

However, the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) has developed a Code of Practice (the MCEETYA Code) for the provision of international education and training services by Australian institutions. The MCEETYA Code specifically requires providers to be responsible for the actions of their appointed agents in relation to the marketing of services to, and the application processes for, overseas students and to make every reasonable effort to ensure that at all times these agents act in the best interests of the applicant and the provider.

The MCEETYA Code is given the force of law in some States and Territories, where compliance with it is explicitly required by State or Territory legislation. The Code is further supported by section 12 of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulations) Act 1991 (ESOS Act) which requires providers of courses to overseas students not to engage in misleading or deceptive conduct in connection with the recruitment of intending overseas students. In addition, section 6A of the ESOS Act (1991) holds private providers responsible for the pre-paid student fees from the time they are received directly by a provider or their agent.

It would be inappropriate for this regulatory function to be undertaken by the Australian International Education Foundation (AIEF). The role of the AIEF is to position Australia as a respected and influential partner in the international education, research and training community. It is an industry/government partnership with a key objective being the promotion and marketing of members' products and services to prospective overseas students. In fulfilling this objective the AIEF is developing specific programs to support off-shore agents who act on behalf of members by providing them with timely advice and information on policy and procedures related to study in Australia, enhancing their understanding of Australian education and training systems, and providing them with up to date information and materials on study in Australia.

Particular activities being undertaken by my Department's Education Counsellors based in Australian Diplomatic Missions in key markets is to support agents representing Australian institutions, including the development of a code of ethical practice for education recruitment agents, conducting agents' fora to provide information on Australia's international education policies and practices, and facilitating the agents understanding of, and commitment to, ensuring that only bona fide students who meet all Australian visa requirements apply for visas to study in Australia.

Although the AIEF does not act as a regulatory body it does provide an effective forum for the industry to make known views on those measures which will provide best support for the long term growth and integrity of the industry.

(2) The MCEETYA Code informs State/Territory legislation and administrative procedures for approving providers of services to overseas students who are then placed on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS). It also forms the basis of sector specific codes of practice in the provision of services to overseas students.

Sector specific codes of practice have been developed by peak industry organisations including: the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee (AVCC); Australian TAFE International (ATI); the English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students Association (ELICOS Association); and the Australian Council of Providers of Education and Training (ACPET).

These codes of practice seek to promote the development and maintenance within each sector of high standards of education and support services to overseas students. Sectoral codes of practice typically encompass activities involved in the marketing of sectoral products and services, selection and enrolment of overseas students and the provision of appropriate support services such as "International Student Contact Officers" to provide counselling and advisory services to overseas students.

In the private sector of the industry codes of practice complement the Tuition Assurance Schemes (TASs) which operate under the ESOS Act (1991). Each provider offering courses to overseas students must be a member of a TAS or have in place an alternative prescribed arrangement to protect students' fees. A TAS ensures that students will be provided their tuition by another member of the TAS should the original provider be unable to provide their course.

(3a) Australian institutions, including universities, generally utilise the services of overseas based agents to recruit students for their courses. These agents may charge a fee for a package of services to facilitate a students' application to an Australian institution. In this respect, agents are authorised by the Australian institution for which they recruit students. These institutions are bound by codes of practice, derived from the MCEETYA code of practice, which articulates the institution's responsibilities in selecting and dealing with agents. These responsibilities are given legal effect through the ESOS Act (1991) which, directly and through implication, requires providers to be responsible for the actions of their appointed agents.

Those intending overseas students who choose to do so may apply directly to the institution of their choice. For example, the Universities Admission Centre provides a mechanism whereby students are able to apply directly to a participating institution.

(3b) As stated above, education and training providers are responsible for the actions of their agents in the recruitment of intending overseas students. In order to support providers in ensuring that their agents are meeting "best practice" standards in the delivery of their services the AIEF is working with agents nominated by its members to improve the quality of their services. Additionally, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) is developing a program whereby selected reputable agents in major student source countries offshore will be offered a "preferred agent" protocol. The agents, who have demonstrated a commitment to ethical practices in preparing bona fide student visa applications, receive a competitive advantage by being authorised to issue visas directly to students.

(3c) Overseas students in Australia are free to transfer from one institution to another provided they maintain the conditions of their student visa. A provider's registration on CRICOS may be cancelled if a provider, directly or through their agent, has engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct in connection with the recruitment of an intending overseas student. My Department does not maintain records of students who change their course after commencement.
(3d) As stated above, Australian institutions are bound by the MCEETYA Code and industry codes to select agents who provide a high level of service.

The price an agent charges for the services provided to students is a matter for the market to determine and is agreed upon between the Australian institution, the agent, and the intending overseas student. My Department has no evidence to suggest that the market forces applying to the provision of agents' services is impacting negatively on perceptions of Australia's education and training services. The number of overseas students applying to study in Australian institutions continues to grow, with a 15.6% growth in enrolments in 1995. This growth in education and training exports contributed approximately a net $1.5 billion surplus to Australia's balance of payments in 1995 and is a key contributor to the strong export performance of service industries as a whole.
(4) The ESOS Act (1991) provides the regulatory framework for ensuring the quality of courses and the financial probity of course providers to overseas students.

All providers offering courses to overseas students must be registered on CRICOS. To be registered on CRICOS providers must meet the accreditation requirements of their respective State/Territory authority.

Under the ESOS Act (1991), course providers who are not the recipients of recurrent government funding (non‐exempt providers) are required to maintain trust accounts to ensure the prepayment of course fees by overseas students are protected. The monitoring of these trust accounts is undertaken by my Department.
Non-exempt providers are required also to meet the TAS requirements of the ESOS Act (1991).

An independent review is currently being conducted of the ESOS Act (1991) involving consultations with provider organisations, State/Territory authorities and the peak overseas student body. The preliminary conclusions of the review indicate broad support from all major stakeholders for the continuation of a national regulatory mechanism to ensure the continued high standard of course quality and financial probity in the industry.

(5) The accreditation and monitoring of course standards offered by private colleges is the responsibility of the relevant State/Territory authorities. The Commonwealth has assisted in the development of a consistent and national approach to qualifications accreditation through the Australian Qualifications Framework (AQF). This framework ensures that the levels, titles and intent of qualifications are consistent on a national level using qualification descriptors built on quality benchmarks for knowledge, skill, understanding and performance. The AQF provides clear educational and training pathways through the school, vocational training and university sectors.
The AIEF is developing a promotion strategy to capitalise in overseas markets on the strengths of Australia's single, unified framework of qualifications.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Higher education funding is allocated on a calendar year basis. As a result, figures have been provided for calendar years rather than financial years and are in Budget 1996 prices. In broad terms, an institution's level of operating grant per EFTSU is determined by the planned Commonwealth funded student load and total operating resources. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 7 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the staff‐student ratio for the `G8' universities for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years.
(2) What was the staff‐student ratio for the other universities for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years.
(3) Is the ratio different for different States; if so, why.
(4) Is the ratio different for former College of Advanced Education universities; if so, why.
(5) How does the ratio compare with other Organisation for Economic Co‐operation and development Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Student and staff data are collected on a calendar/academic year basis, not a financial year basis. Presentation of data as student‐staff ratios, and not staff‐student ratios as requested by the Senator, is standard within the higher education sector. Student‐staff ratios are defined as the ratio of student load, excluding industrial experience load, in EFTSU (equivalent full‐time student units), to academic staff with teaching only and teaching‐and‐research functions, in FTE (full‐time equivalence). 1995 casual staff data are not yet available so two sets of ratios are reported. The first set, for 1994, includes casual staff data, the second, for 1994 and 1995, excludes casual staff. The student‐staff ratio for the `G8' universities in 1994 (including casual staff) was 14.3, and for 1994 and 1995 excluding casual staff 16.6 and 16.8, respectively.
(2) For the remaining universities the student‐staff ratio for 1994 including casual staff was 15.9, and excluding casual staff 19.0 and 19.8 for 1994 and 1995, respectively.

(3) State student‐staff ratios in 1994 including casual staff were as follows: New South Wales 15.6; Victoria 15.2; Queensland 15.8; Western Australia 15.7; South Australia 13.9; Tasmania 14.8; Northern Territory 12.1; Australian Capital Territory 15.6; and Australia 15.3. Student‐staff ratios excluding casual staff in 1994 were: New South Wales 18.3; Victoria 18.2; Queensland 19.1; Western Australia 19.0; South Australia 15.7; Tasmania 16.0; Northern Territory 15.3; Australian Capital Territory 19.1; and Australia 18.1. 1995 Student‐staff ratios excluding casual staff were: New South Wales 18.6; Victoria 18.7; Queensland 19.5; Western Australia 19.4; South Australia 17.0; Tasmania 18.4; Northern Territory 16.1; the Australian Capital Territory 18.6; and Australia 18.5. Differences in ratios between States may reflect the nature of the universities in each State. For example, universities with higher postgraduate loads will have lower student‐staff ratios. The pre‐1988 universities, in particular the `G8', have long established postgraduate programs. Thus States with proportionately more students at pre‐1988 or `G8' universities will generally have a lower student‐ staff ratio than States with higher proportions attending post‐1988 universities.

(4) There is no straightforward comparison between `former Colleges of Advanced Education' and other universities, because many of the pre‐1988 universities absorbed Colleges of Advanced Education. However, we can compare pre‐1988 universities with post‐1988 universities. The student‐staff ratio in 1994 for the post‐1988 universities (including casual staff) (16.1) is higher than that for the pre‐1988 universities (G8—14.3, others 15.6). The ratios for each category, excluding casual staff, in 1994 were 16.6 for the `G8' universities, 18.1 for the remaining pre‐1988 universities and 19.9 for the post‐1988 universities. In 1995 the ratios increased for each category of university to 16.8 for the `G8', 18.8 for other pre‐1988 universities and 20.7 for post‐1988 universities.
(5) The OECD publication which lists details of the education systems of OECD countries is `Education at a Glance'. The most recent release lists 1993 data but does not report student‐staff ratios.
